PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Poland: Human Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That there are political prisoners in the Polish People's Republic.
That preparations are under way for another mass trial against members of the Confederation of Independent Poland.
That human rights are denied under the Communist Government of the Polish People's Republic.
That people of any nation in the Free World could find themselves under Soviet Occupation.
That the inhuman totalitarian system of Communism is openly heading towards controlling the entire world.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should do all in its power and authority, through the Government of Australia, to alleviate the suffering of the Polish people and to ensure the right of all people everywhere to freedom of speech.
That the Australian Government will not shut its eyes to the plight of others lest we see our own freedom of thought and speech reduced to mere mockery.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Warships
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled and to the Australian Government:
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out that:
foreign warships visiting Australian ports give acceptability to the increasing militarization of the Indian and Pacific Oceans;
W.A. endures a visit of a foreign warship on average every 1.5 weeks;
a situation of de facto `home-porting' facilities exists in W.A.;
there is increasing citizen concern that nuclear armed/nuclear powered warships put Australian ports and people at risk in many ways.
Your petitioners humbly pray that: The Australian Government refuse entry to Australian ports to all foreign warships.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
This petition of concerned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
Uranium mining and processing is dangerous to the health and well-being and ecology of the Earth and its citizens.
By-products of uranium are toxic for periods of up to 500,000 years, and are an intrinsic part of the production of nuclear weapons.
Existing safeguards are inadequate, and are not properly monitored.
The policy of the Australian Government permits the entry into Australia territory of vessels and aircraft without the assurance that they are not nuclear powered or armed.
Such vessels pose a threat to both the security and well-being of Australia and its citizens.
The presence of foreign military and communication bases on Australian soil seriously endangers the health and well-being of Australia and its citizens.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable Senators will take cognisance of the above and take immediate action to remove the above dangers.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Constitution
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of Australia:

The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully shows that there has been clear demonstration of public dissatisfaction with the mismanagement of the Victorian Otway forests, and we pray that: the Constitution of Australia be reformed to recognise significant expressions of public concern, eg petitions, by the formation of a committee to represent public requests
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Otway Forests, Victoria: Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of certain citizens of Australia shows that woodchipping and clearfelling will destroy the Otway Forests, water catchments and jobs in tourism.
Your petitioners therefore pray that you will protect the Otway Forests for the future and refuse any licence to export woodchips from the Otways.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will every pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements Prohibition Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully shows:

That we strongly support `The A.C.T. Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements Prohibition Bill' introduced by Senator Evans, because it represents the first positive national step towards the eventual elimination of widespread serious ill health caused by smoking tobacco.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Petrol Distributors and Retailers
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament House assembled.

We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, humbly pray that the Parliament act to outlaw the practice of the large petrol companies also controlling petrol retail outlets in competition with independent petrol distributers and retailers who they supply, thus acting in a position of unfair competition, and leading to the large companies exerting unconscionable pressure on those independent distributers and retailers.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:

That the proposed Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985 will endanger the Federal system in Australia, the State and Federal criminal justice systems, the State and Federal Police Force, the State and Federal education systems, the independence of the churches and religious associations, marriage and the family, children, the unborn, the handicapped, the aged and the infirm, employer and employee relationships and Australian society generally.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That your Honourable House defer debate on the Bill for twelve months and circulate the Bill for twelve months for the widest possible debate, scrutiny and discussion, and your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Peter Baume (from 20 citizens), Michael Baume (from 28 citizens), Parer (from 10 citizens) and Sanders (from 36 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian Bill of Rights Bill is a harmful, dangerous and divisive proposal, the provisions of which are authoritarian and anti-democratic.
Your petitioners therefore pray:
That the Senate rejects this Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Jessop (from 114 citizens) and Parer (from 58 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we oppose utterly the proposed Bill of Rights because this Bill will-
Transfer to government powers not given nor intended to be given by the Constitution
Threaten our rights by making them subject to the will of this and any future Government
Turn the Human Rights Commission into a political Star Chamber with unjustifiable power
Abrogate Common Law and common liberty
Set the State above the individual
Restrict Rights to those specified by the Bill.
We the undersigned believe in democracy and freedom and earnestly entreat you to recognise that this Bill will undermine the fundamental basis of these.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should reject a Bill of Rights in this or any other form.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we deplore the proposed Bill of Rights because it adversely affects areas of the liberty and freedom of Australians. It will operate against:
The States and our Federal system of Government
Criminal Justice
The Police
Education
Families
Employer/Employee relations

It will remove the power of the people through Parliament, by giving power to a new more powerful Human Rights Commission which is not elected, but can act as a Star Chamber. We do most earnestly wish to keep our system of Common Law.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should reject this Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Australian Bill of Rights will do nothing to advance the rights of Australians, because it is dangerously ambiguous and will cause confusion within the legal system; it endangers our Federal system; and, it is to be administered in an authoritarian manner inconsistent with the present legal rights of all Australians.
Your petitioners therefore pray:
That the Senate rejects the Australian Bill of Rights Bill and all cognate Bills.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Hawke Government's failure to correct the anomalies arising from the application of the assets test on pensioners, with the failure of the Australian Democrats to support Senator Messner's Bill to repeal the assets test, is causing unnecessary hardship for Australia's aged, particularly those living in rural areas.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Hawke Government will itself take action to repeal its iniquitous and anomalous test.
And your petitioners as in duty bound ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That certain Trade Unions are currently forcing employers and employees to join union-controlled Superannuation schemes through industrial blackmail, thereby extending the Unions' economic power and at the same time infringing individual rights.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government:
(i) Guarantee that Occupational Superannuation is a matter of individual choice
(ii) Declare illegal industrial standover tactics which force people to join superannuation schemes controlled by, or sponsored by, trade unions.
(iii) Protect those companies and their employees who establish their own superannuation arrangements at the enterprise level.
(iv) Ensure that union or industry-based schemes are not disguised pay rises by providing that employees must also make contributions.
(v) Provide that control of the funds of such schemes is vested in the elected representative of the contributors to those schemes
(vi) Oppose any backdoor attempts at achieving compulsory unionism.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Oil Prices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
Your petitioners most humbly pray:
(i) that the Hawke Labor Government pass on the full benefits of lower international oil prices on March 1st, 1986; and
(ii) that the Hawke Labor Government does not increase or extend fuel taxes
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Female Circumcision
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned believes:
(1) That the practice of female circumcision is barbaric.
(2) That this practice is objectionable and alien to the standards and beliefs of a majority of Australians.
(3) That the practice contravenes the notions of individual rights and liberties that are strongly held in Australia.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should request the Government to use its powers to eradicate the barbaric practice of female circumcision.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Notice of Intention to Withdraw Notice of Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to standing order 190A, I give notice that it is my intention, at a later hour this day, to withdraw Business of the Senate Notice of Motion No. 1 standing in my name for this day of sitting relating to the disallowance of the First Home Owners Regulations (Amendment). I seek leave to make a short statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances has been considering a provision in these regulations under which the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) has prescribed the Secretary to the Department of Social Security and the Commissioner of the Australian Taxation Office as persons to whom may be given confidential information relating to applicants for grants under the first home owners scheme. The objective behind the prescription is to counter fraudulent social security and tax claims. The Committee did not object to that aim but it suggested that, in order to protect privacy, the regulations should expressly set out the type of information to be released and the circumstances in which it could be released. As the regulations stood they placed no legal impediment in the way of releasing any information in any circumstances to the departments concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee has received an undertaking from the Minister that he will have the regulations amended so that the new regulations will expressly set out the circumstances in which defined types of confidential and personal information may be released from the first home owners scheme to the Department of Social Security and the Australian Taxation Office. These matters were settled only this morning and consequently I seek to withdraw the Committee's notice of motion on this day when it is due for debate by using standing order 109A. I seek leave to have the Minister's letter incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Chairman
Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
The Senate
Parliament House
Canberra, ACT 2600
Dear Senator Cooney,
I refer to your letter dated 18 March 1986, and to our previous correspondence in connection with the First Home Owners Regulations (Amendment) (Statutory Rules 1985 No. 267).

As indicated in my previous letters, I am mindful of the views of the Committee and share your concern that the privacy of citizens be protected from any unwarranted intrusions by the bureaucracy. I have reconsidered the matter as requested and agree to amend the Regulations to describe the type of information to be divulged and the particular conditions to be satisfied before this occurs.

You will appreciate that it may take some time to develop Regulations and identify the nature of information which may be sought by the Australian Taxation Office or the Department of Social Security. Pending the development of the necessary legislative proposal I agree not to alter the administrative policy which is described in detail in my earlier letters. In the meantime I will continue to use the certification procedure set out in Section 29 (2) (a) of the First Home Owners Act 1983.

This will ensure that the rights to privacy of individuals providing information to my Department in connection with their First Home Owners Scheme application will be afforded a necessary measure of protection.
I trust that the above agreement satisfies the requirements of your Committee.
Yours sincerely
STEWART WEST

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee thanks the Minister for Housing and Construction for the assistance he and his officials have given it in this matter and commends the Minister for his willingness to amend the regulations and allay its concerns.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Cooney) agreed to:
That Business of the Senate, Notice of Motion No. 1 standing in my name for this day, for the disallowance of the First Home Owners Regulations (Amendment), be postponed till a later hour of the day.

Motion (by Senator Vigor) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Judiciary Act 1903 to facilitate the bringing of class actions.
Bill presented by Senator Vigor, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate my second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
On 15 March 1962 President John F. Kennedy of the United States inaugurated World Consumer Rights Day. In doing so, he spelt out seven rights which consumers should be entitled to:
the right to safety
the right to be informed
the right to choose
the right to be heard
the right to redress
the right to consumer education
the right to a healthy environment.
The Class Actions Bill which I am bringing forward today, 24 years later, will bring the right of redress of Australian consumers into the 20th century.

It will also provide practical protection to small business people, such as the owner-driver truckies, who are at the mercy of unscrupulous insurance operators, or unconscionable contracts designed by financiers.

Furthermore, it will give an incentive to manufacturing industry to institute quality control procedures which will hopefully make our goods synonymous with the highest standards of reliability, and therefore more attractive to overseas purchasers.
We cannot afford to remain a country attached to mediocrity and to the protection of the shonky industrialist or merchant.

That, unfortunately, is the situation at the moment, simply because ordinary Australians do not have in their grasp proper remedies for dealing with situations where they have been cheated or have suffered damage as a result of poor business practices.

The costs of litigation in this country are prohibitive, except for the very rich, or for those who qualify for legal aid. For a lot of ordinary honest Australians the option of legal redress is not available in practice.
Our legal system itself is quite antiquated in many respects, despite the efforts of some tireless individuals.

Long delays in legal processes and an inability of our courts to deal efficiently with many matters have led to the creation of administrative forums, such as small claims courts and residential tenancies tribunals, to deal more informally, expeditiously and inexpensively with the resolution of disputes.
Despite the valiant attempts of various reformers, the procedures used in our legal system have advanced very little since the passage in the United Kingdom in 1873 of the Judicature Act.

In 1910, in the case of Markt & Co. Ltd v Knight Steamship Co. Ltd, it was held by a majority of an English Court of Appeal that a representative action could not be brought on behalf of the 45 traders whose cargo was lost when a Russian cruiser captured, and then sank, the ship the Knight Commando on finding that it contained contraband.

Two of the three judges held that there was no interest common to the traders because their claims to compensation on account of the breach of an implied undertaking that the Knight Commando would not carry contraband, were based on separate contracts of shipment.
This ruling effectively closed off the common law opportunity to sue for damages in a representative capacity. This Bill is aimed at re-establishing that remedy at law.
In the United States, from the same representative action foundation has sprung a quite robust system of class actions, though not without its problems.

I have examined American developments, the work of the Australian Law Reform Commission in the nine years since its reference on class actions and standing, and the splendid 1977 report of the Law Reform Committee of South Australia relating to class actions.
I wish to pay tribute to that Law Reform Committee chaired by His Honour, Mr Justice Zelling.
Its pellucid report includes a draft Bill for a Class Actions Act which has been of great inspiration in the drawing up of this Bill.

I commend to all honourable Senators a perusal of that report, because it goes to the heart of differences between Australian and American legal practice, and in its recommendations deals most effectively with some of the problems which the American system has highlighted, particularly in the past two decades since the adoption in 1966 of Rule 23 of the Federal Rules of Civic Procedure for the United States District Courts.

By taking our lead from the South Australian Law Reform Committee, we have fashioned procedures which will make justice available to all Australians without putting at risk the conscientious and scrupulous trader or manufacturer.
I have already mentioned the high cost of litigation, which effectively prevents many people from pursuing their rights through the courts.
Small claims tribunals have now been established in the States.
These are unfortunately often under-resourced, and as a result are not always able to mediate effectively in disputes.
They are certainly unable to cope with any large scale problem such as systematic fraudulent conduct on a mass scale, or general quality control negligence.

The point is made very strongly in the August 1984 publication of the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisation, `The Role of Prosecution in Consumer Protection', that the State agencies are not able to deter corporate misbehaviour.

In this report we see that for every consumer affairs conviction in Australia, there are more than 200 written complaints which do not lead to a conviction, and conservatively over 2,000 unwritten complaints.
I do not believe that we should tolerate a situation in which the same shysters continue to fleece decent Australians day after day, year after year.
We certainly should not be encouraging sharp and unethical practices, and that is what a lax legal system does.
Our trading reputation is brought into disrepute.
There is an enormous wastage of time, effort, and often money, to rectify situations which should never have occurred in the first place.
I want the system to reward the honest and scrupulous trader, merchant, manufacturer or corporation.
I want those who stick to ethical behaviour, and try to provide a real service to the community to prosper!
Every time we eliminate an unscrupulous operator, we can be certain that our available resources will be used more effectively as a result.
This Bill will aid that process.
A good way to achieve this is to enable people to band together for the purpose of obtaining relief where they have suffered loss or damage through negligence or malfeasance.
Currently the unscrupulous rely on the high cost and trouble associated with litigation to merely engender in an individual an angry but powerless acceptance of what has happened.
Once we adopt class action these sharp operators will find it essential to clean up their act if they are to remain in business, as their penalties will be too great.
That will be good for the whole community.
We will find fewer dangerous products on the market, be exposed to fewer sharp practices, experience fewer toxic spillages or emissions, and be subject to less false advertising.
It is important to realise that the class action mechanism does not create new offences.
The same standards of proof will be required of the plaintiffs as under any other court actions.

Ordinary honest Australians will no longer be intimidated just because they do not have the financial resources to match giant corporations and agencies. Instead of being frightened off by the prospect of an adverse court decision which could ruin them, they will be able to group together, combine their evidence, and properly test the matter in the courts.
`Equality before the law' will take on a real meaning.
That is surely a minimum requirement for a just society.
Not just consumers can benefit in this way.
The lessees in a shopping complex could join together in an attempt to force management to comply with some neglected or abruptly altered aspect of their contractual agreement.
Farmers whose interests might be adversely affected by an authority's plans would more readily be able to mount a challenge on the legality of what the authority was proposing.
Employees subjected to injurious or discriminatory practices could challenge a corporate wrongdoer.
In each of these cases at present, the relative imbalance of resources often allows the Goliath to act with impunity. This David is trying to stop that through this Bill!
Class action can also be of benefit to the defending companies.

For even though individuals are generally deterred from seeking legal redress by their lack of resources, there are circumstances in which a long run of lost individual cases with all of the attached legal costs can cripple a company.
The uncertainty over how many extra suits can be expected and how to make provision for the future can jeopardise an entire operation of a company.
Class action is much cleaner and less may be spent on litigation, more on remedy.
This process of attrition has happened with A. H. Robins in the United States.

Since 1972, there have been more than 10,000 law suits filed against A. H. Robins on account of the Dalkon Shield's involvement in causing pelvic inflammatory disease, spontaneous abortion, sterility and death.
More than 9,300 actions have been settled for over $378m in damages and $107m in legal costs, the largest award to an individual being $6.2m.
In 1984, consumer groups were successful in getting the Food and Drug Administration to organise a programme of removal of all Dalkon Shields still in use, at the expense of A. H. Robins.
Similar steps are being taken in Australia, except that the company is not being asked to pay for the removal of the devices.
On 2 April 1985, A. H. Robins announced that it was setting up a $615m reserve fund to pay future claimants.

On 21 August, it changed its mind and filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code which provides for corporate reorganisation and a cut-off point for liabilities.
At that stage over 5,000 suits by victims seeking hundreds of millions of dollars in damages were pending.
This has led to the U.S. District Court in Richmond, Virginia establishing 30 April this year as the date by which claimants against A. H. Robins must register with the courts.
Well over a thousand Australian women have done so already.
It is amazing that we had neither the legal mechanisms nor insurance requirements for such actions to be taken here.
Another interesting American case where the protection of generous bankruptcy proceedings was sought, was that of the asbestos miner and manufacturer Manville Corporation.
It filed for bankruptcy in 1982 and has recently proposed to emerge from bankruptcy by paying $2,500m to settle the claims of asbestos-disease victims.
Just as A. H. Robins has done, Manville declared at the time that it was financially healthy but needed protection from the continuing burden of litigation.
I remind honourable senators that we too have had major problems with asbestos at both Baryugil in New South Wales and Wittenoom in Western Australia.
Although the facts of the matter would have been common in a lot of cases, we have forced victims to `try', sue, even beg, for compensation one at a time.
They have not always been able to obtain proper redress.
The matter remains a blot on our industrial conscience.

Insurance companies are able to continue their practice of settling out of court with other insurance companies, but taking individuals right through the legal process in a game of brinkmanship. They might well consider this practice if a class action were available to the group of such victimised people.
If this Act were in force, it would be far less likely that anyone caught with a batch of dangerous goods would seek to ship them on elsewhere in Australia.
The absence of a consumer affairs prohibition order would not, as now, provide them with cover for such heinous activity.
Motor car manufacturers would be far more likely to quickly establish the causes of a batch of lemons, would take more rapid remedial action both towards the consumer and the workplace.
Rural buying cartels would find it much more difficult to impose harsh and unfair conditions on the farmers or growers from whom they were buying.
Waste disposal companies would think twice before dumping toxic materials which could affect people's health or the environment.
Many other cases can be cited.
I wish to refer to some aspects of the Bill to highlight its features.

Before doing so, I should point out that this measure is quite different from the American situation in three fundamental aspects, and hence certain criticisms voiced in the United States are totally without foundation here.
Firstly, we do not have `contingent fees' for lawyers, whereas that practice is the norm in the United States and may lead to litigation which would not occur elsewhere.
In any case, before a class action can proceed in accordance with my Bill, the plaintiff's counsel must convince the court that the action is brought in good faith and appears to have merit.

Secondly, ever since the 1974 decision in Eisen v Carlisle and Jacquelin to the effect that the plaintiff would have to mail a notice to over 2 million buyers of odd-lot shares on the New York Stock Exchange between 1962 and 1966, the problem of giving due notice to all members of a class has often caused a United States class action to become unmanageable.
In my formulation, the court is given discretion to deal with this contact in the most sensible manner available.

Thirdly, in the United States, there is strict liability and courts may impose punitive damages. It is enough in the United States to merely establish that damage or loss has occurred. Under our common law negligence also has to be proved.

In addition, American courts can impose damages far in excess of the losses actually sustained by plaintiffs, either through the minimum damages provisions of legislation such as the Truth in Lending Act, 1976, or the treble damages provisions in anti-trust cases.

While section 11 of the Australian Industries Preservation Act, 1906, modelled on the U.S. Sherman Act, allowed treble damages, the advent of the Trade Practices Act 1965-66 coincided with the repeal of that section.
Overall then, neither the tendency to litigation nor the cost and damages pressures are as great in Australia as they have been in the United States.
The Bill that I have introduced certainly cuts out any frivolous attempts to bring about class actions.

Not only must the action be brought in good faith and appear to have merit, but also the representative party has to demonstrate its capacity to adequately and fairly represent and protect the interests of the members of that class.
A period of time is made available for members of the class to be given notice of the action and to opt out, if they so choose.
If they do not, they are bound by the decision and are not able to litigate separately.
That introduces a degree of certainty for the defendant.

If the Court gives judgment for the plaintiff in a class action but does not determine questions of law or fact that affect only individual members of the class, there is an orderly procedure for the filing of individual claims and their assessment.

This may well occur if there are separate contracts or transactions made or entered into between members of the class and the defendant, and an evaluation has to be made of the damage suffered in each case.

While the relief sought is allowed to be monetary, it of course can take many other forms such as honouring of a contract, an end to a discriminatory practice, or the clean up of environmental damage.

A Class Action Fund is established to accept moneys appropriated out of Consolidated Revenue, moneys not able to be distributed to members of the class, refunds of moneys that are advanced by the Attorney-General for the purpose of facilitating the action, and interest on these moneys.
Having given Australians a real chance of exercising their legal rights, we must not allow technical barriers to snatch those rights away in practice.

Hence major attempts to notify members of a class may be covered by the Class Action Fund if the merits of the case and the financial resources of the plaintiff are such that the Attorney-General acquiesces.
Where funding for costs has been advanced in this way, it is recoverable against costs subsequently awarded to a successful plaintiff.
Costs can be awarded to defendants in relation to those matters peripheral to the class action proper.

The courts are further able to asses the proportion of solicitor and client costs to be borne by the members of the class, and the way in which any deficiency between the net amount available for distribution and the total of individual entitlements is to be handled.

The Judiciary Amendment (Class Actions) Bill is a real opportunity for this Parliament to show that it cares about justice in Australia, the cost of that justice and the effectiveness of the avenue that leads to it.
I urge honourable senators to give it proper attention and to also address themselves to other much needed reforms of the legal system. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator McIntosh) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Walsh) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to propose amendments to the Foreign Takeovers Act 1975 arising from the Government's review of foreign investment policy, the results of which were announced on 29 October 1985. The modifications to the policy have been designed to streamline the existing processes, facilitate certain types of investment proposals and contribute to the Government's wider aim of reducing the burden on business of government regulation.

The policy modifications were decided upon having regard to the continuing need for a balance to be struck between the economic benefits of foreign investment and community concerns about foreign ownership and control of Australia's industries and resources. That need, I believe, has been recognised by all parties for over a decade now and will continue to be recognised by this Government.
The Government welcomes and encourages foreign investment that has beneficial economic effects and is consistent with the needs and aspirations of the Australian community.

In its assessment of proposals for investment in Australia, the Government continues to give substantial weight to their development and employment creating aspects; to keep the degree of foreign ownership and control within acceptable bounds; and to ensuring that through the Australian equity participation guidelines there are opportunities for Australians to participate in the development of local industries and resources.

As announced on 29 October 1985, the necessary amendments to the Foreign Takeovers Act arise from the Government's decisions to exempt acquisitions by foreign investors of existing mining exploration rights and to increase the `offshore takeovers' threshold. These two proposed amendments affect sections 5 and 13 of the principal Act.

Acquisitions by foreign interests of mineral exploration rights generally do not raise sensitive issues concerning ownership and control of Australian resources and are not, therefore, required to satisfy the normal policy criteria.

Proposed mining developments resulting from successful exploration will still need to be submitted for examination under foreign investment policy and such proposals will continue to be subject to the Australian equity participation guidelines.
The proposed amendments to section 13 of the Act will raise the threshold above which offshore takeovers are subject to examination under the Act.

Offshore takeovers are those where an offshore company with assets in Australia is acquired by another offshore company. This type of transaction does not involve any reduction in Australian ownership and control and has been found in practice to be unlikely to raise issues contrary to the national interest.

At present, the Act requires the notification of offshore takeovers if the value of the Australian assets involved exceeds $3m, a threshold which has not been adjusted since it was established in 1975. The proposed amendments will raise the threshold to $20m. Where the Australian assets represent 50 per cent or more of the worldwide assets of the business being acquired, the notification requirement remains irrespective of the value of the Australian assets.

The Bill proposes some additional amendments to the Act which do not affect the features or administration of the Government's foreign investment policy. They are designed to tidy up the Act and bring it up to date following changes in other Commonwealth legislation. They will, for instance, remove from the Act those provisions which have been made redundant by amendments to the Acts Interpretation Act and the Judiciary Act.
The Bill will have no financial impact.

The proposed amendments to section 5 and 13 of the Foreign Takeovers Act 1975 represent only one part of the overall package of foreign investment policy modifications announced on 29 October last year. The changes announced at that time that did not require statutory implementation have already been implemented by administrative action. Under those changes, the `opportunities test' was abolished, certain thresholds under foreign investment policy were increased significantly and policy in respect of merchant banks, other non-bank financial institutions, insurance companies and real estate was liberalised.

In total, the changes to foreign investment policy announced last October represent a major step towards reducing the regulatory costs of foreign investment policy. Based on past experience, the changes will either exempt from examination or simplify and streamline the examination process for around one-third of proposals that have been subject to foreign investment screening. The Government has demonstrated its commitment to the removal of those parts of regulations which are burdensome and contribute little benefit to Australia. I commend this Bill to the Senate.

The Senate is dealing with regulations that allow the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) to all intents and purposes to dodge a Federal Court decision of 16 December 1985. The Minister and the Department have an obligation under law to provide export meat inspection services on request. The regulations we are now debating give the Minister and the Department discretion on four possible grounds: First, efficiency; secondly, staff safety; thirdly, industry interests; and, fourthly, national interest. No amount of flowery language can disguise the fact that the Opposition considers this a cop-out. We have here a very necessary service because, without it, Australia cannot export its meat to other countries. The service is recognised by other countries and provides the imprimatur to our meat exports so that they meet the health requirements of this nation and those to which we export. Without the service, no matter what else happens along the train, meat cannot effectively be exported from this nation.

It comes as no surprise to anybody interested in this debate that the catalyst for these regulations was the Mudginberri dispute. I might also point out that this service, which is necessary and has been provided by Commonwealth meat inspectors, is funded to at least 50 per cent by the producers in this country. Yet they have had no say in it. They have no say in its efficiencies. They have been annoyed and devastated by this Government's action and its inability to come to grips with the situation that existed at Mudginberri last year.

The Government has seen fit to provide these regulations which allow it a cop-out from its responsibilities, responsibilities that the Opposition and the industry see as belonging to the Government in providing this very necessary service. It is just coincidental that at this time the Senate is also debating the Bill of Rights. We have listened almost ad nauseam to the Government proclaiming its commitments to human rights.

But we look at the Mudginberri affair and what do we find? We have an arrangement between the employer and the employee on wages and conditions, and we have an agreement which was ratified in the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, an arrangement which was to the mutual benefit of the employer and the employee and, dare I say, to the community and the nation. We had an export abattoir operating efficiently, operating with the goodwill of all concerned, and operating in harmony-and it also had markets. Yet we saw a picket line put on by another group of meat workers belonging to the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union.

It is significant that we should ponder at this time, with all the flowery language from the Government about the necessity in this nation for a Bill of Rights-something that we have opposed quite vehemently-about the rights of workers to negotiate. What about their rights? I ask members of the Government to cast their minds back to that group of people who have been considered to be the foundation of the union movement-the Tolpuddle Martyrs. Significantly, they were also involved in primary industry. They were farm labourers. They were treated very harshly by the authorities at the time because they wanted the right to negotiate. From that small beginning, the great union movements of the world have evolved. Yet now we have regulations introduced to allow the Government a cop-out because a group of workers has sat around a table and negotiated a satisfactory agreement with their employer. They have made competitive what was once a meat works which was not very competitive. They have earned themselves higher salaries than they could ever have hoped to earn previously. They have provided jobs in the Northern Territory. It must be noted that almost two-thirds of beef cattle in the Northern Territory are killed elsewhere because of the high cost structure up there.

So, we have a group of people who have met every criterion that one would want to think about on how to negotiate, how to look after themselves and how to make suitable arrangements with their employer. We have a government that is bringing in the nefarious Bill of Rights and talking about human rights whilst, at the same time as it is doing that, bringing in regulations which allow it to cop out from its responsibilities of providing a meat inspection service so that these people can go about doing what they want to do, providing very much needed export dollars for this nation, handling stock in the Northern Territory and providing jobs there-anything that one can think of. Yet this Government is copping out by trying to introduce regulations which negate its responsibility to provide that very much needed export service.

We are a trading nation. If we are not trading, we are in trouble. At present we are not trading too well. The cumulative current account deficit, to February this year, is running at $9.468 billion. It has almost overtaken the total current account deficit for 1984-85, which was $10.534 billion. In other words, in 1985-86 we are heading for a current account deficit in the vicinity of $13 billion-plus. Significantly, the cumulative three-year current account deficit for the Hawke Government-we are into anniversaries now; we have heard all about the Government's three-year anniversary recently-is in excess of $30 billion. In other words, we have imported $30 billion more than we have exported. Our overseas debt is running at in excess of $70 billion, which is double the debt of $36.4 billion when the Hawke Government came to power. In other words, we are consuming more than we are producing and buying more than we are selling.

The beef industry is a major contributor to our export earnings. The last figures I was able to get rather quickly were for 1983-84, when the beef industry contributed $1.114 billion or 4.5 per cent of our total exports and 17.6 per cent of our agricultural exports. The people of Australia have to realise-an education program should be in train-that we are a trading nation, that if we are not trading we are in trouble and that if we are not trading well we are also in trouble. That is the situation at present. In other words, any responsible government should be doing all in its power to encourage anybody who can export, most of all an exporter who is doing so with a suitable arrangement with his employees. The Government should be doing all it can to encourage exports and should be educating the people of this nation, particularly the work force, to the fact that we need to trade and that, if we do not trade, we are in trouble.

There are some points to remember about the Mudginberri dispute. I remind honourable senators, and anybody else who is interested, that at one time the Commonwealth meat inspectors at Mudginberri lived on site. Some time before this dispute came to a head they were moved from Mudginberri to live in Jabiru. That is quite significant and should be remembered when we talk about cop-outs by this Government. It is quite significant that the Commonwealth meat inspectors moved from Mudginberri, where they were on site, to Jabiru. In other words, if and when a dispute arose and a picket line were formed, they would have to cross that picket line, which, as history would have it, is what happened. It is also significant that, although the Northern Territory inspectors, who are as well qualified as the Commonwealth inspectors, could have been licensed, they were not.

So, we have three cop-outs. We have the most recent cop-out, which we are debating today. We have the cop-out of moving the Commonwealth inspectors from Mudginberri to Jabiru so that they would have to go past a picket line. We also have the cop-out that the Minister for Primary Industry chose not to license the Northern Territory inspectors to handle the meat for export from the Mudginberri abattoir. It is also significant-the chamber should be reminded of this-that the picket line at Mudginberri was in breach of all the regulations which apply to the Kakadu National Park. If any of us tried to do the same thing, to live on site in a camp and cut down trees, we would be in all sorts of trouble. Even in regard to that aspect this Government has not met its commitments and responsibilities.

Quite significantly, after the negotiations took place and the Mudginberri abattoir started to work, its killing costs were reduced from $140 per head to $40 per head. Interestingly, the last figures available for the Katherine Meatworks indicate that its killing costs were $159 per head. It closed down, it is still closed down, and no wonder. Following the negotiation that took place and with the arrangements that were made we saw increased productivity, increased wages, lower killing costs, a competitive abattoir which had markets, but all to no avail. Every criterion one would wish-every criterion of the union movement-was met, yet because of the intransigence, almost conservatism, of the AMIEU, it was all to no avail. It was not only because of the AMIEU. This Government is also in the grip of the AMIEU and the Australian Council of Trade Unions. It is not game to take any decisions, and has to do what it is told. As a result we have this tragedy in the Northern Territory.

What makes matters worse now is that the Government, having been ruled out of order and having been told to accept its responsibilities by the Federal Court of Australia, is now looking for a cop-out. It is almost like McEnroe playing tennis and taking on both the linesmen and the umpire. But at the end of the day McEnroe has to knuckle down. At the end of the day this Government chose not to knuckle down and obey the decisions of the linesmen and the umpire but to change the rules of the game. That is what these regulations are all about. No matter what flowery language the Minister uses and no matter what examples he gives of other Commonwealth legislation, this is purely and simply a cop-out. It is seen as that by the Opposition and it is seen as that by the industry. This industry is currently the one bright spot in the whole of our export orientated industries. There is still a good export market for our beef, and the beef industry is holding up.

As I said previously, as a trading nation one would think that we would be doing everything in our power to encourage this nation to trade and to encourage anybody who is in the export business to become more efficient. The name Mudginberri will live long in this nation in the annals of industrial relations. It is almost like the Alamo. In the Alamo, of course, a small group of people stood out against some insurmountable odds. I think Mudginberri will be remembered not so much for a small group of people standing out against insurmountable odds; it will be remembered in the annals of Australia's industrial relations that we had a group of people who, with good will, sat down around a negotiating table and negotiated how they would work, negotiated the wages to the mutual benefit and satisfaction of both sides, went about their work with increased productivity and went about their work of providing much needed export dollars for a nation which is in grave trouble, yet the Minister for Primary Industry saw fit not to help them by providing the meat export service.

The legislation says that the meat export service should be provided and it is the opinion of the Opposition that that service should be provided. It is the opinion of the industry-I remind this chamber once again that the industry is paying 50 per cent of the cost of the service-that this service should be provided. I think common sense also would dictate that in an economy that is in such a bad state as ours is for a trading nation the service should be provided at all times. In the last couple of weeks there have been disputes at two meatworks in Queensland-Biloela and Merinda-holding up once again much needed export dollars.

It is very necessary that this Government take a long hard look at what it is doing. It is in its interest, the interest of the union movement and the interests of all Australians that Mudginberris should be allowed to happen. Nothing that this Government does should prevent that happening and prevent the export of beef to other countries, bringing into this country much needed dollars.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Collard) agreed to:

That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Business of the Senate, Notice of Motion No. 3 standing in the name of Senator Chaney, for the disallowance of Prescribed Goods (General) Orders No. 100a being debated and voted on with Business of the Senate, Order of the Day relating to the disallowance of Prescribed Goods (General) Orders No. 111a.
Motion for Disallowance
Motion (by Senator Collard for Senator Chaney) proposed:

That Order 100a of the Prescribed Goods (General) Orders, as contained in the Prescribed Goods (General) Orders as Amended (Amendment) (being Export Control Orders No. 2 of 1986) and made under the Export Control Act 1982, be disallowed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating motions to disallow two regulations. The important regulation is Order 111A, directions by Minister, of the Prescribed Goods (General) Orders as amended, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Notwithstanding anything provided in orders, where the Minister considers that it is desirable, taking into account the national interest, that a decision which may be made by the Secretary under orders is made in a particular manner, so as to achieve a particular result, the Minister may direct the Secretary to make that decision in that manner or in such manner as will achieve that result.

I indicate at the outset that the Australian Democrats will support the motion for disallowance of this regulation. The matter at hand is relatively complex. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) raised the issue in the House of Representatives that it is normal practice for government to proceed in the manner in which the Government is proceeding. The Government has instanced a number of Acts, for example, the Telecommunications Act 1975, section 7 of which reads:

The Minister may, after consultation with the Commission, give to the Commission, in writing, such directions with respect to the performance of its functions and the exercise of its powers, as appear to the Minister to be necessary in the public interest.

I invite honourable senators to compare that wording `as appears to the Minister to be necessary in the public interest' with the phrase in this regulation `taking into account the national interest'. The next Act mentioned by the Minister was the Postal Services Act 1975, section 8 of which states:

The Minister may, after consultation with the Commission, give to the Commission, in writing, such directions, with respect to the performance of its functions and the exercise of its powers, as appear to the Minister to be necessary in the public interest.

Again we see the phrase `in the public interest'. The next Act referred to and relied upon by the Government was the Australian Tourism Commission Act 1967. Under this Act, unlike the other two that I have mentioned, the directions given by the Minister do not have to be tabled. It is interesting that this Act was introduced under a Liberal-National Party government, in other words, under the Opposition parties which are now making so much noise on this issue. Under at least one of the Acts referred to by the Government, the direction was not required to be tabled, although similar directions were provided. One sees a similar situation in the Australian Shipping Commission Act 1956, in which the direction must be tabled. This again is of interest. The direction to the Commission, section 18 (2), says:

Where the Minister is satisfied that it is desirable in the public interest to do so, he may, by notice in writing to the Commission, give directions to the Commission with respect to the performance of its functions or duties or the exercise of its powers.
Once again the phrase `in the public interest' is stated quite clearly. An Act relating to the rural area, the Wheat Marketing Act 1979, states in section 11:
The Minister may give directions to the Board concerning the performance of its functions and the exercise of its powers, and the Board shall comply with those directions.

That Act was passed under a Liberal-National Party government. Under that Act the directions are not required to be tabled, so the Parliament would not even have the benefit of the items being tabled. Let us consider more recent Acts, such as the Aboriginal Development Commission Act 1980. Again, this was a Liberal Party Act. We find similar provisions in section 11 (1):
The Commission shall perform its functions and exercise its powers in accordance with such general directions as are given to it by the Minister in writing.
Schedule 1 to the Commonwealth Functions (Statutes Review) Bill 1981 contained amendments to the Wool Industry Act 1972. They included adding the following to section 76:

(3) Where the Minister is satisfied that the retention by the Corporation of land or a building to which this Part applies is not necessary to the maintenance by the Corporation of a minimum wool storage capacity, the Minister may, by writing under his hand, direct the Corporation to dispose of, in such manner and on such terms and conditions as are specified in the instrument of direction . . .

Obviously, in that Act there is no reference, because it concerns a different matter. Another Act relied on by the Government is the Australian National Railways Commission Act 1983, an interesting Act. Section 19 (2) states:
Where the Minister is satisfied that it is desirable in the public interest to do so-
again we see the phrase `in the public interest to do so'-
he may, by notice in writing to the Commission, give directions to the Commission with respect to the performance of its functions or duties or the exercise of its powers.

The interesting thing about that Act is that section 20 provides for remuneration of costs for complying with directions. That is an interesting feature that came in in 1983 that may well form part of the operation of the Government's proposals on export inspection, if we proceed with them.

Looking at the next item that I will refer to, the Building Industry Act 1985, this is again a rather interesting Act. The important thing here is that there are circumstances in which inspectors are required to inspect, for example, the progress in building work. Honourable senators will remember the Building Industry Act 1985 because it is one that we passed through this chamber only last year and concerned the Builders Labourers Federation. I must admit that there was unanimous support from all parts of the chamber for this. If we are looking for a matter of principle, it is probably about the best one around. I refer to the `orders by Minister in relation to Federation' in section 5 (1) which states:
Where the Commission makes a declaration under section 4, the Minister may, if the Minister is of the opinion that it is desirable to do so having regard to the public interest-
here we find a phrase similar to that now used in this regulation-
in securing the prevention and settlement by conciliation and arbitration of industrial disputes-
in other words, it does refer to the type of case that we are talking about-
extending beyond the limits of any one State or in maintaining peace, order and good government in a Territory-

It then continues under (a) and (b) to state what it is able to do. In other words, the Minister is able to act, under the Building Industry Act of 1985, which was supported by the Liberal Party of Australia, the National Party of Australia and the Australian Democrats, to perform a function which is very close to being analogous to the situation we are talking about here. However, there is still one distinctive feature missing from that and I suggest that, of all those Acts that I have now rehearsed, the building one is probably the closest and yet it still misses out on one of the essential features in this matter. I refer to the fact that under this regulation a service is provided and it is partly paid for by the recipients of that service. In those other Acts there is no question of any payment for service. So I suggest that any of the items currently relied upon by the Government as being analogous to the situation with which we are dealing here really fall down. None of those propositions that I have rehearsed are analogous to this situation because they do not contain all of the elements that we are looking at, that is, an industrial dispute, a withdrawal of a service and that service being partly funded by the recipients of it.

It will be interesting to see whether the Government, in responding to this, has actually been able to find any more analogous items in legislation that has been passed. I suggest that the arguments presented by the Government by drawing attention to things that have happened elsewhere are not valid arguments.

I will turn now to what I think is a substantive proposition that really must be tackled. I refer to how we deal with the issues that the Minister raised in the statement that he made in the House of Representatives. I remind the Senate that we are not discussing the Mudginberri dispute; we are discussing whether there will be an extension of the Minister's power with regard to the provision of export inspectors. That refers not only to meat but to all inspectors. The issue is whether the Minister should have that type of discretion. I suggest that in the exercise of ministerial discretion, as we see it in many Acts, the Parliament has progressively sought to hedge around ministerial discretion in such a way as to have it reviewable. An initial development in that circumstance was to enable a review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Since this regulation is in general a ministerial direction to a department, in the normal course of events it would be reviewable by the AAT although I am not sure what the AAT would make of such a reference considering the fact that it has to have regard to the national interest. I am not sure that that reference could be handled in any successful way by the AAT and I am of the opinion, as is my party, that it would be an inappropriate body to deal with what essentially would become a highly charged political activity.

With regard to the various technical criteria-it is important to refer to them-I have a very interesting letter from the Livestock and Grain Producers Association of New South Wales which raises some excellent points. For example I will read paragraphs 7, 8 and 10 for the benefit of honourable senators who have not received this correspondence. Paragraph 7 states:
Disallowance of this Order will not require the Commonwealth to supply Export Inspection Services to recipients who do not satisfy technical criteria.

I am not at all sure that this is correct; in fact I think it is probably incorrect. But the point is that this reference to technical criteria is very important because of a number of matters that the Minister has raised. The industry could be forced, by the disallowance of this motion, to bear some considerable additional costs. This hinges on whatever legal interpretation one would want to give to the comments made by the judge with regard to the withdrawal of export inspection services in the Mudginberri dispute. I feel that in many ways it is a typical lawyer's reaction-one of extreme caution or putting the extreme case. Quite frankly, all that the judge said was that it should be provided; that there was no discretion. Of course, if it was impossible to provide meat inspectors, there was no obligation. The Department, in its advice to the Minister, and the Minister's proposition in the House of Representatives have suggested that the interpretation to be given to those comments made in the judgment is that there would be an additional cost-something around $2.5m if I remember correctly, half of which of course would have to be borne by the industry. For example, backup people would have to be provided in case people were sick or additional backup people in case cars broke down, and the like. Quite frankly, I think that is taking the whole situation to extremes--

TALK.START.PARA: —Twenty per cent more.

—Senator Boswell interjects that we have 20 per cent more. If he refers back to the Hansard when his Party was in government he would find that in fact the bloating of that export inspection service occurred mainly under the Fraser Government. In fact, I attacked that Government precisely over the way that it was operating in imposing additional costs-costs which that Government imposed for the first time on the people who received that service. Until the movement by the Liberal-National parties in this regard the service was free of charge. If Senator Boswell really wants to know, it was under the direction of a National Party Minister that for the first time half the charges were imposed on the industry and that cost recovery program was started, although it was not at the level that the current Government has put it. But I also remind the honourable senator that he knows very well from our discussions at the last election that he voted to increase the costs to the people who receive these services. He could in fact have made sure that they did not have the additional--
—I did not; I demand a retraction.
—Sorry, the honourable senator left the chamber; is that right? However, his Party voted for them. Paragraph 8 of the letter from the LGPA states:

SPEECH.PARA: To our knowledge there is no precedent for the Government to withhold a service essential to the conduct of business and only available from the Government unless either:
(i) the recipient does not satisfy technical criteria, or
(ii) the relevant legislation expressly states operational criteria which have not been satisfied.

This Order will be defeated at whatever stage debate takes place. I understand that the Government will seek an adjournment, which we will not oppose, on the ground that it wishes to have further discussions with the industry. That is something we have never opposed and do not intend to. As I understand it, the industry has requested those discussions, so I am certainly not going to stand in the way of their taking place. I have already indicated to the Senate that the Australian Democrats will oppose this Order at whatever time the vote is taken. It does not really make any difference to us whether it is now or later.

I would like to make a number of suggestions to the Government regarding this matter. Firstly, the technical criteria for the withdrawal of any service ought to be provided in regulations. In other words, the type of unfettered discretion provided under Order 111A is not allowed. There are technical reasons why services may have to be withdrawn, and I think these can be spelled out. They are known to everybody who knows anything about this industry. In the past under a variety of circumstances some services have been withdrawn and there has been no dispute about that because of technical matters.

However, I believe that when one comes to the crux of this matter, at some stage or another-as I have already said, there are already a number of instances-Ministers, under legislation introduced into this chamber by both Labor and Liberal governments, have been given discretion by this place to withdraw services in the national interest. How will we define what is in the national interest? I suggest that one way of overcoming this type of problem is to make that judgment reviewable; in other words, make that a matter of parliamentary scrutiny. Undoubtedly, that could not be done by regulation. I refer the Senate to the Willocks v Anderson High Court of Australia case of 1970, which was referred to the High Court, so the learned judges were very interested in it. That case stated that it was not possible to confer, by regulation, those types of powers. Therefore, I do not believe that it is possible for the Government to confer by regulation reviewable powers on the Parliament; it would have to be done by amendments to the legislation.

I refer to some recent cases where this has occurred. Senator Peter Baume, the shadow Minister, would remember them. After some extended debate in this chamber the Government agreed to place into the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Act 1984 the ability for this chamber to review ministerial decisions. I believe that was a very interesting advance and is an advance which could well be followed up. In other words, I am suggesting that there may need to be a two-pronged approach to deal with any technical problems that may arise. The Government felt that previously it had had the power to withdraw services: Indeed it had withdrawn services in the past. The Minister has said that it was always assumed that this situation could occur and it was only when a court said that the Government did not have that power that it was not able to do so. So there are instances, based on technical reasons, when services have been withdrawn. It may be necessary for us to look-undoubtedly, we will-at any regulations that the Government may wish to bring in with regard to the technical withdrawal of services either in this or any other area.

I suggest that, if the Government wishes to go further than that, the current position of the Australian Democrats is that that matter ought to be reviewable by the Parliament. Hence we would ask that any action taken in terms of that type of ministerial discretion based on the public interest be done by way of amendment to the Act and certainly not by way of regulation. There are, of course, a very large number of instances where that has occurred to date. Paragraph 10 of the letter to which I referred earlier states:
There has been inadequate consultation with interested parties on the issues contained in the Regulation.

I agree with that. Yesterday the Government expressed the view to me that it would wish to have those discussions. That is reasonable and it should have occurred earlier, as the various industry bodies, such as the LGPA have pointed out.

The irony of the situation is that if this order had been brought in prior to the Mudginberri dispute we certainly would not be having this debate. The matter has been raised as a result of that debate. The reason I make that point is this: We are talking about not only a technical matter but also a very political matter. Because it has that very hard political edge I believe that the final decision ought to be made by this chamber, not by the Minister in terms of directions to his Department or anywhere else. The Government is moving to a position where these types of hard political points have to be made in that way and the Parliament should take back much of the power it has delegated willy-nilly in the past. I support the proposition that I have been enunciating and that we can see in more recent legislation.

In summary, I simply again put on the record that the Australian Democrats will be voting to support, at whatever vote is taken, the disallowance motion moved by the Opposition parties. As the Opposition parties well know I had drafted a disallowance motion which I had intended to move on the same day but they beat me to it by getting the call before me. There is unanimity that this Order is not acceptable. What will take its place will have to be a matter of discussion between the Government and the industry. The Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin, has indicated that he is now proceeding to undertake those types of discussions. The Government has requested that the matter be adjourned in order to allow it to discuss this matter with industry. I think that is perfectly acceptable. We are aware that a time limit has been set by Standing Orders and if that time is exceeded this Order is automatically disallowed if debate is not resumed. I am quite happy to accept the bona fides of the Government to have a discussion with the industry on this matter. Hopefully, when the Government does so the result will not be the type of outlandish proposition which we have before us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak very briefly in this debate. Other speakers will canvass the issue; indeed they have already. Senator Macklin has expressed very clearly the view of the Australian Democrats. I confirm that at a later stage of the debate-I understand that such later stage has been agreed to-the Government will move that this matter be adjourned in order that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) may have discussions with the industry, discussions which may well be consistent with some of the views that have already been expressed.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer briefly to the history of the matter. Amendments to the Prescribed Goods (General) Orders arise following a decision of the Full Bench of the Federal Court of Australia following legal action by the Mudginberri abattoir against the Commonwealth. Honourable senators will recall that when the Mudginberri dispute arose the Commonwealth endeavoured to provide inspection staff for the abattoir and on four occasions staff were directed to report for duty. They refused, on direction from their union, the Meat Inspectors Association, on the grounds that the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union picket had been endorsed. The Mudginberri abattoir subsequently took action under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act seeking a review of the Department's decision not to use other avenues to supply staff. On 14 August last year, Mr Justice Neaves dismissed Mudginberri's application. An appeal was than made to the Full Bench of the Federal Court and that decision was reversed. In its judgment the Full Bench said:
there is no such discretion (in the Orders) and there is a duty to provide inspectors . . .
It also said:
. . . the duty does not extend to doing what is impossible.

The Court did not define what it meant by `impossible'. Although `impossible' is not defined, it is known to exclude the welfare of the meat industry and the national interest. However, the Court said, without expressing a view one way or another:
that for practical reasons (it may) be desirable that the duty be . . . qualified; if so it would seem to be a simple matter for the Minister to make an appropriate order.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is easy for judges to say.
—Of course, judges who do not have the benefit of the quality of the debate in the Senate.
—They are only trying equitably to carry out the law for everyone.
—Stop rabbiting, Senator.
—Something which you keep ignoring.

—I cannot keep ignoring Senator Walters, and I do not intend to. If she interjects again I will not ignore her. The recent decision of the Federal Court showed that, unless there are amendments to the Orders, no discretion exists in legislation and there is a duty to provide inspectors when requested. The Government believes that, on the basis of this decision, the Export Inspection Service cannot operate in a cost-efficient manner, nor can safety, welfare or national interest issues be considered when providing inspectors. The supply of inspection services requires a discretion because of the many operational variables involved. The Department will have to do a number of things to give effect to that stated position.

SPEECH.PARA: In making the amendments the Government of course recognises that discretionary powers exist in other Commonwealth legislation where services are provided by government authorities. The Federal Court said, without expressing a view one way or the other:
that for practical reasons (it may) be desirable that the duty be . . . qualified; if so it would seem to be a . . . matter for the Minister to make an appropriate order.
Decisions on management efficiency considerations, safety and staff will be subject to review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

I gather that the debate will rage for the statutory time of two hours but I just want to indicate that it is the Government's intention to pursue, as expeditiously as possible-there is certain discipline in all that, as Senator Macklin has pointed out-discussions with the industry about this matter. Those discussions are highly desirable in the interests of the industry as a whole. For that reason at the appropriate time we will be seeking an adjournment, cognisant as we are of the disallowance provisions in the Senate Standing Orders and the desirability of those discussions being expedited as much as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is discussing cognately two motions to disallow certain orders which have been made in relation to the provision of meat inspectors. It is quite clear from what has taken place already in the debate that the numbers in the Senate are such that, if it came to a vote, the orders would be disallowed. So they should be because these orders have revealed what the Australian Labor Party is about. Labor, with these orders, has revealed clearly where it stands and where it has stood in relation to its support for the corporate state, for the monopoly power of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, which was heavily involved in the Mudginberri dispute, and for unions, right or wrong-and they were wrong in the Mudginberri dispute. These orders have revealed clearly that the Labor Party has very little interest in the rights of the individual, such as the individuals at Mudginberri, or the rights of individual unionists, such as the unionists at Mudginberri, who suffered from the events that occurred. The Labor Party has very little interest in anyone wanting to do better for himself, such as Mr Jay Pendarvis, and it had very little interest in any enterprise wanting to do better for Australia or for itself, as the Mudginberri abattoir wanted to do.

SPEECH.PARA: These orders seek to allow the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) to weasel out of doing his duty to provide meat inspectors on request. Really they seek to allow the Labor Government to avoid doing its duty. They seek to allow the Minister to choose, if he wishes, to avoid an obligation clearly put to him by the Full Bench of the Federal Court of Australia on 16 December last year. In this way the orders seek to enable the interests of organised labour to be put ahead of the interests of individual unionists and it all arises from the dispute at the Mudginberri abattoir last year, to which other senators have referred. This was a dispute about individual unionists who made an agreement that gave them more money, that gave them something they wanted, that increased the productivity and efficiency of the abattoir and that improved the viability of the business on which they were dependent.

What was the response of organised labour to the agreement made by the unionists with their employer? Was it to welcome the better pay? Of course it was not. Was it to welcome the agreement reached between employee and employer? Of course it was not. Was it to welcome the improved viability of the business? Of course not. Was it to welcome the improved productivity and efficiency which would flow? Of course it was not.

The response by organised labour to the agreement reached at Mudginberri was that organised labour did everything in its power to destroy the initiative and to force the employees and the employer alike to toe the standard union line even though it was inappropriate and even though it would mean worse conditions and possibly threaten the viability of the business.
