The fact that the standard line was not appropriate to Mudginberri and to the situation at Mudginberri mattered not at all to the union movement, which demanded a standard, uniform, national, expensive, feather-bedded, outmoded, inefficient and mindless approach and tried to impose that upon the Mudginberri abattoir operators. What it had not counted on was that neither the employer nor the employees were willing to be told what they were to do. They were determined to pursue what common sense dictated. They were determined to pursue the more productive, more efficient and better paid course in defiance of the union and for their own best interests and the best interests of Australia.

What was the response of organised labour to this show of independent judgment? It certainly was not to examine the proposal on the merits or to find out why the Mudginberri abattoir had found a better and more efficient way of operating. It was not to go to Mudginberri and say: `What can you teach us about the operation of abattoirs in other parts of Australia?'. It was not to see how it could extend the Mudginberri model for the benefit of abattoir operations and for the benefit of Australia generally. The response was to declare war upon Mudginberri, to declare war upon the operator, to declare war upon the abattoir and to declare war upon the employees. The business was made the subject of a picket line, which the employees proceeded to cross because they knew they were right and they were determined to continue and they were determined to succeed. The employees, of course, were expelled from their union for daring to make local decisions about matters which affected them locally.

The Labor Government, which is supposed to be the champion of organised labour, did its best to prevent the emergence and success of an arrangement which increased efficiency, production and wages, enhanced the business and promised increased and continuing employment. That is pretty typical of the approach of the Labor Government. The Government stood by and did as little as it could to help the employers and the employees. It did as little as it could to stop the harassment of people seeking to earn their livelihood. It did as little as it could to stop the bully-boy actions of those on the picket lines with their threats of physical violence. Further, the Labor Government did not supply, as it was required to do, the meat inspectors to examine the carcasses of slaughtered beasts. It is required to provide these inspectors on request, and indeed, as has been pointed out already in this debate, the producers have paid half the costs associated with the provision of this inspection service. The Labor Government contrived affairs in such a way that the meat inspectors would have to cross the picket line, whereas the previous arrangements would not have required them so to do. Part of the response of the Labor Government was to increase the confrontation and to do as little as it could to relieve or fix the situation.

When the matter was finally taken to court, it determined that the Labor Government had failed to provide inspectors, which it was duly bound to do. The court found that it was required to carry out its side of the process by which one of our great export industries operates. The court decision meant that, at a time of economic hardship for Australia, the Labor Government had not done all it could to keep an export industry operating and export dollars rolling in, and that in future under the existing rules it would have to do so. By its inaction the Hawke Labor Government was promoting job loss, economic recession, the supremacy of union power and the feeling of hopelessness which many Australians have about winning against union diktat.

Labor did not count on the determination of all the people involved. It did not count on the determination of Jay Pendarvis to carry through and to win. It did not count on the determination of friends who provided carry on cash to make sure that he could survive. Most of all, it did not count on the determination of the workers at the abattoir, now expelled from their union, who operated under threat to keep their abattoir working and to win. Of course win they did-they succeeded. The Labor Party now wants to change the rules so that when the next confrontation comes they will be able to weasel out of their duty again. The people at Mudginberri have provided an example of how to make arrangements that give Australia a chance to succeed and to make winners out of everyone connected with the process. We think that this is a sensible approach to industrial relations and a sensible example of what can be achieved.

What has been Labor's next response? Has it been to seek to abide by the decision of the court? Not on your life. Has it been to accept that its duty is now to provide the meat inspectors, an essential part of the chain of meat export? Of course it has not. What Labor has done is to bring in new orders to provide the Government with a mechanism to allow it to slip out of its duty, if the Government so wishes. The Government brought in some new regulations to allow it to avoid the intent of the court and to allow socialist Ministers to do their part to ensure that, in circumstances such as those at Mudginberri, it is the union movement that will win and the business community and the employees who will go to the wall. The Government seeks to ensure that for individual employees the message is that obedience to the Australian Council of Trade Unions is what will count and that the most efficient, most productive and most lucrative way of earning a living has to be put to one side if that does not fit in with union demands.

What Labor seeks to do through these orders is anti-Australian, anti-employment, anti-worker, anti-productivity and anti-common sense. It is pretty typical of what we see going on in Australia. It is typical Labor corporate strategy where the state counts for more than the individual. We do not believe in the corporatist state. We do not believe in the whole Labor approach. We do not believe in what these orders may achieve. The orders seek to preserve and to entrench the possibility of a less efficient and less productive system. It is an approach which the employees at Mudginberri have already rejected. It seeks to allow the Commonwealth to weasel out of a duty which it has under the law and which has been confirmed as recently as the last four months by the Full Bench of the Federal Court. If we do not determine this matter quickly, it could drag on for another two months. During that time these new orders would continue to apply.

I accept Senator Macklin's bona fides. He said that if it comes to a vote we know how he will vote. Indeed, he was to move the same motion of disallowance. But I would remind him that, if the Government does not proceed down the path which Senator Macklin suggested to the Senate that the Government might follow, it may be May or June before we can determine this matter within the 13 sitting days that remain. We believe that these orders must be disallowed quickly and we will seek so to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak on these disallowance motions as Chairman of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee and on behalf of the Committee. At a special meeting yesterday the Committee considered the Prescribed Goods (General) Orders as Amended (Amendment) along with an urgent legal report from its legal adviser, Professor Douglas Whalan, of the Australian National University. The Committee considers delegated legislation from the point of view of its principles. The Committee does not involve itself in considering the merits of the policy behind delegated instruments. That is not its role. After considering the Orders generally and its legal adviser's report in particular, the Committee concluded that it could not object to the Orders under its principles. The Committee did not consider that any of its principles were infringed. The policy behind the Orders is, of course, beyond the scope of the Committee's concerns. It was the wish of the Committee that I make this statement on its behalf.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating two motions of disallowance to the Prescribed Goods (General) Orders moved by Senator Collard on behalf of the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney. The motion concerning Order 111A seeks to disallow a regulation put forward by the Government which seeks to overcome a court decision forcing the Government to supply meat inspectors of export meat. Let us look at the history of the need for this regulation and at the Mudginberri dispute. Simply put, the owner of the Mudginberri abattoir, Mr Pendarvis, came to an agreement with his employees which not only increased the efficiency of the abattoir and the ability of the abattoir to gain overseas markets by being more competitive, but also gave the employees better pay and conditions. Therefore, both employees and employer were happy. What is wrong with that? One may well ask that question. Why on earth would the unions object to their employees being better off, having better conditions, with Australia generally having more money and being able to have overseas markets which are of such great benefit to Australia?

SPEECH.PARA: The unions decided in their usual way that, unless they had reached the agreement and had fought for these conditions, it was just not on for those conditions to be taken. The unions did not want their members coming up with an agreement which the employees preferred on their own, without the involvement of the unions. The unions told the employees that they could not abide by that agreement made with Mr Pendarvis. The employees refused to take any notice of the union, so the union set up a picket line. The employees continued to work and Mr Pendarvis continued to employ them. But the picket line was there, and Mr Pendarvis, to fulfil his contract overseas, had to have his meat inspected. However, the meat inspectors refused to cross the picket line. They were the only ones; the employees kept on going through and they continued to be employed, but the meat inspectors refused to cross that picket line; so the abattoir lost its overseas markets.

Who employs the inspectors? We know that the Government employs the inspectors. Why did not the Government insist that its inspectors cross that picket line and carry out the service that the Government must supply, which, indeed, is being paid for by every abattoir and by every taxpayer? Why did the Government refuse to instruct its employees to cross that picket line and get on with their job? The Government decided that it could not cross the Australian Council of Trade Unions or that union and, in its usual fashion, it bowed to the pressure of the ACTU. We had headlines such as `The ACTU says no to Willis' and `Willis pleads for peace on the abattoirs'. We had the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) pleading with the ACTU to allow the inspectors to cross the picket line and not to support the meat workers union. The ACTU said to Mr Willis `Get back into line. We will have nothing to do with that'-and, indeed, that is exactly what Mr Willis and the Labor Party did; they got back into line. They did not instruct the Government's employees to go ahead and carry out their job, for which they were being paid.

The Full Bench of the Federal Court of Australia brought down an order saying that the Government should have instructed its inspectors to do what they were paid to do and should not have allowed them to sit back and allow Mr Pendarvis and his men to lose markets overseas.

TALK.START.PARA: —But they did not lose markets. They made money on it. Get your facts straight.

—We are told that they did not lose markets. That is an absolutely ludicrous suggestion. They lost $7m. The situation is such that the ACTU has supported a union that insists on bringing this country to its knees by destroying our overseas markets. So we have the situation now in which the Federal Court has instructed the Government to send its inspectors in to carry out their duties. What is the Government's reaction to the Federal Court's direction to it? The Government has succumbed. It has had another chat to the ACTU, which has said: `You can do that. Who do you think you are? You are the Government. You make sure you bring down a regulation that gives the Minister discretion on whether he instructs those meat inspectors, or gives the Secretary to the Department the discretion on whether he instructs the inspectors'. The ACTU has also said to the Government: `Don't you take any notice of the Full Bench. You do what we instruct you to do. You bring in this regulation and the Parliament must pass it'.

SPEECH.PARA: We have had an indication in this place however that the Parliament, indeed, will not pass it; that it will move, as Senator Chaney has done, for a disallowance of that Order. That means that if that motion is passed today, the Government must abide by the decision of the Federal Court. But we have a tricky situation in that the disallowance must be passed within a certain period. The Government has seen that it is to be defeated on this issue and has talked the Australian Democrats into supporting the Government to put off debate for a while, until as it says, it has had further consultations. If any member of the Government can tell me why the Government did not have consultations prior to bringing in the Order, I would be very happy. The Government should have had all those consultations before it brought in the Order. It should not bring in the Order and then say to the Democrats: `We do not want to be defeated on that today; we want to consult. Will you give us time to consult? Will you put it off?' That is what the Government is trying to do. It is trying to hoodwink the Democrats-who are not even present in the chamber, which is a pity-into putting off the motion for disallowance until a later date. It must come up before the 13 days, and I just finish up by saying to the Democrats: Do not be hoodwinked; let us have a vote on it today. The Government certainly has no excuse for not having consulted with the various people concerned beforehand. It should have done it then. There is no excuse for the Government to put it off and pretend that it needs more time to consult.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —If ever there was an indication that this Government is in the power of the unions, it is demonstrated today very clearly. I do not say that it is even a coalition, because the word `coalition' implies mutual respect. But that is not so in this case. It is quite clear to the whole of Australia that it is not a coalition of mutual respect; it is a domination by the Australian Council of Trade Unions of the Australian Labor Party. What do we have before us here in this motion for disallowance? The Government has put into a Hansard of 300 pages three lines and it hopes that it can move the Order through the Parliament so that the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin, will not have to obey the laws of this land. Already the matter has been before the Parliament and has been ruled on by the highest court of this land, but the Labor Party will not abide by the decision of the highest court of this land because it is not allowed to do so by its masters, the ACTU.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Button, with all the eloquence that he commands, gave a very poor performance, a half-hearted performance, because even he knows that one cannot defend the indefensible. He went over this matter and he gave an appalling defence. I would not want Senator Button defending me unless he could lift his game from this performance. Senator Cooney, the Labor Party's kamikaze pilot, went into bat for about three words, so even he could not defend this action.

The point of the matter is that we have seen the disgraceful behaviour of the Minister for Primary Industry in this Mudginberri dispute. Last year in the Northern Territory the unionists, the management and the workers got together and hammered out an agreement that was beneficial to all concerned. The workers would lift their wages from say, $400 or $450-I think that that is about the figure-to around $1,000 a week. The management would reduce its costs on killing a beast, on slaughter charges, from around $140 to $40. That is the sort of productivity increase that this Government should be encouraging. It should be going out of its way to say: `Let us do it. Let us lift the export income of this nation. Let us lift the productivity of this nation'. But what do we see? We see a shocking display of cowardice when Mr Kerin would not order the meat inspectors across the picket line. He was ordered to do so by the Federal Court of Australia; so he did.

But what happened only three weeks ago, which I believe is behind the motion for disallowance before the chamber? Three weeks ago in Biloela there was another strike, with $150,000 worth of meat locked up in an abattoir with no inspectors. Let us look at the reason why the strike occurred. A boning room designed for 24 people had 22 people working in it. The union said that there was enough room for only 21 people. It said: `All out'. The unionists, the workers, went out. The meat inspectors were called to inspect the $150,000 worth of meat, but they would not go through the picket line because television cameras were there. They were coy, or perhaps someone shouted something at them. They were sent by taxi from Biloela to the abattoir but they were not prepared to go through the picket line.

Mr Kerin has put down the reasons why he is not prepared to send people across picket lines. The first reason is the availability of authorised officers for performing services at the place and time described in the application. Senate Estimates committees have found-it is quite well known-that there are more meat inspectors than there are jobs to go around. It is considered that there are 20 per cent more meat inspectors than there are jobs for them. We even found that now, to fill in time and keep them busy, they have to go to classes for 10 hours a week to help them read the meat inspection levies manual. They are underemployed.

I put it to the Senate very clearly that this Government is not enforcing the law of this land. The Government goes through the charade of bringing down a Bill of Rights. What is the good of a Bill of Rights when the Government will not even stand up for the law as it has been determined by the High Court of Australia and court actions in Australia? It is an absolute facade to bring down that sort of Bill. If the Government is not going to enforce the law of the land, why does it want a Bill of Rights? All I can say about this motion for disallowance is that it should be carried today.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a good point.

—I am glad that Senator Button acknowledges that it is a good point. What Senator Button and his Government should be doing-he is very much aware of it-but what the Government is not doing is trying to get this country to produce more, to raise its productivity, to raise wages so that everyone has more money to spend and to raise our level of exports so that we can meet our overseas financial commitments. But the Government is not prepared to do that. It is not prepared to stand up to the unions or to send in meat inspectors to inspect the export products of this nation, and it should be condemned for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion for disallowance moved this morning by Senator Collard. If the Senate does not support this motion-we have it from the Australian Democrats that they will support it, which is good, although I would have liked it to be today-once again it will be a victory for the union movement. The Government will be seen as not caring for the meat industry and its employees-earners of export income-but rather, as giving support once again to the union movement of Australia, as it had done in the case of the superannuation 3 per cent productivity issue. I consider that the proposed Government amendment is harmful to the meat processing industry. It removes from the Minister for Primary Industry the obligation to provide Commonwealth export meat inspection services at abattoirs. It certainly is a bad industrial precedent for other areas of government to amend ministerial orders to give the Government and the Minister the discretion to refuse to provide meat inspectors when requested. We should remember that, without meat inspection by authorised meat inspectors, there can be no meat exports. It is the Government's duty to provide inspectors.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, this Government does what the unions tell it to do. That is probably the root cause of the problem that exists today. I have received some information to the effect that the community and the hard pressed rural industries certainly cannot accept a government and a minister who are not prepared to stand up to union standover tactics that have been and are being waged by the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union. The Minister, in refusing to ensure that Commonwealth meat inspectors crossed the picket line at Mudginberri and, in the most recent case, at Biloela in Queensland, demonstrated that the Government was not prepared to stand up to the standover tactics of the union. The Government is concerned that under the existing provisions it would have to order the inspectors to cross the picket lines. I point out that trade union interference in Australian meat exports has cost more than $7m in the six-month period to September 1985, including lost export sales from Mudginberri, which amounted to about $3m.

The workers at Mudginberri showed that employers and employees can achieve mutual benefit without union involvement. Basically, the Mudginberri dispute was a dispute between the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union and the workers whom it had kicked out of the union because they were not prepared to accept the tally system. The union, for its part, was not prepared to accept an agreement that was reached between the employers and employees and ratified by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. I congratulate Jay Pendarvis on the job that he did. I had the opportunity to meet him on one occasion in Brisbane and heard from him the problems he had been experiencing at Mudginberri.

What I fail to understand is why the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) did not take action under sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act against the meat inspectors who refused to cross the illegal picket line. The unions are fighting the right of employees to negotiate an agreement under which they can receive up to $1,000 a week, as against the $450 to $500 a week maximum they could have earned under the tally system-the very system that the union has been trying to force upon the 25 workers. I find it hard to believe that any union could be so silly.

Under this Labor Government the cost of inspections to industry has more than doubled, from $23.9m in 1982-83 to $53m this year. This is a great burden on industries which are struggling to maintain their competitive basis on world markets. Cost pressures on the agricultural export industries are particularly severe. In recent years these industries have turned in an unusually sluggish export performance. Over the past five years to 1983-84, total Australian export income rose by 4.5 per cent. Over the same period rural exports, accounting for 40 per cent or more of the total income, fell into decline. The Bureau of Agricultural Economics has estimated that rural export income will decline even further in real terms this financial year. That is a problem for a vast area of Australia. People who are involved in rural industries know just how hard they are being hit and have been hit in the past. At present much of Australia faces a drought, which will make things even harder.

It is the rural industries which hold the key to winding back Australia's foreign debt, which has spiralled from about $40 billion to around $70 billion in less than two years. One would think that the Government would be doing everything it could to help rural industries, such as the one at Mudginberri, instead of causing losses of millions of dollars in this one industry alone. I certainly support the motion of disallowance which has been moved today by Senator Collard and on which I understand debate is going to be adjourned. I point out that there is a need for a decision and I would like to think that the question could have been put to a vote today. We hope that the Government will bring it on in time for a vote to be taken so that this motion of disallowance can be carried.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support most vigorously the motion moved by Senator Collard to disallow the export control orders. The actions of the Federal Government throughout the entire Mudginberri dispute, with which these export control orders are linked, are an absolute disgrace. I find it ironic that at the same time as this chamber is debating a Bill of Rights for Australia, which the Federal Government says we must have, we have a situation where the rights of employees and employers in an export industry have been threatened, and we have a government not only not prepared to do anything to protect the rights of those people in that industry, but also, in fact, prepared to allow those people to remain defenceless. It allows rights to be taken away which in another piece of legislation it is purporting to protect. What hypocrisy!

SPEECH.PARA: Is this the same Federal Government which only a few short weeks ago professed such deep concern for the plight of the rural sector that it started to prepare an aid package? Does the Federal Government honestly believe that on the one hand it can claim genuine interest in the rural industry while on the other hand it washes its hands of any responsibility for that industry? This legislation simply proves what the Opposition has long suspected; it proves that the trade union movement runs this Government and this country. What an appalling state of affairs that is.

We now have a Federal Government and a Federal Minister for Primary Industry passing control of a vital export industry to unions such as the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union. What type of upstanding citizens are the members of this union? Let me quote from the Australian Law Reports summary of the AMIEU v. Mudginberri:

The President of the Union made remarks in the presence of Mr Pendarvis to the effect that he and others would be out of business by the following year. When asked what he meant by that, [the President] said: `You bastards have had it your own way in the past but we are going to close you down'.

I believe that they are common thugs. Never mind the legality of the situation and never mind the rights or otherwise of the meatworks owners or their employees. The summary goes on to report that the AMIEU organiser threatened the use of physical violence. This is how justice and democracy in this country work. These are the types of people to whom the Federal Government has handed over the reins of this country. This is not the first industry that has been threatened by union bullying and thuggery, but it is about time the Federal Government took a stand.

It is not the unions of this country that have been elected to govern, for better or for worse-we are certainly getting more of the latter than the former-it is the Federal Labor Party. So when, may I ask, will the Federal Government start governing? How can this Government possibly argue about the rights of individuals and how can it claim sympathy for the rural sector when it allows control of this country to fall into the hands of irresponsible bullies?

The trade union movement in this country appears hellbent on crippling every export industry we have. What is the strength of this Australian Council of Trade Unions tail that it can so effectively and vigorously wag the Government dog, that it can make the Federal Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) so impotent and so unwilling to carry out his duties and make it so powerful and arrogant that it considers itself above and beyond the powers and decisions of the High Court of Australia?

The Federal Government, and in particular the Minister for Primary Industry, have a very clear role to play in providing an essential export inspection service. Export inspection services in this country are available only from a Government monopoly. They are essential in the daily operations of businesses engaged in the production or processing of foodstuffs for export. Why have this service, and indeed why have a Federal Government, if it is the unions that determine whether these services are provided or not?

Australia at present is running itself into bankruptcy. We have an appalling imbalance in trade. Our exports in the past month have fallen by some 19 per cent. Our trade performance must improve and it is the rural export industries that can lead the recovery. But are those rural industries to survive only at the whim of the trade union movement and can they survive with a weak Primary Industry Minister who abdicates his responsibilities so easily? What will become of our reputation as a reliable supplier? Is it to be tarnished still further?

Industries involved in export have a right to expect support from the Federal Government, but has that support been forthcoming? I would say no. What is the Federal Government doing to secure and protect our overseas markets, to strengthen our reliability? Basically the Federal Government is saying that it will do as much or as little as the trade union movement allows it to do.

It is not just the Federal Opposition that is so critical of the Government's actions. The Livestock and Grain Producers Association of New South Wales represents over 25,000 export oriented rural producers involved in producing meat grains, eggs, fruit and vegetables, much of which is exported. The LGPA considers the regulations an improper response to judgments of the Federal Court and regards them as invalid. It considers them as establishing political bias in government decisions. The Federal Constitution is quite clear on export powers, yet we have the Federal Primary Industry Minister ignoring that and choosing instead to give himself a discretion, rather than an obligation, to uphold his constitutional and legislative responsibilities. If the Federal Government buckles under to this pressure, when and where will it end?

The Government's role in this is very clear. It has a moral and legal responsibility to provide essential services. Further, it must be able to do this totally independent of the control of the ACTU. Additionally, workers must have the right and the freedom to negotiate conditions of employment without the control of unions. Industry also must be allowed to operate free of government and union intervention and domination. The trade union movement in this country must be stopped from crippling the nation. The Federal Government has the legal power to do that. It also has a moral responsibility to act. It is about time it accepted that responsibility and got on with the job.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly in support of the motion of disallowance moved by Senator Collard for Senator Chaney and supported by other Opposition senators. The motion seeks to disallow an order made under the Export Control Act 1982. At present the export control orders which provide for the prohibition of the export of meat unless certain steps are taken, including inspections by meat inspectors, have been held by the Federal Court of Australia to imply that the Commonwealth is bound to provide meat inspectors. This was determined in the recent ruling of the Federal Court in the Mudginberri case. This ruling means that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) and the Department of Primary Industry have been held to have been bound to provide meat inspectors to Mudginberri during the period of last year's pickets.

SPEECH.PARA: The amended orders which we are now debating and which the Opposition seeks to disallow provide that the Secretary may, in determining whether to direct the services of the authorised officers available have regard to, firstly, the availability of authorised officers and, secondly, such other considerations consistent with good management practices as he thinks fit, including the welfare and safety of authorised officers and the general interest of agricultural and fisheries export industries. This amendment would lead to the situation where if a Mudginberri picket occurs again the Federal Minister and his Department would be able to refuse the supply of meat inspectors with impunity. It has been suggested and mooted that there are going to be pickets again this year to kill off Jay and Joy Pendarvis. The motives of the Federal Labor Government in proceeding with these amendments are crystal clear.

The Minister, Mr Kerin, failed to send in meat inspectors during the dispute last year when those inspectors should have been provided. The Federal Minister for Primary Industry, like so many of his colleagues-the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Trade, John Dawkins-was not prepared to stand up to the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union. The Federal Government could not afford to put a union off side. Even though it was clear that the Minister has a legal and moral duty to provide the inspectors, he failed to do so. The result was the loss of buffalo meat sales worth millions of dollars and severe damage to the reputation of the Mudginberri abattoir through which Jay and Joy Pendarvis had developed very lucrative markets overseas over a number of years.

The Mudginberri operation was a major employer in the area and involved considerable participation from Aboriginal people. It provided its employees with a better return for their work than did other abattoirs in the area. Indeed, a number of the other abattoirs have closed down. They simply were not economic. Jay Pendarvis, on the other hand, had managed to build up a very viable business. This was all jeopardised by the Minister-the business, the employment of the workers, the standing of Australia in overseas markets and the money which would have come into Australia with the sale of the buffalo meat. The Minister, presumably, has been embarrassed by the result of his inaction-if that is possible. I certainly hope that he has been embarrassed. Any Minister in a government who ignores his obligations, and as a consequence diminishes the standing of Australia in overseas markets for our primary produce and allows contracts worth millions of dollars to be cancelled, should be embarrassed. In fact, he should be sacked. He should be ashamed and he should, if he has any sense of obligation, make sure as far as possible that any such situation does not arise again. As I have said before, I think that there should be another Minister for Primary Industry.

Unfortunately, this Minister has refused to acknowledge his obligations as set out by the Federal Court of Australia. He wishes to avoid his responsibilities and therefore seeks to enact amendments to legitimise the spinelessness of the Federal Labor Government's effort. The Federal Government which goes on at length about the accord and consensus and how they have contributed to industrial harmony, simply lacks the backbone to stand up to the unions, particularly in the Mudginberri case with Joy and Jay Pendarvis. The accord and consensus are all very well as long as the unions can get what they want, but it is quite clear that when the umpire decides against them, as the court did in the Mudginberri case, the unions are prepared to pull strings in Canberra to get their way. We see the Federal Minister for Primary Industry dancing to their tune.

As I said before, it is quite likely that the AMIEU intends to impose a picket at Mudginberri this killing season. With the benefit of these amendments, the Minister would be free of any legal obligation to send in meat inspectors. As the Minister would be free of any legal obligation he would allow the unions to come in once again and kill off Jay and Joy Pendarvis at Mudginberri. If ever there was a Pontius Pilate act, here it is. It is quite clear that the Mudginberri dispute last year was well organised, so well organised that the meat inspectors who had been living on the lease at Mudginberri for months before the dispute moved off the lease well before the AMIEU picket was set up so that they would have to cross a picket line to do their job. We saw what happened then. Clearly, there was a long term plan which not only involved the AMIEU but also had the collaboration of meat inspectors, who did not want to break the picket line-if we can call the motley camp a picket line. Now the Minister is seeking to make it easier for the meat inspectors and himself to avoid their duties if the situation arises again. I believe that it is likely that it will-given the determination of the AMIEU in bringing this industry to a close and, at the same time, bringing unemployment to all those meat workers who very earnestly wish to continue with their jobs at Mudginberri.

That a Minister in a government which is supposed to be working to get the Australian economy moving and improving would take this step which will leave the union free to destroy financially the Mudginberri abattoir is an indication of lack of true commitment to small business enterprises. When it comes to the crunch, the Labor Government is not prepared to buck the unions, no matter how unreasonable are their claims or how damaging their actions. If the Federal Government wishes to retain any semblance of responsibility it would be well advised to withdraw these amendments. Apparently the Minister is not interested in responsibility so it is left to the Opposition to disallow these amendments.

I wholeheartedly support the disallowance motions and urge honourable senators to support them. Once again, we have a situation in which everyone expected that these motions would be finalised today, that a vote would be taken. I understood that the Democrats supported the Opposition in bringing this about. We will now see a postponement of this debate, which means that the decision to assist Mudginberri will be evaded. Frankly, I cannot see why these motions should not be put to the Senate today. I see no reason why any credence should be given to the excuse that there should be a postponement so that the matter can be referred to industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister should supply inspectors under the present law.

—I notice what Senator Sheil says. What a ridiculous situation: The industry wants a result, yet the Minister says that he must refer the matter to the industry. This is a sham and a shame. Once again, I ask-I ask the Democrats too-that, rather than carrying on with this farce of an adjournment of this debate, we put the question to the Senate now and get this matter over once and for all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too speak today in the strongest possible support of Senator Collard's motions to disallow the Government's proposed amendments to the export control orders and regulations. Those amendments would allow the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) totally to abrogate his ministerial responsibilities, to lie down to the whims of the trade union movement. In the Minister's speech in the other place on 13 March defending the proposed amendments under discussion today, he stressed that they were his Government's response to what he described as industrial reality. At the end of the day, industrial reality had to be accepted, according to the Minister. In so highlighting the Government's reason for introducing these amendments, the Minister has indicated his Government's major concern, that is, keeping the unions at bay so they will not cause problems for the Hawke Government.

SPEECH.PARA: In deciding whether essential meat inspection services or, for that matter, any inspection services relating to the agricultural and fisheries industries embraced by the Export Control Act will be provided, the Minister is abrogating his responsibilities. These amendments are a flagrant and discriminatory use of Executive power. The unions are to be left to decide the fate of our export industries. That fate is to be decided at the Government's behest. These amendments provide the Minister with a way of ignoring his duties and obligations and providing what is essential to the shipment of our rural produce, namely an inspection service. They provide him with a way out of providing the essential service of inspection which is vital to export trade.

Industrial reality can always dictate, above all other considerations, whether goods can leave our ports for their final destination. At least that is the attitude of this Hawke Government. The Minister pays scant attention to whether the abattoir or the plant goes bankrupt, or whether employees lose jobs or the costs of our exports go on rising. If these amendments are not disallowed, the Minister can, with impunity, sweep under the carpet his responsibility for perishables rotting for want of certificates. Industrial reality, in the Hawke Government's eyes, demands that unions control our exports. They shall decide the fate of the millions of Australians who rely on our export industries.

At a time when this country is facing the worst balance of trade figures on record, when our rural producers are facing decline and ruin in some cases, one would have thought that the Government would be doing all in its power to facilitate the movement of goods from abattoirs, farms, mines and factories at a most expeditious rate. The impact of these amendments, if allowed to proceed, will be yet another nail in the coffin of Australia's rural industries. The rural sector earns vital export income for this nation-almost 40 per cent of total export earnings. The Bureau of Agricultural Economics has forecast the real net value of rural production to fall by 24 per cent in 1985-86 to the second lowest level recorded in the last 30 years.

In framing these amendments it seems that the Minister has paid scant attention to the falling export prices producers are receiving for their products on export markets. Indeed, the amendments reflect a cynical lack of concern by the Government and the net result will be a falling confidence in our ability to get goods to customers. That is hardly the action of a government seriously committed to the plight of the rural industry. The revenue side of the equation for the rural producer is not the only factor neglected by the Minister's one-eyed concern for so-called industrial reality. Rural Australia is facing increasing costs at levels unprecedented in its history. Over the period 1980 to 1984 interest rates have increased by 45 per cent, government taxes and charges by 38 per cent, electricity by 29 per cent, farm machinery and equipment and shipping by 11 per cent and hired labour by a significant amount also.

From these figures it is clear that the Government has played a large part in the increasing costs faced by rural Australia. These realities will not go away. Indeed, they are exacerbated by the Government's record in its interest rate policy, massive spending and an inability to curb the detrimental impact of the unions on costs faced by rural producers. It should be remembered that the meat industry meets 50 per cent of the inspection service charges. For the 12 months ending in March it cost the Federal Department of Primary Industry $13.7m to inspect 8.6 million units slaughtered in Victoria Over the same period it cost the Victorian Department of Agriculture $8.4m to process 16.4 million units. The cost to the State Department was 50c per unit; the cost to the Federal Department was $1.60 per unit. Given the gutlessness that this Government has shown during the Mudginberri dispute it is not surprising that such a discrepancy should appear. The Government had clearly been giving in to union demands even before that dispute, and it proposes to continue with its gutlessness in siding with the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union and the Australian Council of Trade Unions in abrogating its responsibilities for the provision of the essential inspection service.

The problem facing rural industry is essentially a result of changing the cost-price ratios. There has been a runaway cost spiral for services provided between farm and gate. For example, since 1980 freight charges have almost doubled and the major causes of this dramatic increase have been industrial. In my own State of Victoria absenteeism is running between 20 to 45 per cent and industrial disputes cost the farmer in excess of $10m in 1984-85. Union muscle is again exercised at the expense of the national interest and of all Australians whose living standards fall as a result of the higher prices paid for rural produce.

In proposing these amendments under discussion today, the Minister for Primary Industry and the Government are in effect imposing yet another cost on Australian meat producers and rural exporters at a time when their attention should be focused on getting farm costs down. For the sake of industrial reality, the Government is failing to put the national interest first. The farming industry and all Australians will be the losers if these amendments are passed. In allowing its decisions to be dictated by the union movement, the Government is shirking its responsibilities. These amendments make the Minister's responsibilities Clayton's responsibilities-responsibilities he exercises when he is not exercising responsibilities. Apparently the first question the Minister must ask always is: `How will the unions respond; will they let me proceed?' The Government and the Minister stand condemned by these proposed amendments. In the national interest they must be disallowed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The main thrust of the arguments today have related to the Mudginberri dispute so I feel I must rise because Mudginberri is in the Northern Territory. The whole incident brings very little credit to the Pendarvis family or to the Northern Territory Government. If I have time, I will develop that point a little later. It is fair to say that seldom has there been a debate in this place-let us face it; the standard of debate is not generally high when we get on to emotive issues such as this-that so indicates the complete lack of knowledge on the part of the Opposition. There has been an effort on the part of the Opposition to misrepresent most of the facts relating to the case and to take out of that some political gain in one of its organised activities.

SPEECH.PARA: To members of the National Party of Australia, representing the rural community-I use the word `representing' very much in parenthesis since they no longer represent the rural community, which the community has made patently clear to them-I have to say that it is not my usual practice to criticise speakers from the Opposition; but they were pathetic in their attempt to discuss the real background to the disallowance motion before us. The whole exercise this morning was nothing more nor less than a union bashing exercise in which Opposition senators trotted out their set pieces that they keep ready for an occasion when they can use them.

It was noted, although I did not take a point of order on it, that most of the speeches were read. Perhaps they were just pulled out of the bottom drawer and trotted out with the title changed. Of course, to be fair I must say that not all honourable senators read their speeches. Senator Walters did not read hers, but Senator Walters does not need to read her speech on union bashing because she has all her information well and truly in the front of her mind.

It seems to me that the sorts of speeches that we heard this morning were more appropriate to policy speeches or to speeches that one might present in rural electorates at election time, or ones that might be used in debates on matters of public importance when honourable senators need something to send out to their electorates to tell them that they are doing wonderful things on their behalf, rather than a serious attempt to debate the issue in front of us.

In the time allowed-there are only a few minutes left-it is impossible for me to meet all of the issues raised and to point out not only their inadequacies but also their total irrelevance to this debate. The broad issues were canvassed quite clearly by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) who tried in an unemotional way to balance views from the other side and to point out the facts in the debate-the real reasons why the Government, which has a responsibility to resolve problems in the community and which is elected to do this, got together with the Department of Primary Industry and prepared regulations which would meet a situation which had arisen. What we ought to have been debating is whether or not the regulations brought forward-I will say more about this later-are appropriate to meet the needs of the situation. It is not a matter of whether those regulations would upset the American Mr Pendarvis and his wife or whether they would affect some other group, but whether they would meet the inadequacy that the court had pointed out. The court quite clearly made its point that something needed to be done.

For those who perhaps were not listening to Senator Button when he spoke, let me make the facts of the situation clear. The Government of the day, the Federal Government, instructed its staff on four occasions to cross the picket line. This is recorded as fact. Those on the other side, of course, tried to say that this was not done. But on four occasions staff were instructed to cross the picket line. The decision not to cross the picket line was made not by the Federal Government but by the union involved, the Meat Inspectors Association. It is perfectly proper for members of a union to take a decision in an industrial situation which they believe they ought to take. That will not receive a great deal of support from the other side of this chamber. Honourable senators opposite do not believe that the unions, having fought for and won certain conditions, ought to apply them. I will come back to that matter a little later.

The three officers who were involved first had their pay and allowances stopped. That is what the Federal Government did and that is the limit of what it could do. What else could have been done within the agreements that had been reached? Inspectors from the Northern Territory Department of Primary Production were not available. These inspectors are members of an organisation-the Australian Public Service Association-which supported the picket; therefore, they were not prepared to enter the dispute.

The Opposition has the audacity to expect the Labor Party-the Party that represents the people, the unions and more of the middle income group and more of the farmers-to say to a union: `You have won these conditions. We will overthrow them and you will do as you are told'. I am pleased to say that that jackboot approach belongs on the other side of the chamber, not this side. I hope that that approach will never be imported from the Opposition or Queensland since we are hearing from members of the National Party.

The matter of the losses that occurred at Mudginberri is currently before the Federal Court of Australia which is being asked to determine whether Mudginberri suffered damages and, if so, to determine their extent. That is the normal procedure for the court to go through. The results will be fairly interesting when the court comes down with its decision. Information has come to us from some court proceedings about the activities of the Northern Territory Government and its relationship with Mudginberri and Mr Pendarvis. When the Federal Court was discussing this matter it raised the issue of policy. The court said to the Federal Government: `This matter of discretion is one of policy'. The Federal Court said, without expressing a view one way or the other:
. . . that for practical reasons (it may) be desirable that the duty be . . . qualified; if so it would seem to be a simple matter for the Minister to make an appropriate order.

The Minister, taking his lead from the court, said: `The law is not adequate in this situation. We will do something about changing it'. These amended orders were prepared by the Department of Primary Industry in consultation with the Attorney-General's Department. I hate to disappoint honourable senators on the other side of the chamber who see the heavy hand of the ACTU hanging over everything that happens. There was no consultation whatsoever with the ACTU in the preparation of these orders. That must be an awful blow to honourable senators on the other side who would like to think that the ACTU controlled the organisation and made all the decisions. It has about the same relevance and credibility as the rest of the rubbish they have been pumping out this morning in this debate.

The court proceedings brought to light some very interesting information and some more interesting information will be brought out in the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly in the debate this week when the Northern Territory Government will be solidly under attack for its part in the proceedings. Action was taken through a statutory body of the Northern Territory, but not by the statutory body, for certain moneys to be made available to Mr Pendarvis. This is an example of the free market, the free enterprise, that we hear about from honourable senators opposite. What did the Northern Territory Government do? It sent the manager of a statutory body outside and the Chief Minister and his Minister for Primary Production to make arrangements to guarantee a $2m loan to Mr Pendarvis to tide him over his little difficulties; in other words, to allow him to continue the very fight against the unions that honourable senators opposite, in their ignorance, are perpetuating here at present. Not only did the Northern Territory Government guarantee $2m with money it did not have-the Northern Territory Government is far from fluid at present-but also it bought the meat which was being held in the Pendarvis abattoir coolrooms so that Mr Pendarvis would not be embarrassed. The Northern Territory Government gave him a good price for it but instead of selling it and making a profit, which is what it was supposed to do, it sold it back to him some months later at the same price as it paid, at no additional cost for storing it in the cool stores in Darwin. As I have said, the Northern Territory Government will be attacked in the Assembly and it will not be able to meet these arguments.

We on this side of the chamber do not prepare employer-bashing speeches-obviously honourable senators opposite have their set pieces on union bashing. So there is not a great deal of information that I can give at five minutes notice. However, it seems to me a very reasonable proposition to adjourn this matter in order to get more information. Honourable senators opposite seem to object to this. Is this because they do not want the matter investigated? If they do not want the matter investigated, I wonder why. I am sure that Mr Tuxworth, the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, is not too happy about having the matter investigated but he will not be given that luxury. The matter will be investigated and it will be thrown back at him.

Clearly we on this side use a different technique to what honourable senators opposite use. They like to make their decisions on philosophy which they decide in back rooms. Of course I would not suggest that they have consultations with anyone before they make their decisions. We like to speak to the people involved, get the facts and, on the basis of those facts, do something about the matter. The Opposition has criticised us for not having enough facts. Two or three speakers have said that we should have got the information earlier. If this is a fact-I am not accepting it-we intend to do something about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, since the time for debate has expired I seek an extension of time to allow Senator Robertson and other speakers to continue their speeches.
—I believe there is no need for that. There is an agreement and there is no need for recognition by the Chair.

—I appreciate that gesture on the part of the Opposition. The understanding and agreement are that the debate will last for two hours. There is no standing order to cover it but I believe I will be the last speaker. I have only two or three minutes left but I thank the honourable senator for that gesture. The Opposition says that we did not have enough discussion. We will get the information. There has been pressure on the Minister to come forward with a resolution to the problem. That is what governments are elected for. Unlike the National Party-judging from the contributions of its members-the Minister is interested in rural development; he is interested in trying to make sure that we develop our rural industries. As I indicated earlier, the National Party knows that it does not have the support of the rural industry; that support is swinging strongly to the ALP which, quite clearly, is concerned to settle the matter in front of us in an unemotional way, in a way in which we have been briefed with the facts and in a way which will satisfy all parties and be within the regulations and agreements which have been reached. I trust that the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) will now adjourn the debate to allow us to get the information about which I have been talking.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to table a paper regarding the text of a statement by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) on the Association of South East Asian Nations and the Philippines made in the House of Representatives on 14 March.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS ADMINISTRATION (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 February, on motion by Senator Button:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs Administration (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1986 is a relatively non-controversial Bill. The Opposition does not oppose it although it will move a couple of amendments at the Committee stage. I will be seeking clarification from the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) on one or two points of essentially a technical nature. The Bill amends a number of laws administered by the Australian Customs Service to transfer a range of ministerial powers to the Comptroller-General of Customs.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate will remember that last year the Parliament approved the establishment of the Australian Customs Service despite several reservations on the part of the Opposition. In particular, we were critical at the time of the lack of explanation given by the Government for the proposal. We also criticised the Government for its failure to undertake a comprehensive review of the Customs Act at the same time.

The Customs Act is a very involved, complicated piece of legislation which has been in existence since Federation. It is one of the oldest Acts of the Parliament and it has never been effectively reviewed in a comprehensive manner. We took the view last year that, when the major administrative change of establishing the Australian Customs Service was undertaken, it should also have provided an opportunity to undertake a comprehensive review of the whole Act at the same time. I think those criticisms were fully justified then and they still are.

I am a little surprised that the Minister has not informed the Senate in his second reading speech on the Bill we are now debating as to how the new arrangements are working on the basis of the eight or nine months experience we have now had of the operation of a separate Customs Service. I trust that the Minister will do so when he comes to reply at the end of the second reading debate because he must be well aware of the concern in the community about the operation of the Australian Customs Service. That concern has been heightened by certain statements made by the Customs Officers Association of Australia and by some individual Customs officers indicating that all is far from well in important areas in our Customs Service; for example, on the waterfront both in Melbourne and in Sydney, and other examples have been cited as well.

The Minister may also recall that I raised other concerns with him in a question without notice several months ago. Despite an undertaking from the Minister to investigate the concerns I had raised he has yet to inform me of the results of his investigations. Whether this demonstrates a laxity in administration in the Minister's office or in the Customs Service-or more likely both-I do not know but I await the explanation with some interest.

The effect of the Bill now before the Senate is to complete the transfer to the Comptroller-General of the ministerial powers involved in the day to day administration of the Australian Customs Service which the earlier Customs Administration (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Act 1985 commenced. That Act, though, left some 25 per cent of the total ministerial powers still to be exercised personally by the Minister as distinct from the Comptroller-General. The present Bill, when executed, will transfer more of those powers to the Comptroller-General, leaving only about 10 per cent of the powers in Customs laws with the Minister. The Government has described the remaining 10 per cent of these powers that will stay with the Minister as having major policy implications. They include such matters as the extension or variation of bounty assistance arrangements and powers relating to the imposition of dumping and countervailing duties. The Opposition agrees that these powers should be retained by the Minister.

Several other powers are being transferred to the Comptroller-General which I thought might also better remain with the Minister and I would welcome comment on these from the Minister later in the debate. One or two of them will be matters on which we will be moving amendments but I just flag them now. Firstly, under sub-sections 119 (2) and (3) of the Customs Act 1901 the power to grant a certificate of clearance for a ship or aircraft to depart from Australia is to be transferred to the Comptroller-General. I am not too sure on the policy implications of that. It seems to me that that is a matter which may have policy implications and the Minister would wish to retain a decision-making interest but, as I have said, that is something that I would welcome clarification on. Secondly, section 183 of the Customs Act relating to the power to disallow renewal of Customs agents' licences is another matter on which we have some doubts as to the transfer of power from the Minister to the Comptroller-General. Disallowance of renewal is presumably a serious matter and would occur only in serious circumstances. If so I think it would raise the right of a public servant, no matter how distinguished he may be, in the form of the Comptroller-General, to have this disallowance power as distinct from it remaining a ministerial power. There are some aspects on which I will seek some clarification from the Minister in the Committee stage.

Thirdly, I question the transfer to the Comptroller-General of the Minister's power or obligation to publish, by Commonwealth of Australia Gazette notice, indexation of rates of duty under sub-section 26a (5) of the Customs Tariff Act 1982, and paragraph 6A (6) (a) and sub-section 6a (8) of the Excise Tariff Act 1921. This Government introduced the indexation of these duties. By this measure the Hawke Government hoisted another series of automatic, insidious, and largely hidden to the public, taxes on an already tax wearied Australian public. The additional taxes that have been paid as a result of this indexation measure have already run into hundreds of millions of dollars. If the Government is going to engage in this type of snide tax rip-off of virtually every Australian the Minister at the very least should have the intestinal fortitude to make the announcements himself. They are announcements in respect of major policy decisions by the Government and, as such, I think they should be announced by the elected government. In my view, the Government should not hide behind the back of an unelected bureaucrat when announcing such decisions. The Opposition will not necessarily be pressing that point to an amendment but I think it is worth noting that that is being proposed in this Bill. Again I would welcome the Minister's comments.

The Minister said in his second reading speech that one of the prime reasons for this Bill is to relieve him and the Secretary of his Department from the routine of Customs administration and, in consequence therefore, to give him and his departmental head greater opportunity to concentrate on the major and complex issues facing industry in this country. I fully subscribe to that as it is an admirable objective. I would now like to turn to the fundamental issue of the future development of Australian industry which this Bill ostensibly gives the Minister more time to pursue. It is to be hoped that the Minister will be able to devote more time to the policy aspects of his portfolio because industry in this nation is in need of a greatly improved environment if it is to provide the growth in investment, income and employment that we so urgently need and which the Government professes to be concerned about. Before I proceed any further down that track I wish to congratulate the Minister on the extraordinarily successful public relations exercise that he has conducted to persuade Australian industrialists and business people that he is an able and efficient Minister for Industry, Commerce and Technology. He has been very successful in his public relations. I spend much of my time in contact with the business sector and the Minister is not only widely liked but also widely acknowledged as an able Minister. I have no objection at all to the fact that Senator Button is widely liked. We on this side of the Senate like him too-more so perhaps than do some of his own colleagues. What I find much more difficult to accept, indeed quite unacceptable, is his stewardship of the industry, commerce and technology portfolio and his role as the third most senior person in the Hawke Government. I find his role in overall economic policy formulation unacceptable in terms of its having been beneficial to Australian industry. It is about time that this myth was dispelled because, by and large, it is a myth. The simple fact is that the performance of the Minister and of the Government of which he is such a senior member is quite at odds with the rhetoric.

Let us look at some of the facts. It is widely accepted within the private sector and within the walls of this chamber and the Parliament generally that Australian industry needs a macroeconomic environment conducive to growth, investment and employment. That environment embraces at least three points: Firstly, it needs policies as a whole which are stable and predictable; secondly, it needs a government that exercises restraint and discipline, for example in its spending, borrowing and taxation; and, thirdly, it needs a government which is the architect and performer of balanced policies-a balance is required, it is essential, between fiscal policy, monetary policy, wages policy and balance of payments policy. These are the three essential macroeconomic prerequisites for a successful, thriving, vital private sector. I submit that the Government has failed all three of these tests.

Let us look at some of the evidence for that. I mentioned that policies should be stable and predictable. That aim has not been pursued by this Government, despite the rhetoric, over the three years of its term of office. It has produced policies which, for example in the area of government spending in its first two Budgets, have involved a rate of increase in real terms not far short of that for the disastrous years of the previous Labor Administration, the Whitlam Government, in the first half of the 1970s. Many people well remember the disaster of the blow- out in government spending which occurred at that time and which has done much to cause the problems which are now confronting the economy in the 1980s. Yet last year, in a sudden attempted sharp turnaround, the Government greatly reined in the level of increase in government spending. One still finishes up with a government which in its three years of office has increased government spending at a rate twice the average of the seven years of the Fraser Government. The present Government has been a reckless spender and indeed has been unpredictably reckless in chopping and changing the rates of its spending policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you support the Northern Territory railway line like your leader?
—I find that fairly irrelevant to my speech.
—If you are talking about reckless spending, talk about that and the other $1.5 billion worth of spending promises he has given.

—I mentioned that the Government had restrained, at least in terms of its Budget figures, expenditure in 1985-86 to a figure of some 1.5 per cent. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) is now talking about the need for a major rein-in of expenditure in the year ahead. He has talked to the Cabinet about the need for expenditure reductions of $1.4 billion. It seems not to be generally known, but it should be, that in 1985-86 there is every indication, on the basis of figures to date during this year, that expenditure will blow out by $1.3 billion over and above the Budget estimates. So if the Treasurer is talking about a cut of $1.4 billion being required, all he is talking about is trying to bring the figure back to the amount it should have been had the original Budget estimates been adhered to.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate interrupted.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received through His Excellency the Governor-General from the Governor of the State of Tasmania a certificate of the choice of Jocelyn Margaret Newman as a senator to fill the vacancy in the representation of that State caused by the resignation of Senator Peter Elliot Rae.

INTERJECT.PARA: The certificate was laid on the table and read by the Clerk.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Senator Jocelyn Margaret Newman made and subscribed the oath of allegiance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister aware that today's housing finance figures show that in January new loans for the purchase of newly erected houses were the lowest on record; total lending for housing fell by 14.4 per cent over the month; since September building society lending is down by 45 per cent and savings bank lending has dropped by 33 per cent; and the total number of dwelling units for which loans have been provided has dropped by more than 30 per cent in the last six months? Does the Minister accept that this serious decline is a direct result of the Government's high interest rate policy? What action will it take to reduce interest rates generally and restore the flow of funds to the housing industry?

—The question of the reduction in interest rates generally has been the subject matter of a series of questions in the Senate, from Senator Chaney and others, and I have given the same answer on each occasion as I give now: The Government recognises that there is a fine tuning to be done in respect of the reduction in interest rates and will take appropriate action as it sees fit at appropriate times. With regard to the question of the housing industry, the whole question of the housing industry will be considered by the Cabinet next week, and I am not in a position to make any advance preview of what will be determined.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. On earlier occasions in the Senate, this Minister, the Leader of the Government, has recognised the danger to the economy of high interest rates. In light of the figures that I have cited, does he still claim that all that is required is some small adjustment? Do the figures not show that there is a serious problem now for the Australian economy which needs the urgent attention of this Government?

—The Government has never tried to run away from the serious effects of high interest rates. That fact does not alter the answer which I gave previously. In Senator Chaney's question there are some figures which I would regard as serious in respect of the housing industry. But there are really two parts to the question. One is in respect of interest rates generally and their effects on the economy, and I repeat the answer that I have previously given. In respect of the housing industry question, I say that the Government will be examining that problem next week and then we shall make a response.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. It relates to a constituent of mine who is a totally and permanently incapacitated pensioner with a stepson who was born to his present wife at a time when she was not formally married to anyone. The veteran has been advised by the Minister's Department that even though his stepson is recognised by the Department of Social Security for family allowance purposes and by the Department of Veterans' Affairs from which he receives a dependant's allowance, the child is not eligible for benefits under the soldiers children education scheme since he is not the product of a marriage or a dissolved marriage. Does the Minister agree that this provision is anomalous and reflects an outdated morality? If so, will he consider amending the legislation accordingly?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that under the law as it stands, the veteran's stepson is not eligible for benefits under the soldiers children education scheme since he is not the product, as Senator Coates has said, of a dissolved marriage. I agree that this provision, which dates from the period between World Wars I and II, is quite inappropriate for this day and age. There are other instances to which I could refer the Senate of similar discriminations which have been brought to my attention-for example, the case of another veteran, in this case a TPI veteran who has custody of his orphaned grandchild. Because that child, too, is not the product of a dissolved marriage, he is ineligible under the existing legislation for the soldiers children education scheme.

ANSWER.PARA: However, the Government is aware of these anomalies, and that is why in the Veterans' Entitlements Bill this anomaly will be addressed and, I hope, resolved by including, within the definition of `child of a veteran', `any child who is, or was immediately before the death of the veteran, wholly or substantially dependent on the veteran'. This means, under the new provision, that the first veteran's stepson as well as the second veteran's grandchild, in the two cases to which I have referred, will both be eligible for benefits under the SCE scheme, which will be renamed the veterans' children education scheme.

However, these veterans will have to wait until such time as the Opposition decides to allow the Bill to pass the Senate without further irresponsible and unsupported amendments upon which the Opposition is currently insisting. Until such time as the Senate deals with that legislation, these anomalies will remain incapable of being remedied.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. I refer to reports that the Government is giving consideration to a new determination of the import parity price for oil based on the present level of oil prices which remains significantly lower than the price on which the 1 March determination was made. I ask: Is it a fact that a price based on the current IPP formula would result in a drop of around 4c a litre in petrol prices? Does the Government intend to pass on that benefit in full to Australian motorists, or is it going to cheat them yet again by imposing a further increase in the tax on petrol to compensate itself for its loss of revenue?

—The Government has given preliminary consideration to this matter, but we will not be giving final consideration to it or making a final decision until next week, when the outcome of this week's Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries and post-OPEC meetings will be better known. As I have said on previous occasions, it is perfectly possible that, should the OPEC members be able to get their act together, as many of the individual member countries now clearly want to do, and particularly if some appropriate response can also come forward from some of the non-OPEC producing countries, we could see a very rapid escalation of the price of oil back to around $US20, as compared with the present level of around $US12.50 or $US12.60, which, as compared with $US16.77, on which we made our present determination, represents a very significant drop of the order of magnitude which Senator Durack has outlined. It is premature to make any final decision on this matter until we know what is happening this week. I trust that Senator Durack will appreciate the good sense of taking it that way.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I know that the Minister cannot make a decision now because of the volatility of the situation; if prices remain at around the present level, so that there would be a drop of 4c a litre, does the Government regard that as a significant enough figure to impose an increase in petrol tax?
—It is premature to speculate on any of these matters. We will leave it until next week, and Senator Durack can respond appropriately then.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation to the arrangements for the funding of the upgrading of the Wynyard Airport in Tasmania to full jet standard. I ask the Minister whether he is aware that the Tasmanian Government is claiming to have contributed $3m towards the cost of upgrading the airport. I ask the Minister whether the Tasmanian Government's claims are true. If not, could the Minister advise how the upgrading of this airport is being funded?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that the Tasmanian Government is claiming that it is contributing $3m towards the upgrading of Wynyard Airport. In fact, there is a large sign at the entrance to the airport making such a claim. However, I can say that this claim is completely untrue. Arrangements for the funding of the upgrading of Wynyard Airport to jet standard are as follows: The Commonwealth has contributed $1.2m, which represents the costs which would have been incurred in partly upgrading the airport.
