The Commonwealth has also contributed a further $3m from the Gordon below Franklin Dam compensation fund. The Minister advises me that the Tasmanian Government has not contributed any of its own funds at all, despite a shortfall of $2.5m which still has to be found. Therefore, the likelihood is that the local ratepayers will be called upon to meet that shortfall.

ANSWER.PARA: I understand that the Burnie Port Authority, which took control under the airports local ownership plan, has made statements in the local Press to the effect that the Federal Government should take responsibility for providing the funds still being sought. First, the Federal Government offered to fund fully the partial upgrading of the airport, after which further upgrading to jet standard would have been funded if a demand existed to warrant it. Secondly, the Burnie Port Authority, in deciding to go ahead and undertake full upgrading with the full concurrence of the Tasmanian Government, did so with the full knowledge that by its taking this route the Federal Government would not be responsible for the full cost of upgrading. There is now no justification for the Tasmanian Government, therefore, to insist on Federal funds. It may well be the case if it were ill-advised to take the course it did; but having done so, it cannot expect the Federal Government to bail it out.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware of statements by the Ambassador for Disarmament, Mr Butler, reported in the Age on 13 March, encouraging the Government officially to disclose information on United States bases in Australia which is now on the United States public record? Does the Government accept that Mr Butler's statement effectively admits that the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics has more knowledge of the functions of the basis than the Australian people? Does this not indicate that the Government's secrecy is directed at its own citizens, effectively placing a matter of national security beyond democratic debate and control? Given that the Pine Gap and North West Cape agreements will be open for notice of termination in 1986 and 1987 respectively and that the Nurrungar agreement is already open for termination, will the Government release to the Australian public at least as much information on the functions of the bases as is now on the United States public record, to allow informed debate on their continued operation on Australian soil?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the Prime Minister's statement to Parliament on 6 June 1984, he made public, with the concurrence of the United States Government, the following information in respect of the joint facilities at Pine Gap and Nurrungar. I put this statement on the record again because it seems necessary from time to time to do so. First, the joint facilities contribute to the objectives of timely knowledge of developments that have military significance, effective deterrence and the verification of arms limitation agreements. Secondly, they provide early warning by receiving from space satellites information about missile launches and the provision of information about the occurrence of nuclear explosions.
—Do you really believe that this is an answer to my question?

—The honourable senator should wait. I will get to his question. In fact, I am in the middle of answering his question, but apparently a little background information is needed to put it into context. The Prime Minister said at the time that the information he had made public on the facilities would correct serious misunderstandings and should provide the Australian people with the reassurance they properly seek. Further disclosure would damage Australian and United States interests. The Government does not intend to comment further than that statement upon speculation or assertions about the joint facilities. It has already been made clear on numerous occasions that the joint facilities operate with the full knowledge and concurrence of the Australian Government.

ANSWER.PARA: It is the case that Ambassador Butler was reported by the Age to have referred to disquiet in some quarters about information on the joint facilities being available under United States information laws but not releasable in Australia. Leaving aside just for a moment whether Ambassador Butler was or was not correctly reported, the Australian and United States governments have identical policies on the release of information about the joint facilities. It is therefore not true that United States citizens have access to more information about the facilities than do Australian citizens.

As to the question of the reporting of Ambassador Butler's remarks, it appears that he was misrepresented. The Age reported him as saying that there were differences between what the United States public was told and what the Australian public was told-a theme that Senator Chipp has picked up in his question today. I am informed that Mr Butler actually said that there is a perception of such a difference, not that the difference actually exists. I repeat my answer: There is no difference between Australian and United States Government policies on releasing information about the joint defence facilities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Veterans' Affairs seen the advertisement inserted by the Returned Services League on page 5 of the latest edition of the House Magazine and headed `Pass the VEB', which says that the RSL, Legacy, the War Widows Guild and the Totally and Permanently Incapacitated Federation `are strongly united in calling on the Opposition to not press its remaining amendment' to the repatriation Bill? In this light, can the Minister inform the Senate of just who is out of step with the clearly expressed wishes of the ex-service community?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that the latest edition, dated 19 March, of the House Magazine contains an advertisement submitted by the Returned Services League and headed `Pass the VEB'. It correctly says:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has conceded all Senate amendments except one that would require undetermined claims lodged before 15 May, 1985, to be dealt with under S.47 of the Repatriation Act as it applied then. Claims could then be approved without there being any link between the disability and previous war service. This is clearly contrary to the spirit of repatriation legislation.

It is true that the Senate, in its wisdom, has still taken the view that all of the amendments that have been recommended by the Senate or requested by the House of Representatives should be accepted by the Government. The Government has been very generous, I believe, in accepting 40 of the 41 amendments. It is not prepared to accept the final amendment which removes the whole basic thrust of the repatriation legislation-that is, that pensions should be given on the basis of evidence of some relationship to war service. That view has the unanimous support, as the advertisement said, of the veteran community. The Returned Services League of Australia, the War Widows Guild, the TPI Association, Legacy and the Australian Veterans and Defence Services Council, at a summit meeting here in Canberra, requested the Senate to exercise its right and take on board the views of the veteran community.

What was said last year substantially was that the Government had not consulted sufficiently with the veterans movement in Australia in respect to the 14 May statement and the Veterans' Entitlements Bill. The Government has now consulted and got a unified position out of the veteran movement in Australia-that is, the peak organisations. Nevertheless, the view is still being expressed to me that the Senate is not prepared to pass the legislation. I ask, therefore, that the Opposition, in particular, and the Australian Democrats take into account the views of the veterans organisations, particularly the premier organisation, the Returned Services League, which has taken the step of inserting an advertisement in the House Magazine asking the Parliament to pass the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations not agree that an employer who insists on employing untrained and inexperienced women on heavy labouring work-work which is normally carried out by men-is committing an act of unjustified sex discrimination which could lead to injury because women are not adequately trained or physically built to perform such work. If this is the case, why do community employment program grants require the employment of 50 per cent women, even on labouring-type jobs?

—Implicit in the question is a belief that all women are lacking in physical strength. While I think it is true on average, without doubt, that men are physically stronger than women, it is certainly not true that all women are lacking in physical strength. Indeed, I have struck one or two who have intimidated me, I can tell you.
—Senator Walters.
—Yes, Senator Walters for starters.
—Senator Knowles.
—Senator Knowles, too, as my colleague Senator Gareth Evans has helpfully reminded me. As for the rest of the question, I will seek a more detailed response from Mr Willis.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Special Minister of State whether the Government has noted comments by Major-General Grey of the Australian Federal Police reported in the Weekend Herald, and I quote:

QUESTION.PARA: Concerned citizens could wonder at the massive allocation to the `non-war'-which is defence in the 1980s.
They could compare it with the allocation to the real war of the 1980s-the war against crime.
Major-General Grey went on to comment:

I can identify no external threat to Australia-nor can anybody else, to my satisfaction . . . we have a war, 24 hours a day, seven days a week, in our cities, towns and countryside . . . carried out by criminals who deliberately erode our rights.

Has the Government noted those comments by a distinguished Army Major-General before he took up his present position and will it take those comments into account when allocating funds in its Budget deliberations?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has noted the report referred to in which Major-General Grey indicated his view that there is a more real threat to Australia from crime than from defence contingencies. I suppose it is the case that Major-General Grey is better equipped than most to make comparisons between defence and crime fighting priorities, but the point I make on behalf of the Special Minister of State is that in our Budgets to date the Government has been able to achieve real increases both for defence and for law enforcement. In particular, the number of police in the Australian Federal Police has been increased each year and the Government is committed to further increases over the next two years. In addition to manpower increases, the Government has agreed to a major upgrading of the AFP's computer capacity and is examining proposals for major improvements in AFP accommodation in Sydney and Melbourne. In an atmosphere of overall expenditure restraint, the Government will need to examine all expenditure programs carefully, including both defence and law enforcement programs.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button. I refer the Minister to Australian Bureau of Statistics figures recently released which show falling manufacturing production, falling motor vehicle registrations, falling private sector building approvals and falling savings bank deposits. I ask the Minister: What are the implications of these figures for the stated budgetary strategy of `setting sail for growth' and, in particular, for the level of unemployment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The main implication of those questions is that Senator Parer asked me a question about them. He has not been able to ask that sort of question in the last two years. I certainly agree that those matters are of concern but they are matters which might well have been expected by the Government as a result of the interest rates policy which it has adopted for reasons which are quite clear, I suspect. Each of those things can be dealt with in isolation. I do not think there is any point in doing that. I have already answered a question from Senator Chaney regarding the implications for the housing industry. The implications for the motor vehicle industry were quite expected last year and on a number of occasions I have answered questions here about other implications for the motor vehicle industry arising from the fringe benefits tax, for example.

ANSWER.PARA: I have said on numerous occasions in this chamber that the Government is committed to strong growth in the Australian economy, but as has been said by the Treasurer, at this time we need to cut back on the growth rate we have experienced in the last two years. Those figures are the consequence of that. A little later on I hope Senator Parer will ask me another question of the same kind and I will see what answer I am able to produce on that occasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. I remind the Minister of his comments in the Senate on 14 February 1986 about farm incomes and the quarantining of farm losses. The Minister indicated in those comments that he had received correspondence from the Livestock and Grain Producers Association of New South Wales on the issue. I ask: Can the Minister now advise the Senate whether he has had any further correspondence from the LGPA and whether this correspondence has provided any additional insights into the issues upon which he previously commented?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 14 February I mentioned that I had written to Mr Tooth, the President of the LGPA, asking him to explain the conflict between his claim that most farmers had off-farm incomes in excess of $20,000 and were therefore affected by the quarantining provisions of the tax package and claims by the LGPA and others that farmers are the new poor. I have a reply. I do not know whether it provides any insight into the issues but it does provide some insights into the ethos of the LGPA. In this reply, dated 27 February, Mr Tooth mentions that Bureau of Agricultural Economics figures of off-farm earnings refer only to investments held by farm family members and not to those held by farm businesses. Implicitly the figure of $20,000, or the number of people with that sort of income, should have been higher. More interestingly, the letter goes on to state:

ANSWER.PARA: The BAE's estimates . . . are based on a sub-sample of the total farm population . . . and includes only those farmers which can readily be identified as being family owned and operated. In other words, company owned and other enterprise-based farms are excluded--
this is the important part-
and these are precisely the operations which will be most affected by the proposed quarantining arrangements.

Some of us have long suspected that the LGPA represents Pitt Street farmers rather than bona fide farmers. It is nice to have that suspicion confirmed in writing by the President of the LGPA; that is, that the LGPA is concerned about `company owned and other enterprise-based farms'. The letter goes on to say that Mr Tooth was not implying that assistance to agriculture was justified on the basis of low farm income or farm poverty but that farm sector profitability had fallen because of the policies of successive governments. However, the issues to which the LGPA gives the highest profile are those of capital gains tax and the quarantining of farm losses, neither of which will have any impact on farm sector profitability, which has declined for a variety of reasons, but both of which will maximise the chances of the present financial problems recurring at some time in the future. Mr Tooth goes on to cite a hypothetical example of a farmer who buys a harvesting machine for contracting purposes on a loan of $100,000, paying interest of $20,000 and so on. He says that such a farmer would be unfairly discriminated against by the taxation provisions. In that comment he completely overlooks the fact that, to the extent that a machine is used for contracting off the farm, the interest costs and, I believe, the depreciation costs may be offset against the income earned from contracting. That is a very important oversight indeed.

Finally, it is asserted in the letter that if the quarantining provisions had applied 15 to 20 years ago the cotton industry would not have been established. I want to make two comments on that: Firstly, it has yet to be demonstrated that if the cotton growers in New South Wales were paying the full cost of the irrigation water that they use, which they do not, that industry would be viable; and, secondly, and more importantly, the major contributors to the establishment of the cotton industry were Americans who had no income in Australia on which losses could have been offset. Therefore, the point that Mr Tooth makes is quite irrelevant. In closing, since the major points of contention are the question of capital gains tax and the quarantining of farm losses, I say again that reversal of government decisions on either or both of those issues would make absolutely no contribution to easing the present fiscal problems in the agricultural sector but they would, to the extent that they would encourage speculation in the future in the purchase of land at unsustainably high prices, maximise the chance of a recurrence of the problem.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES PUBLIC HOSPITALS: VISITING MEDICAL OFFICERS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Is it not true that the New South Wales State Government agreed last year to abide by the decision of Mr Justice Macken on pay levels of visiting medical officers in New South Wales public hospitals? If so, what has been done in accordance with Mr Justice Macken's decision last December that visiting medical officers should receive substantial increases in pay?
—I will have to seek advice on the matter raised in Senator Sheil's question.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Education, a question relating to an answer which I received to a question on notice about the adequacy of allowances under the isolated children's education assistance scheme. I was informed that these allowances are reviewed in the Budget context. Nevertheless, I wish to ask the Minister whether any work has been or will be undertaken to assess the adequacy of these allowances, taking into account the costs borne by parents of isolated children who are obliged to live away from home to attend school.

—The answer to Senator Colston's question is yes. My Department regularly reviews the effectiveness of all our programs, including those under which children living in isolated areas get assistance for travelling and school fees. That advice is available to me at the time of the Budget consideration. There have been some improvements in the levels of allowances available. I would say, in very general terms, that for some families it is an adequate level and that other families with a lower income still have difficulties. The matter is very much under active consideration. We are assisted in reviewing the effectiveness of this program by the efforts of the Isolated Children's Parents Association, which is very active and which represents the interests of parents of isolated children throughout Australia. The Association regularly meets with officers of my Department, with the Commonwealth Schools Commission and, from time to time, with me. It is a very useful source of advice on how effective the program is in assisting isolated children. As well, I expect that the Schools Commission will address shortly in some detail issues related to education in rural areas, which, of course, will incorporate a further examination of the needs of isolated children.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Does the Government continue to oppose lifting the 13.5 per cent ceiling on home loan interest rates? If so, will the Minister give an unequivocal commitment to that effect? If not, does this not conflict with the statements by both the Treasurer and the Prime Minister during recent State election campaigns and the continued denials of the Minister for Housing and Construction that lifting the ceiling was an option for the Government?
—An almost identical question was asked of Senator Button-I think it was the first question of the day-and I have nothing to add to what Senator Button said.

—Will the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs inform the Senate of recent initiatives taken by the Australian Government to assist in securing world peace? What progress has been made in obtaining support for a nuclear-free South Pacific? Is the Government united in the view that the removal of threats to world peace is a subject of overwhelming concern?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since taking office in March 1983, the Government has taken a great many initiatives to promote peace, disarmament and arms control. I could occupy a large portion of the Senate's time in detailing those initiatives but I will simply summarise them by saying this: The Government has actively encouraged an end to the nuclear arms race by the two super-powers, promoted a comprehensive ban on nuclear testing in all environments for all times, made a special effort to develop effective international control of chemical weapons, made it clear that it does not wish to see the arms race extended to outer space, ratified a number of international arms control agreements and strengthened Australia's institutional capacity to make a contribution to peace and disarmament, not least through the appointment of a permanent and very effective Ambassador for Disarmament. The Government took a leading role in negotiation of the South Pacific nuclear-free zone which was adopted by heads of government at the South Pacific Forum in 1985. The treaty is in the process of ratification by the states or parties concerned. The Government's commitment to peace, disarmament and arms control is clearly reflected in the Australian Labor Party platform and also in the $3m program of activities which is planned to mark the International Year of Peace 1986.

ANSWER.PARA: I want to make it clear that the Government is completely united on these questions. That places us in marked contrast with the situation which exists within the Liberal Party. Those members of the Liberal Party who show any kind of sensitive and informed interest in peace and disarmament issues are immediately ostracised and condemned by their parliamentary colleagues. I refer in particular to a report in the Adelaide News of 4 March, just a few weeks ago, which reports the fact-it was widely reported-that Senator Hill and a front bencher in the State Parliament, Mr Lucas, called on all members of the Party in South Australia to join mass peace demonstrations, starting with a Palm Sunday march on 23 March. I understand that Senator Teague was also a party to that exercise, although he is not mentioned in this report. According to the newspaper report, which I believe is accurate, a letter was sent to Liberal Party State councillors by the Opposition finance and taxation spokesman in this House, Senator Messner, expressing surprise and concern at this call by senior Liberals to join the Palm Sunday peace march. It is hardly surprising I suppose that Senator Messner, who is always quick to see the way that the wind is blowing in his public responses, should respond as he did. He gets his lead in this respect from the leadership of his Party. I refer in particular to a statement which summarises the attitude of the Liberal Party towards peace and disarmament-a statement made by the former Leader of the parliamentary party and now its foreign affairs spokesman, Andrew Peacock, on 7 August last year in which he opposed the South Pacific nuclear free zone treaty and made clear the Opposition's commitment to a policy of accepting the installation and storage of nuclear weapons on Australian soil. That is very clear in the terms of Mr Peacock's Press release of 7 August.

TALK.START.PARA: —He did not say that, Gareth. You are telling fibs.

—It is not a statement which has subsequently been repudiated or qualified in any way. I am not surprised that this is embarrassing even Senator Crichton-Browne, who is normally unembarrassable about any subject. But it is a demonstration of just how comprehensively insensitive the forces opposite are to these questions of peace and disarmament which are absolutely fundamental to the future not only of Australia but of the world and which it is entirely appropriate should be addressed in the way that we in the Labor Party have addressed them during our period in office.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Did Mr Robert Holmes a Court give the Government information on how he will finance the interest payments on his $2 billion overseas borrowing and the further $500m he will need to buy the shares of the Adelaide Steamship Co. Ltd for which he currently has options? Does the Government know against which company's profits the interest charges will be offset? Is the Government aware that Mr Holmes a Court's three-tiered company structure is designed to avoid the loss of the dividend rebate on the shares of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and that this structure will put $69m in his pocket at the expense of the pay as you earn taxpayer? Is the Government concerned about these matters? I should add that the three-tiered structure is essentially designed to circumvent the application of section 50 of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to parts of the question let me say that the Government sought assurances from Mr Holmes a Court about a number of matters. At Question Time in the Senate I have indicated the essential nature of those matters but have declined to go into details--
—Why?

—I do not know whether Senator Crichton-Browne has been here this month or this year but I have said why on at least two occasions. He was probably reading a comic at the time. I have indicated on a number of occasions the nature of the commitments the Government sought from Mr Holmes a Court and, indeed, from Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd about some of these matters. I indicated that, while we will inform the Senate and the House of Representatives broadly of the nature of the undertakings sought and the answers given, we are not in a position at this stage to publish any of those undertakings while the Supreme Court action in Victoria is proceeding. I will certainly seek further information from the Treasury about the particular point which Senator Siddons has raised regarding the alleged three-tiered structure of the Holmes a Court company. I am advised on a tentative basis that dividend rebates under section 46 of the Income Tax Assessment Act allow dividends to be passed from one company to another without incurring multiple taxation of the one income. Where a dividend is passed perhaps through several companies it would be incorrect to tax it as income in the hands of each receiving company. This principle has also been recognised by the Government in its introduction of the imputation system to avoid the double taxation of dividends. Of course, that is scheduled for introduction later this year.

ANSWER.PARA: I have said that I am not personally aware of the answer to the problem posed by Senator Siddons in relation to the company structure but I add that there are a number of assumptions in the honourable senator's question, to all of which I offer the observation that they may or may not be incorrect. Some very nice theories have been developed about where Mr Holmes a Court would make his borrowings, what the source of those borrowings would be and in particular how the interest payments would be handled. Some of those theories have developed into an art form and I must say that many aspects of those theories have been shown already to be wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his undertaking to seek further advice from the Treasury on this matter. I will just word my question slightly differently so that it is abundantly clear what information we are seeking. Section 50, as no doubt the Minister knows, states that a company that borrows to buy shares must write off interest against those shares. That is specific in section 50. It is a matter of well-known fact in business circles in this country that the three-tiered structure of Bell Resources Pty Ltd does manage to circumvent that clear meaning of section 50. It is that--
—Order! Will the honourable senator ask his supplementary question. He has been making a statement.
—My supplementary question is this: Will the Minister, in giving his answer, also make clear that it is section 50 about which we are particularly concerned?

—Mr President, it is not my function to usurp your function in any respect but that is not a supplementary question; it is just a further speech by Senator Siddons on this issue, one of a series. There have been some glaring inaccuracies, if I might say so, in several of the earlier versions. I am now asked whether I will draw attention to the fact that it is section 50 about which the honourable senator is talking. That was put as his supplementary question but it is not a supplementary question. Let me repeat what I said earlier. The answer to his question is in two parts. The Government received assurances on a wide range of matters, including some of the matters referred to in his first question. As I have said, we are not in a position at this stage to publish those assurances. The issue of publication of those assurances will be dealt with and considered by the Government finally after the current Supreme Court action is resolved. It is the present intention of the Government, with the agreement of the parties, to publish the assurances that we were given. Quite apart from that, I undertook to ask the Treasury to examine what appeared to be another technical question which Senator Siddons raised in the first part of his question. I will do that.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TEACHING PROFESSION: APPOINTMENT OF WOMEN TO SENIOR POSITIONS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Education in that capacity and also in her capacity as Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women. Has the Minister noted that the Director of the Catholic Education Commission of Western Australia is reported as regretting that there are too few women in senior teaching and executive positions in the Western Australian Catholic education system? Has the Minister any advice for the Director?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention has been drawn to Dr Tannock's comments about his concern that there are few women in senior positions in the Catholic education system in Western Australia, and a declining number. The first thing I wish to say to Dr Tannock is to congratulate him for recognising this as a problem. It is a problem not only in terms of the employment prospects for women but also in terms of the education process. Although the debate about the merits of single sex versus co-educational schools for girls continues, and is not finally resolved, one thing is clear and is agreed by most students of this issue; that is that many of the successes of single sex girls schools, be they Catholic girls schools or other sorts of girls schools, in the past have been due to the very strong role modelling that the girls experienced at school from very competent female principals. It is a matter of concern not only for the Catholic system in Western Australia but for other parts of the non-government system, and regrettably for State systems also, that the number of women in senior positions, particularly as principals of girls schools or principals of co-educational schools, is declining, not increasing as we would expect it to increase given the equal employment policies and legislation which are in effect in many parts of Australia and federally.
—Due in part to the continuing retirement of religious--

—Senator Baume interjects that one of the reasons why Catholic women are seen less in senior positions is that there has been a decline in the number of religious positions. That is certainly a contributing factor. Nonetheless many women-Catholic and others-are still teaching in the Catholic system; so the pool of available women for teaching positions is not smaller although the particularly suitable religious women for these jobs are not available in the numbers that they were. I think Dr Tannock is right to pinpoint this as a problem and to set up a working party to address it. I hope that his initiative in this regard will be followed by the Catholic system throughout Australia and by other education systems.

ANSWER.PARA: In conclusion, in answer to Senator Giles's question about the advice I would have to give Dr Tannock, although his system is not covered by Federal legislation I would be very happy to make available to him all of the information we now have in the Office of the Status of Women on the development and implementation of our affirmative action employment policy.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I direct a question to the Minister for Resources and Energy and it relates to the subject that was raised earlier by Senator Durack in his question about fluctuations in the price of oil. Is the Minister able to confirm that at the present Australian dollar exchange rate and the international price, the fall in the price of oil will result in something like $500m to $600m in loss of revenue to the Government if no recoupment action is taken? Could he confirm the magnitude of that figure? What is the present position of the oil companies regarding stock losses resulting from price fluctuations? Is any action contemplated by the Government to compensate these companies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case that if the import parity price were to come down now to reflect the prevailing world price, which as I said before is something under $US13 per barrel, the reduction in crude oil excise revenue to the Commonwealth would be of the order of $500m to $600m; I think it may even be a little higher at the moment. Obviously that is something that is being taken into account in the Government's current review that I referred to in answer to Senator Durack.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the refiners' stock loss problem, it is true that since the world oil price plateaued to a further low level after the last decision and that lower price of around $US13 or less has been applicable for the whole of March so far, it is the case that refiners, to the extent that they have been taking higher price domestic liftings as compared with the cheaper crude they could have purchased on the world oil market, are storing up for themselves a further stock loss problem in the event that the import parity price is reduced.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is your policy.
—The Government indicated an appreciation of that problem.
—Order!

—I do not mind a classy interjection, Mr President. If Senator Durack lifts his game I do not mind spending some time on him in Question Time. I have just indicated that the Government expressed some sympathy for the refiners' plight and the implications of that in its decision for 1 March. No doubt it will again take that into account in its decision-if it makes any decisions-over the next few days to lower the import parity price earlier than would otherwise be the case.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence and refer to my question to him of 14 March concerning the RIMPAC exercises. In light of his answer to this question, I again ask: Is it not appropriate, given that Australia has decided not to take part in the bombing of the island of Kahloolawe during the RIMPAC exercise and even though such a decision has to be made by the individual participating nations, that the Australian Government still make representations to these countries to follow suit? As this year's scenario for the RIMPAC exercise consists of the Hawaiian islands having been occupied by an invading orange force, with a blue naval task force liberating it and with Australia acting as a baddie, along with Canada and the United States air force, will the Minister explain what relevance this scenario has to the self-reliance defence strategy for Australia outlined by the Minister for Defence?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the island of Kahloolawe is United States territory. Therefore it is a matter for the United States Government to decide whether it should be used as a bombing range by its forces and those of other countries. Once the United States Government has decided on the matter it is up to individual countries to decide for themselves whether they should use the range. In these circumstances it would be inappropriate for the Australian Government to make representations to the United States Government or other governments on the matter. As I said on 14 March, the Australian forces will not participate in the bombardment.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the remainder of the question, exercises such as RIMPAC are designed to maintain and enhance important operational capabilities which make a strategy of self-reliance credible. They provide opportunities for the Australian Defence Force to operate its sophisticated defence equipments in demanding tactical environments at the limits of their operational capabilities.

Being a combined exercise involving several nations, the RIMPAC exercise does not, of itself, reflect specifically Australian circumstances. The scenario simply provides general conditions within which co-ordinated operational techniques can be practised. Exercise scenarios really have nothing to do with strategic planning. I think Senator Vallentine's question needs to take that consideration very much into account.

Combined exercises with our traditional friends and allies allow the Australian Defence Force to maintain high capability standards in a resourceful and time efficient manner. These operational capabilities are completely relevant to a strategy of self-reliance since, in the unlikely event that they would be needed, the Australian defence forces would be able to employ them successfully.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance in his own capacity and also that of Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the extensive media coverage of leaked Treasury Budget documents on alleged squirrelled funds by the States. Is it not true that this attack on the States, which are required to provide basic services to the Australian people, is nothing more than an attempt to restrict the States in their activities, rather than a realistic effort by the Federal Government to grasp the nettle and apply real limitations on the growth of Federal Government expenditure?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —May I suggest that if Senator Vanstone is seriously interested in containing the growth of Federal Government expenditure she give her leader a stern lecture on the subject because in the last 12 months he and his associates have given firm commitments to increase outlays by $1.5 billion-$1.5 billion over and above existing levels of expenditure, plus $3,600m worth of tax expenditure, that is, revenue losses because of tax concessions, thereby increasing the deficit by a total of $5 billion. If Senator Vanstone is seriously interested in reigning in profligate government expenditure or potential profligate government expenditure, I suggest that she lecture people on her own side, particularly her Leader, rather than members of this Government.

ANSWER.PARA: I said the other day that I will not comment on allegedly leaked documents. Independently of any allegedly leaked documents, it is known that some State governments have been squirrelling money away for purposes which the Commonwealth regards as improper. For example, for many years the Commonwealth has advanced moneys to Queensland for rural adjustment purposes, both under the present rural adjustment scheme and the scheme that preceded it, whatever it was called. Loans-partially a grant component and partially a loan component-are repayable over a 20-year period with a repayment holiday at the front end of the loan. The Queensland Government has on-lent this money to farmers, recovered it very quickly from them and stuck it away in a slush fund. The Queensland Government has lent the money given to it by the Commonwealth for on-lending to farmers, to the farmers, taken it back from them after a couple of years and stuck it away in a slush fund to use for any purpose whatsoever. The Government is currently making an attempt, firstly, to quantify the extent to which the amount of money is being, in our view, improperly used-or misused, if honourable senators prefer-and, secondly, to do something about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs state what progress has been made toward achieving the release of Nelson Mandela?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been renewed media speculation recently about Mandela's possible release but so far there is no evidence of any actual progress towards this goal. The Government has noted President Botha's suggestion in January that Nelson Mandela could be released in return for the release of a South African prisoner of war in Angola, Captain du Toix, and two Soviet dissidents. While the Government notes President Botha's willingness to consider releasing Mandela on humanitarian grounds, it considers these conditions unrealistic and reaffirms its previously stated position that he should be released unconditionally.

ANSWER.PARA: On 2 September last year the Australian Government called for the release of political prisoners, including the immediate release of Mandela, as an essential step toward dialogue and negotiation leading to the end of apartheid and a transition to a united, free and democratic South Africa. There has been growing international pressure by countries, including those of the European Economic Community, the United States of America and the United Kingdom on the South African Government to release Nelson Mandela unconditionally. I remind the Senate that the unconditional release of Mandela, as well as other political prisoners, is also a central element in the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting accord agreed to in Nassau in October last year. Today, in the face of continuing violence in South Africa, it is even more urgent that a process of negotiation begin. It is essential to that process that leaders such as Nelson Mandela be released from prison immediately and unconditionally so that they can participate in negotiations.

I just mention for the record some of the things about which honourable senators opposite might need reminding. Nelson Mandela was sentenced to life imprisonment with other African National Congress leaders in April 1964-22 years ago-after he was charged with sabotage. Although imprisoned, Mandela is still regarded as the symbolic leader of the black community and his release would be seen as a signal of the South African Government's genuine commitment to peaceful negotiations with genuinely representative black leaders.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is it true that certain Papua New Guinea members of parliament used the national development fund and the minor projects development fund as personal slush funds, as reported in the Canberra Times of 14 March? The article states:

QUESTION.PARA: Others used the fund for themselves, friends and family-in particular to buy motor vehicles.
In many cases, part of the money was used blatantly to buy food and beer for electioneering.

Was the Government aware of such abuses at the time of the signing of Australia's new long term aid arrangements with Papua New Guinea giving some $1,400m over five years commencing this year? How will the Government ensure that Australian taxpayers' contributions are not dissipated in this way?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure whether I am appropriately briefed on this matter. I will see what I can find out-not before the end of Question Time but tomorrow-and I will let Senator Hill know.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs whether she has seen the report in the Advertiser today headed `Aboriginal imprisonment numbers staggering', in which Professor Richard Harding, Director of the Australian Institute of Criminology, is quoted as saying:

QUESTION.PARA: Aboriginal people are the most imprisoned indigenous people in the world.

Is the Minister aware that, in one State, 10 per cent of Aboriginal males between the ages of 20 and 24 were in gaol at any one time? Is the Minister aware that these figures are 10 times greater than for Australia's population as a whole? Will the Minister say what steps the Government could take to address these appalling statistics and the appalling problem?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the situation described in the article from which Senator Crowley quoted. I am sure that the Minister whom I represent, Mr Holding, is also aware of the situation. Although it is very useful for the Institute of Criminology to bring these statistics to public notice on frequent occasions, it is not the first time that these statistics have been made public. In fact, I think they have been in the public domain for some years. It is a very distressing fact that Aboriginals appear to be the most imprisoned people in the world, as claimed in the article. I think the solutions to it have to be very long term and very careful. The kinds of policies which our Government has been implementing now for three years ought, in the longer term, to make some erosion into those dreadfully high statistics of Aboriginal imprisonment.

ANSWER.PARA: The reasons for Aboriginal imprisonment are associated with the extreme poverty in which most Aboriginal Australians live and the depression that accompanies that poverty when there seems to be no way out of it. It is certainly true that neglect in areas such as housing, income security, education, health and so forth has contributed over the years to the situation where Aboriginals are frequently law breakers although usually, I would say-Senator Crowley's question did not cover this-in fairly minor areas such as drunkenness, vagrancy where that offence still exists and crimes against property, such as young Aboriginals stealing cars and things of that kind. When it comes to serious crimes in our society I do not think that Aboriginals have a worse record than white Australia or any other part of Australia. But certainly in these crimes that seem to arise from a feeling of hopelessness and dispossession Aboriginals have extremely high imprisonment rates. From that it can be inferred that they have higher conviction rates than the rest of Australian society, although I think there has been some improvement since the development of Aboriginal legal services, which are able to give more careful and more committed assistance to Aboriginals who are arrested on these sorts of charges than the legal profession generally was able or prepared to give.

So the solutions to this terrible situation are not short term and they are complex. They involve an improvement in the basic living conditions of Aboriginal people, addressing problems such as inadequate shelter, inadequate income support and so on. They involve greatly improved health services, improved education and, in particular, the kind of self-respect that can come from the inclusion in the general curriculum of a positive approach to Aboriginal studies and Aboriginal culture and history. All these policies are being pursued and have been pursued by our Government for the last three years. There is also the fundamental question of secure possession of land. It is certainly the view of Aboriginal people that the question of self-respect, positive identity and aspirations for a better life are very much linked to secure possession of land. It is for that reason that our Government has pursued the achievement of secure possession of land by Aboriginals throughout Australia and has made some substantial progress in that respect. In conclusion, I do not think we will see any dramatic improvement in these statistics until we are able to assist Aboriginal people to solve the basic problems of poverty and powerlessness.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with my notice of intention given earlier today I now withdraw Business of the Senate, notice of motion No. 1 standing in my name, for disallowance of the First Home Owners Regulations (Amendment).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-During Question Time today Senator Gareth Evans answered a question about an alleged letter of mine that appeared in the Adelaide Press of 4 March. I will seek leave in a few moments to incorporate a copy of that letter in Hansard but I wanted to make four or five points in respect of it in summary. First of all, we were led to understand that that letter indicated my lack of concern about peace issues. I pointed out that I was sending the letter to State councillors to inform them that, because I would not be in Adelaide that day and taking part in the march, I would like to set down my own views on the matter. Secondly, there had never been any question in my mind that I would want to meet as many sincere people engaged in the peace movement as possible, and I made that quite clear. Thirdly, I expressed support for the Liberal Party's `Peace through Security' campaign, and in particular that part of the campaign run in South Australia by my colleague Senator Teague. The only problem raised in the letter was the question of the knowledge of those who were organising the campaign in South Australia, on which I have not yet received all information. Lastly, I wanted to express my view to State councillors in the Liberal Party that I believe the best way in which peace can be organised throughout this world and ensured for all Australians is through security, and in particular through our alliance with the United States. I seek leave to incorporate a copy of the letter in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
PARLIAMENT OF AUSTRALIA
THE SENATE
SENATOR THE HON. A. J. MESSNER
SHADOW MINISTER FOR FINANCE AND TAXATION
SENATOR FOR SOUTH AUSTRALIA
Commonwealth Parliament Offices
100 King William Street
Adelaide, S.A. 5000
26 February 1986
Parliament House
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
Dear State Councillor,

No doubt you would be aware of the call by Rob Hill and Rob Lucas for Liberals to join the Palm Sunday Peace March. Since I will not be in Adelaide that day due to commitments interstate, I would like to express my views on this.

I am only too pleased, at any time, to meet with sincere people interested in furthering world peace. It is an issue of vast consequence to us all. I fully support the Liberal Party's ``Peace through Security'' campaign, of which my colleague, Senator Baden Teague, is the South Australian coordinator.
However, I am concerned that I am called upon to involve myself in a March for Peace where the Liberal Party is not informed of the names and affiliations of its organisers.

I am not averse to identifying with people who are genuinely interested in promoting peace. Nevertheless, as a participant in any such activity, I reserve my right to put my view that the best vehicle in the search for world peace is the alliance with the United States.

I was surprised that a proposal such as that put forward by Rob Hill and Rob Lucas was not raised at the State Council meeting held only last Friday. Obviously, such a novel suggestion requires a considered Party decision. To advance in public the argument that ``we must identify with the youth vote'' as a reason to take part appears to me to be entirely counterproductive.
Our legitimate objective to promote ``Peace through Security'' may well be frustrated.
I hope these comments make my position clear.
With kind regards,
Yours sincerely,
TONY MESSNER

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Lewis proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The crippling effect of the Federal Government's policies on the rural industries of Australia.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The subject of this matter of public importance is:

SPEECH.PARA: The crippling effect of the Federal Government's policies on the rural industries of Australia.

Let me see whether I can encapsulate the argument in a nutshell. It comprises three fairly simple propositions that even Senator Button and Senator Walsh might be able to understand. The first is that this Government's industrial relations policy, the accord, has forced up wages, costs and inflation. The second is that this Government's taxation policies have lowered land values and thereby borrowing ability. The third is that this Government's economic policies have so forced up interest rates that those who still have a reasonable equity in their farm property cannot afford to borrow because they cannot afford to pay the interest.

Many thousands of primary producers throughout Australia cannot get the money to put in the crops to produce the income. That is it in a nutshell. Primary producers are being forced off the land while the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and his Ministers walk around like a bunch of fingerboard signposts, all pointing away from themselves saying that it is somebody else's responsibility and not theirs. That is the way they are operating. At present they are pointing towards the European Economic Community and saying that it is the EEC's fault and not the fault of the Government. The simple truth of the matter is that the farmers cannot get the finance to put in their crops to produce something they can sell.

TALK.START.PARA: —They can get it at 21 per cent.

—My colleague Senator Boswell says they can get it at 21 per cent, but they cannot afford to pay that much. I remind Senator Boswell that they can get it at 21 per cent only if they still have sufficient equity in their property. That is not the EEC's fault. It is this Government's fault. It is Senator Walsh's fault. I see that his Leader, Senator Button, has just left, but it is his fault too. Senator Walsh is in the Cabinet and it is his fault. He is one of the people who make these decisions and who have decided the Government's economic policy. Indeed, today Senator Button in answer to a question admitted that the Government had a tight monetary policy. That tight monetary policy is keeping up interest rates and creating this great problem for the farmers. The Government is not prepared to give them the full value of the fall in fuel prices. The Government will not even allow them to take advantage of the falling value of the dollar. So not even that has been of any real value to the primary producers. All this has come from a Prime Minister who, in 1984 in his rural speech said:

SPEECH.PARA: The special needs of rural people will have a high priority . . .

They will have a high priority all right! What has this Government done for the people of Australia? What the Government did was to acknowledge in that speech that a one per cent drop in interest rates meant a cut of $35m in farmers' interest rate bills. One can see what the Prime Minister was doing. He was going around the countryside saying to primary producers: `Your needs will have a high priority with us and we recognise that a one per cent drop in interest rates will mean a $35m cut in farmers' bills'. That was implying that somehow or other there would be a cut in interest rates. What happened? Under this Government's policy, implemented I have no doubt by Senator Walsh as strictly as he possible can, interest rates have increased by a massive 7.5 percentage points to an almost out of the world interest rate of 21 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is 21.5 per cent.

—It is 21.5 per cent, as my colleague Senator Boswell reminds me. It is out of this world and by Mr Hawke's own calculations that increase in interest rates added an interest bill of $262.5m for primary producers.

SPEECH.PARA: I give the Senate a practical example. The people of Woomelang, a little town in north-west Victoria with a population of about 300 people, recently got together to prepare a submission to the Victorian rural economic study currently being conducted by a Dr Lloyd. Their submission was a community effort. In common with most country towns around Australia, when the farmers are in trouble everyone wants to help. In that community effort the farmers were joined by councillors, bankers and small businessmen of the town and they put a submission to Dr Lloyd's study. What did they say? Let me quote:
We have an economic crisis on our hands . . . We have a social disaster on our hands . . . We have no future farmers.

These people are not whingers. They are desperate. This Government fails to understand this point. The Bureau of Agricultural Economics recently in its quarterly review made it perfectly clear why farmers are in trouble when it said that the high interest rates are due to the Government's tight monetary policy. I said earlier that Senator Button implied in an answer to a question today that the Government will continue with its tight monetary policy. It is trying to hold up the value of the dollar with high interest rates. How is that helping the farmers of this nation-holding up the value of the dollar? Apart from keeping up the high interest rates, how is that helping the farmers? That in itself proves my point: The crippling effect of the Government's policies on the rural industries of Australia.

There was then the 1986 Outlook Conference of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics. I digress to draw Senator Walsh's attention-and I hope that he passes this on to his Minister-that at that Conference not one representative of the Coles or Woolworths organisations was invited to come along to listen to or talk with farmers. Those organisations through their supermarkets are the largest retailers of meat in Australia, but not one was invited to come to the Conference. The 1986 Conference warned of a tough couple of years ahead. Key points were that there would be a 66 per cent fall in average farm income to $6,700 a year. There would be 35 per cent of all farms and more than 50 per cent of grain farms with negative incomes for this year. There would be an annual average income per farm person of $3,800, a return to capital of minus 6 per cent and a rise in overall rural debt to $8,000m by June this year. In other words, $8 billion would be the rural debt by June of this year. `A couple of tough years', the Conference was told. A couple more years like that and farmers will be dropping like flies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think the Government cares?

—Of course it does not care. Just look around the Senate now. Where are all the Labor senators? There is not one of them here, except Senator Walsh who will be the next speaker. There is not one Labor member in the chamber prepared to listen to this debate. They knew they would get a thumping on the subject. They got up and ran out of the chamber because they did not want to hear what I had to say about primary producers. They could not get out of the chamber quickly enough. Not one of them has the guts to come back and sit and listen to this debate.
—They do not care about farmers.

—Of course they do not care about farmers. I understand that in the Bulletin today it is said that the farmers are not relevant to the Labor Party Government. Apparently that is in an article in the Bulletin today. That is the Labor Party's attitude right around Australia and, in particular, in this chamber. It is not interested in primary producers. At that Outlook conference, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics predicted an increase in the rate at which farmers will be forced to quit farming. It had a survey which showed that about 7 per cent of Australian farms-that is, 12,000 enterprises-are now `at risk owing to the heavy debt burden'.
—Family farms.

—Family farms; some 12,000 enterprises estimated by the BAE as being at risk. How many people does that involve, in these 12,000 enterprises? These people will walk off their farms, or they will need some sort of debt rescheduling, or they will need some other source of income. Under this Government's stupid quarantining proposals-to which I shall come shortly, and no doubt Senator Walsh will respond to me-these people will have difficulty in seeking adequate off-farm income to support themselves and to keep themselves on their properties. These people are not seeking the dole. Farmers around Australia have always been prepared to go out and work hard for their living. They are being faced with a terrible situation. This Government is not prepared to do anything for them. Let me mention Professor Lloyd, who is conducting an inquiry in Victoria.
—He is a friend of mine.
—He is apparently a friend of Senator Walsh.
—I did not think that Senator Walsh had any friends.

—It will be interesting to see what Professor Lloyd has to say. I agree with Senator Boswell; I did not think that Senator Walsh had any friends. However, apparently Professor Lloyd has warned that up to 10 per cent of farmers-and their families, of course-might have to leave the land because of the crisis. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I don't mind using the word `crisis'. It is a common thing in Australian agriculture. Farmers have to get used to crisis as a way of life.

What a terrible thing it is, in a country such as Australia, that farmers have to get used to crisis as a way of life. Glory be! Is that what has happened to this country, this land of plenty, this land with all the capacity and ability to grow all the crops, grass and vegetables and produce all the meat? Are we really serious when we say that farmers will have to get used to crisis as a way of life?

Senator Boswell will talk about the budgetary attacks on the rural sector. However, let me just say that since the ALP came to government, over 40 benefits have been removed from, or adverse budgetary decisions have been made to the detriment of, the rural sector. This Government, in the three years in which it has been in office, has made over 40 decisions against the farmers. But Senator Boswell will cover that matter; let me return to the economy.

One of the things I find very worrying is that there appears to be a conflict of economic statistics. When I talk to people about our worries and the massive debt burden that this Government is forcing upon this country, they say: `Oh yes, but there are statistics which show that this is happening and that is happening, and is that not good?' The example which came to my mind when I was thinking of trying to explain this was to say that if a family were to borrow, say, $100,000, that family could substantially improve the appearance of their life-style. With $100,000 a family might be able to extend their house, to install a swimming pool, to buy a new car, and do all those sorts of things. Looking at them on the surface, one would think that that family was doing very well. But of course, they still must find the interest to meet the debt. If they have a falling income, although things might look prosperous that family could be in dire trouble. Is that not the state of Australia at present? We have falling income on the world market; yet this Government continues with its deficit budgeting long past the hour of need. There was a need in 1982 for deficit budgeting. There might even have been a need for that in 1983, for some lower deficit budgeting. That is not so any longer. But this Government continues to budget for a massive deficit with a massive increase in debt burden to be paid all the time, while our overseas income is falling desperately.

That is one of the problems that this country is looking at now: Where will we go? In the meantime, this Government continues with its industrial relations policy, its accord, to increase people's wages. When the country is facing this terrible problem, this Government goes on increasing people's wages. The result is that some people who happen to be on two incomes-probably two government-paid incomes-are in very strong financial positions, in which they can afford to buy expensive imports, such as motor cars and other expensive imported goods, and that is the main reason why the J curve will not bottom out. It is because the Government keeps maintaining the income of the wage earners of Australia. They can keep buying expensive imports, and the J curve will not reach its bottom; it will keep diving down until disaster comes to this community.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an I curve.

—Yes, it is not a J curve but an I curve. Who carries the can for this? It is the exporters, of course, I include among them the miners, but, in particular, exporters include our primary producers. Wages, costs and inflation continue to rise under the accord, to the detriment of those people on the land and in our rural towns.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at some of this Government's taxation policies. It has removed the investment allowance on plant. It has increased the taxes of those people who had some income. It has introduced a capital gains tax. Glory be! What has that done to the equity of people on the land? A capital gains tax has brought about a fall in the value of rural properties and it is that fall that squeezes the equity that farmers have which might enable them to borrow extra funds from bankers and other financiers. Senator Walsh, in particular, certainly does not seem to grasp that point, because we got to the question of quarantining farm losses. The ALP and, in particular, Senator Walsh seem to have a philosophical obsession about Collins Street and Pitt Street farmers. Senator Walsh has been talking for years about their rorts. The result of the legislation that he is proposing to introduce with regard to quarantining farm losses has ignored the consequences for those working on the land, those who seek off-farm income to counter their losses, and the Government has now had to modify its proposal because of those people. But it also ignores the fact that those Collins Street and Pitt Street farmers are innovative and productive, because they go into this business to make a profit. They have introduced new ideas, new capital and new income for the whole of the districts into which they have gone. They have been of enormous value in bringing our farms and farming operations in Australia into this century. Many of them have done wonders in the areas in which they have invested. This Government is forcing them to withdraw from investing in rural properties. The result of that has been falling land prices where such people are no longer coming into the investment areas, reduced revenue for those farmers who can obtain off-farm income by working these properties, and the falling land prices, which are, as I say, reducing the equity in farm properties. When the equity is reduced, so is the borrowing potential.

I seek leave, Madam Acting Deputy President, to have incorporated in Hansard a copy of a letter from the Livestock and Grain Producers Association of NSW to Senator Walsh dated 27 February 1986 and one to me dated 4 March 1986.
Leave granted.
The letters read as follows-
THE LIVESTOCK AND GRAIN PRODUCERS' ASSOCIATION OF NEW SOUTH WALES
Telex: AA26638
Telephone: (02) 27 9031
Telegrams: RURAL Sydney
27 February 1986
56 Young Street, Sydney 2000
Box 1068 G.P.O. Sydney, N.S.W. 2001
Senator The Hon. P. A. Walsh,
Minister for Finance,
Parliament House,
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
Dear Senator Walsh
PROPOSED QUARANTINING OF FARM LOSSES

Thank you very much for your letter of 13 February seeking clarification of the apparent anomaly between the BAE's low farm income estimates and likely high incidence of damage from proposed tax quarantining measures.

There are some very good reasons for believing that a large number of farmers will be hurt by the tax quarantining proposals put forward by your government. As we have pointed out to Mr Kerin on previous occasions, the BAE's survey figures do not provide an adequate base for assessing the impact of tax quarantining.
The reasons for this are as follows:
The BAE estimate of off-farm earnings is known to exclude earnings on investments held by farm family members in their own name and not in the farm business name.

The BAE's estimates of family farm income are based on a sub sample of the total farm population in Australia, and includes only those farmers which can readily be identified as being family owned and operated. In other words, company owned and other enterprise-based farms are excluded and these are precisely the operations which will be most affected by the proposed quarantining arrangements.

The BAE's survey eligibility criteria also require a $10,000 level of agricultural activity. It is likely therefore that properties which are currently going through the development phase and which may be affected by the quarantining proposal would not show up in the Bureau's survey results.
In brief, the BAE measures of farm income are designed as indicators of farm business performance and are inadequate for assessment of off-farm earnings.

We do not, as you allege, see the BAE figures as `decisive evidence' of the need for general assistance to agriculture. Rather, we use these figures to demonstrate the damaging effect that the policies of successive Governments have had on farm sector profitability. What we seek is to have a range of unnecessary cost imposts removed to allow agriculture to compete on world markets.

Where welfare-related problems do exist in agriculture, we have sought to have these addressed through the appropriate mechanisms of the Rural Adjustment Scheme or alternative assistance arrangements. You should be aware that applications for assistance under these schemes are dealt with on a case by case basis and appropriations made accordingly.

However, while it is acknowledged that the BAE survey figures probably underestimate the level of total income available to farm households, one cannot ignore the dramatic change in incomes they indicate for the current year. In my public comments on this matter, I have repeatedly referred to the deterioration in farm returns that has taken place over the past two seasons and I believe that no-one could challenge the validity of this statement.
I remain concerned that neither you nor Mr Kerin appear at all interested in the genuine expressions of worry that are coming from all sections of the community your Government's tax proposals.

The Government has also produced certain figures, presumably obtained from the tax office, that indicate that very few farmers would be affected. It seems that the only information that could be available to the Government would be from farmers' income tax returns lodged in recent years where a split between non farm income and farm income was necessary under the existing laws to determine the amount of average rebate that the taxpayer might receive.

Such information from the tax office could be very misleading. Many farming businesses have been trading at a loss for some time. Many of those businesses have off farm income but because the total business trades at a loss it is not necessary to split the income of that taxpayer between off farm income and farm income. This is because there is no net income or no taxable income. Discussions with numerous accountants indicate that there are many taxpayers in this position.
The downturn in rural income has made more and more genuine primary producers even more dependent on off farm income for survival.

With interest rates presently at record levels causing severe hardship to farmers, many are forced to supplement their income with off farm activities. Under the tax quarantining proposals, once the off farm income rises above $20,000 per annum, no further amount can be used as an offset against farm losses without being fully taxable. At present $20,000 would barely meet the interest payment on a $100,000 loan (necessary for the purchase of, say, a grain harvester costing approximately $150,000). An Allis Chalmers N7 or Claas 116 or John Deere 8820 grain harvester has a charge out rate of approximately $160 per hour. A John Deere 7720 has a chargeout rate of about $120 per hour. Hence, the $20,000 threshold can be attained in a matter of ten (10) to fourteen (14) days.

A genuine farmer who spends $20,000 to have a contractor to shear his sheep, then uses his own harvesting equipment to earn, say $40,000 (in keeping with normal farm operation) cannot offset the income from one operation against the cost of the other.
BHP, on the other hand, can offset their steel losses against their oil income.

Genuine farmers who have sought to diversify their investments, or alternatively sought to utilise their equipment in an economic manner will thus be severely penalised. Moreover, the greater the need for off-farm income, the harder the primary producer will be hit.

The farm loss quarantining proposal will allow an amount equal to previous five (5) years net farm income to be the amount against which off-farm income can be offset. It should be noted that young farmers with high borrowings to equity ratios, and who would have little or no previous income history to offset against, will be among that group who will be hardest hit.

The quarantining proposal is the only tax proposal which will have an effect on business arrangements already entered into. Such retrospectivity does not apply to the negative gearing legislation on housing investment where interest costs for arrangements entered into before 19th September 1985 will still be allowed to be offset against income generated by other than residence investment in later years.
I must convey to you that the farm loss tax quarantining proposal is seen by the membership of this Association as selective and discriminatory.

The implementation of the proposal will have (and to a degree already has had) the effect of removing from the farming industry the urban-based farmer. It appears that the Government sees this as desirable. Mr Kerin's view is that future `rationalisation' of the farm sector will be predicated on lower farmland prices and it is evident that your Government is doing everything in its power to push farm prices down. If you took the time to check the facts, you would find that the efficiency gains which have been achieved in Australian farming in recent decades have been the result of capital-labour-land substitution process. Through high interest rates and anti-investment taxation proposals, your Government will choke off capital formation in agriculture and commit it to a future of inefficiency. Your government's drive to push down farm land prices will do little more than strip the asset value of agriculture's balance sheet and make lenders even less interested in agriculture as a venue for investment.

Many urban-based farmers inject large amounts of money into improving their farms. Most of these funds go to rural towns, many of which have high and potentially higher unemployment levels relative to other sectors in the nation. I have no hesitation in saying that the proposed tax package proposals of Capital Gains Tax, employee housing tax and the farm loss quarantining proposals are offensive against rural Australia.

I also refer your attention to the experience in New Zealand where similar legislation, having been introduced in 1982, was repealed in December 1985. It was repealed because it was preventing any development of new agricultural industries so essential to gain extra export earnings for New Zealand (e.g. Kiwi Fruit, and venison exports).
The same would have applied in Australia if these laws had been in place 15-20 years ago. There would now be no cotton industry presently earning Australia $300 million in production.

I suggest that with the reduction of agricultural returns to farmers occurring worldwide, productivity will depend critically on outsiders being prepared to invest in Australian agriculture. If your Government is to see any reduction in the current account deficit now running at over $1,000 million monthly, farm sector investment and productivity must be encouraged.
I have taken the opportunity of forwarding a copy of this letter to all Senators and other decision-makers in the expectation that the critical issues will be addressed.
There will need to be a continuing restructuring in agriculture, due to the low level of net returns.

Impediments or uncertainties in the market place will slow down and make more difficult and more costly the smooth progress towards the improved productivity of the agricultural sector that is so vital to the export earnings of this nation.
Yours sincerely,
MICHAEL TOOTH
President
THE LIVESTOCK AND GRAIN PRODUCERS' ASSOCIATION OF NEW SOUTH WALES
Telex: AA26638
Telephone: (02) 27-9031
Telegrams: `RURAL' Sydney
4 March 1986
56 Young Street, Sydney 2000
Box 1068 G.P.O Sydney, N.S.W. 2001
Senator A. W. R. Lewis,
Parliament House,
Canberra, A.C.T., 2600
Dear Senator Lewis,
RE: QUARANTINING OF FARM LOSSES
Please find enclosed a response to Senator Walsh's comments of the 13th February, 1986, contained in the Hansard reports, Parliament, for this date.

The Association considers this issue of primary importance considering the current massive downturn in farm incomes which has been forecast by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics. The Association welcomes the opportunity to respond to any Senator who may have some difficulty in understanding the ramifications of the Government's proposed action.
Naturally the Association would welcome any opportunity to clarify with you any questions you may have with respect to these taxation measures.

Following Senator Walsh's public comments on the contents of our previous letter on this issue, and the obvious publicity that his response has been given, we have taken the opportunity to publicly respond to the good Senator's obvious misunderstanding of the ramifications of these proposals.
