Our Association is deeply concerned that rural debt is in excess of $7 billion and that agriculture is facing its most difficult period. Accordingly we believe that now is not the time to place unreasonable burdens on the rural sector's productive capacity.
Yours sincerely,
MICHAEL TOOTH
President

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Senator Walsh castigated the writer of these letters, the President of the Association, Mr Michael Tooth, at Question Time today because the Association is saying that the Collins Street farmers and the Pitt Street farmers are important to Australia's rural industry. Of course they are important to it. But in fact, this quarantining proposal is the only tax proposal that I know which will have an effect on business arrangements already entered into. In that regard I refer Senator Walsh to the quarantining proposals which will cripple the private forestry industry. At a time when we are in need of timber and forestry, this Government is introducing legislation which will, in effect, cripple that industry. This Government's industrial relations and taxation policies have had, and continue to have, an absolutely crippling effect on the rural industries of Australia. This means that many thousands of people out there in the community, on farms and in rural towns and cities, are being hurt, and hurt badly. This Government, and this Prime Minister in particular, should be ashamed of the fact that their policies have put primary producers in Australia into this dire position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lewis is the shadow spokesman on the Australian Capital Territory. When I received his letter I wondered why he was leading the debate for the Opposition on an agricultural matter. Having listened to him, I now realise why. He represents the Murrumbateman hobby farmers. He represents the senior public servants and academics who have hobby farms at Murrumbateman and in parts of the Australian Capital Territory and who have been major beneficiaries of the pre-existing taxation arrangements which enabled people to offset so-called farm losses against income earned from other sources. Those provisions, which this Government has now ended, enabled the Murrumbateman hobby farmers, whom Senator Lewis represents, to indulge themselves in a lifestyle which suited them, very substantially at public expense through taxation concessions.
—Whom do you represent?

—We know whom Senator Crichton-Browne represents. He represents the insider traders on the stock exchange, people such as his wife who worked in the office of the consulting geologists, Burrell and Jones, who were working for Poseidon.
—Whom do you represent?
—Order, Senator Crichton-Browne!
—In that capacity she had access to the assay--
—I take a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. Could you ask Senator Crichton-Browne to lower his voice a little?
—There is no point of order. I have already called him to order.
—As I was saying, we all know whom Senator Crichton-Browne represents. He represents those who were insider traders in Poseidon shares back in 1969 and 1970, principally his wife--
—No; whom do you represent?
—Principally his wife--

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. I remind you of the terms of the matter of public importance that is being debated today. What Senator Walsh has said so far, notwithstanding the fact that it is totally dishonest and totally irrelevant, is unrelated in any way, shape or form to the set of words which he intends, purportedly, to debate. I ask you to draw his attention to the fact that he ought to be directing his remarks to the debate and not making spurious allegations which are quite untrue and unfounded.
—I ask Senator Walsh to keep to the subject of the matter of public importance.
—Certainly, Madam Acting Deputy President. I can understand why Senator Crichton-Browne does not want me to divulge the rest of the sordid details of his and his wife's activities.

—I take a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. We will have to ask Senator Walsh to stick to the point of the debate. He is simply maligning an honourable senator unfairly and untruthfully. He is doing it over the top of the interjections which are going on, into the microphone and into Hansard. I think he ought to be required to withdraw.
—I ask Senator Walsh to keep to the subject of the matter of public importance and not to make imputations against honourable senators.

—Certainly, Madam Acting Deputy President. I was, however, asked a question by way of interjection: Whom do you represent? I represent, among other people, farmers. I was a practising wheat farmer for 25 years. I was actually a manual worker. The thing that sets me apart from members of the Liberal Party of Australia-I would suggest, from almost everybody in the Liberal Party now that John Hyde has lost his seat in the Parliament-is that I actually know something about farming and I also know something about economics.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Lewis said that there were three points in this debate. The first point was that the Labor Government's prices and incomes accord had caused a wages explosion, a costs explosion and an inflation explosion and that that was the cause of the present farm income problems. There are recurring cycles of farm income problems. Let us compare this Government's wages, costs and inflation record with that of its predecessor, particularly as Senator Lewis chose to blame the accord for what he asserts is a blowout in all of these areas. Because of the accord the rate of inflation has been halved from that which we inherited. The rate of wages growth has been halved from that which we inherited. The rate of farm costs also has been approximately halved. It is currently lower than it was for almost every year the Fraser Government was in office.

Senator Lewis said that the tax policies of this Government have lowered land prices, thereby lowering equities and the ability to borrow. Given Senator Lewis's ignorance of actual agricultural practice, it is not surprising that he should reach that conclusion. What determines whether lending institutions will lend money to farmers is not so much their equity as their capacity, through their income flow, to service the loan commitments which they may or may not be able to undertake. Senator Lewis referred to interest rates. Certainly, interest rates are higher than this Government would like to see them. They are higher than any sensible person would like to see them. They are not, however, as high as they were in April 1982, when Mr Howard was Treasurer, and they are falling.

Presumably, one wants to have a rational discussion about this matter. The Bureau of Agricultural Economics figures Senator Lewis cited were, so far as I could tell, accurate. However, one should be very careful in using BAE figures and qualify them very carefully because the particular definitions and qualifications attached to them are laid down by the BAE and are not commonly understood. For example, Senator Lewis referred to the alleged negative income of wheat farmers. As I recall, the forecast income for 1986-87 of the BAE Outlook Conference is that `wheat growers' incomes would be negative to the extent of about $5,000'. That does not represent cash flow, because an imputed allowance is made in determining that final figure, for the depreciation of farm plant and equipment. For wheat farmers that is $27,000. So, what the BAE defines as farm income is not cash flow and does not give a picture that is at all reliable of the amount of money which farmers have available. Apart from an imputed figure being written in for plant depreciation, which I have mentioned, BAE estimates do not measure off-farm income. According to a letter from the New South Wales Livestock and Grain Producers Association, which apparently has the endorsement of Senator Lewis, most farmers have off-farm incomes in excess of $20,000. That is not a figure that I believe, but it is a figure which has been asserted and which, apparently, Senator Lewis believes.

Senator Lewis referred to 40 alleged `benefits' which have been withdrawn by this Government and said that Senator Boswell would enumerate them. He specifically mentioned investment allowance, capital gains tax and so on. One of the reasons why farmers have got themselves into financial trouble-not just now, but periodically, cyclically, over time-is that they have been seduced by politicians, such as Senator Lewis and more particularly those of the National Party of Australia, who have sold them a string of what they call `benefits' which do long term damage not only to agriculture but also to the people who are involved in it. I quote from a speech delivered in Perth in 1979 by the present Secretary to the Department of Primary Industry when he was Director of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics. On this very subject of tax concessions he said:

Tax concessions result in excessive entry into agriculture for the specific purpose of receiving the economic reward associated with the concession. Rural land values and the costs of other limited resources such as livestock and credit, are inflated by this process.
Inflated asset values slow down the rate of adjustment and productivity growth in agriculture and distort the relationship between capital values and current income.
Although individuals may benefit, the benefits of tax concessions to rural industries as a whole are likely to be negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—Geoff Miller, at the time Director of the BAE and now Secretary to the Department of Primary Industry. I suggest that honourable senators read that speech and the views of other rational agricultural economists, who all come to the same sort of conclusion-a conclusion that I have no doubt Professor Lloyd will come to in the inquiry to which Senator Lewis has referred. On the question of credit, Mr Miller said at that time:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Bureau is of the firm view that the widespread availability of concessional credit to farmers is not in the long-term interests of agriculture or of the economy as a whole.

Senator Lewis deplores the fact that land prices are falling. What really ought to be deplored is the fact that land prices in recent years, particularly the late 1970s and the early 1980s, rose to unsustainably high levels because it is to that fact that the present financial problems of a great number of farmers can be directly traced-that is, the existence of tax shelters of the type that Senator Lewis wants to perpetuate or resurrect. The absence of a capital gains tax encouraged outside capital into agriculture, not for the purposes of the profits that could be earned in agriculture but, as Mr Miller said at the time, for the specific purpose of receiving the economic reward associated with the concession.

Land prices were grossly inflated, principally by the tax shelter and the absence of a capital gains tax, to unsustainably high levels. Farmers who purchased land in the late 1970s and the early 1980s form an extremely high proportion of those who are currently in financial difficulties. Their problems can be directly traced to the taxation induced distortion of land prices which this Government ended and which Senator Lewis wants to resurrect. The simple fact, as an increasing number of farmers are beginning to realise, is that because the cost-price squeeze in agriculture has existed for almost all of the last 100 years in the long term only the more economically literate farmers will survive as farmers. Because of that process of natural selection, an increasing number of farmers are beginning to realise that, if they are going to remain in farming, they have to acquire more land because changing technology and technological progress extend the point at which economies of scale either flatten out or become negative. In other words, there are powerful economic and technological forces-forces which have this tendency to increase farm sizes. It follows inescapably from that that those people by and large who want to remain farmers will have to acquire more land. It ought to be obvious, even to a National Party member for Maranoa or even a Queensland senator, that cheaper land is a good thing for those people who have to acquire it. Dearer land may be a good thing for the sellers and the speculators but for those farmers who actually want to remain farmers their best interests are served if land prices are lower rather than higher.

Let me move away from the question of the effect of taxation distortions on land prices but remain in the area of taxation and tax concessions, particularly since Senator Lewis specifically mentioned the abolition of investment allowances. Anybody who has any knowledge in depth at all of Australian agriculture, particularly of the Australian wheat industry, which along with sugar and dairying is probably the most severely affected by the present income problem, knows that there is chronic gross overinvestment in plant and equipment. That overinvestment was encouraged by mountebanks and mountebank politicians who tell farmers that they are helping them by providing taxation concessions for them-taxation concessions which induce them, in an attempt to minimise taxation, rather than more rationally attempting to maximise income, to grossly overinvest in plant and equipment. I note again that there is evidence that the farmers who have some comprehension of economics and some ability to think rationally-that is, those who are surviving and growing-not only realise it, but are increasingly talking about it. I refer honourable senators to an article which appeared on page 3 of the West Australian on 15 March 1986 which quotes a very successful farmer from Goomalling, which is near Northam in Western Australia-a very successful wheat and sheep farmer, Mr Roy Clarke. It states:
Many problems being experienced by WA farmers are due to mismanagement, according to prominent Goomalling producer Roy Clarke
The article goes on to say:
Mr Clarke estimates that he and his four farming sons have saved $1m in the past 10 years by buying secondhand machinery then modifying and repairing it in their farm workshop.
I seek leave to incorporate that article in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The article read as follows-
Many problems being experienced by WA farmers are due to mismanagement, according to prominent Goomalling producer Roy Clarke.
He said that they had not done their homework and had sought to `keep up with the Joneses'.
Mr Clarke said that the purchase of new costly equipment was often beyond their resources.
Producers had been attracted by benefits such as taxation advantages without calculating the ultimate interest costs involved.
`I would love to own a new tractor, but it is not on in the present climate, nor has it been for some years,' he said.
Mr Clarke estimates that he and his four farming sons have saved $1 million in the past 10 years by buying second-hand machinery then modifying and repairing it in their farm workshop.
They have used machinery with an average age of 20 years, backed by a rigid maintenance programme.
The savings were put into land expansions.
`I know my comments will not make me popular with many of my farmer mates or machinery dealers,' he said.
`But I believe they must be said in this time of rural crisis'.
`Making money is what it is all about.'
Mr Clarke (56), brother of legendary East Fremantle and WA ruckman Jack, has been a farmer all his life and is also a director of Co-operative Bulk Handling Ltd.
He said that older plant and equipment was simply built and so relatively easy to maintain.
`Sure, the finger-tip control with everything that opens and shuts on modern tractors and headers is magnificent,' he said.
`But who can afford them?'
`We took a rubbishing for years in using old gear. Now people are coming to have a hard look at what we are doing to try and stay in business.'

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest that anybody in the Liberal Party who is seriously interested in the agricultural problem as distinct from attempting to score a few cheap political points and ingratiating themselves with what they see as their constituency through flogging off bottles of snake oil to them make a serious study of that article and the implications behind it. Agriculture is presently going through a cyclical slump which albeit has been seriously exacerbated for a number of producers by purchases of land at excessive prices and by gross overinvestment in plant and equipment. On the latter point, I refer to a paper which was given at a seminar held in Perth on 28 August last year sponsored by an organisation called the Kondinin and Districts Farm Improvement Group and the Primary Industry Association of Western Australia (Inc.). The theme was `Farm Costs-The Facts'. A Mr Peter Falconer of Planfarm Rural Consultants-a farm management consultant with a long-standing clientele in the Wongan Hills area-made the point, and this is derived from actual average figures from the Planfarm firm's clients in that Wongan Hills district:

SPEECH.PARA: The tractor investment on our own client's farms range from $10 per ha of crop to $135 per ha of crop and an examination of all the figures shows no relationship between tractor investment and yield.

To convert that into something more meaningful-they are not hypothetical farms; it is an actual arithmetic mean of real farms-the average area in crop was of the order of 1,200 hectares. In other words, on the arithmetic mean farm the investment in tractors alone varied from $12,000 to $162,000, a difference of $150,000, and bear in mind, as Mr Falconer said, there was no relationship between tractor investment and yield. From the highest to the lowest, with no correlation with any index of efficiency or performance, there was a difference in investment of $150,000 in tractors alone. At interest rates of 17 per cent, that gives an interest cost, without allowing for depreciation, of $25,000. In other words, if the farmers in that particular group had all made the sorts of adjustments that Mr Clarke made-that is, minimised their plant capitalisation-they would have saved, at 17 per cent interest rates, in interest costs alone, some $25,500, which just happens to equal the total fuel bill on average for that same group of farms in 1985 and which would be well above the fuel bill that they will be paying at the lower prices in 1986.

Politicians who get involved in debates on agricultural issues have basically two choices-or at least this has been true in the past. They can say what is true, which is something I have always tried to do, or they can say what is popular, which is something that most members of the Liberal Party-I exclude people such as Mr Hyde, who unfortunately, of all the Liberals who have been removed from this Parliament, was about the last one who should have been-and virtually all members of the National Party do. That is the sort of choice that we face. The people who are actually friends of the farmers in the long term are those who tell them the truth.

TALK.START.PARA: —They love you.

—I have already conceded that it does not bring popularity in the short term. I warn all those mountebanks and snake oil salesmen opposite that the level of awareness among farmers, particularly in the southern States of Australia, is increasing. They are beginning to recognise the snake oil when it is presented to them. By no means are they a majority, but an increasing minority, and they are the minority who will survive because they have a capacity to think rationally and have some understanding of the underlying economic questions.
—But how does that help the farmers who cannot afford even to put in a crop this year?

—For many of the people who are already in deep trouble, partly because of cyclical factors and more often because of investment decisions which were unwise, both in plant and equipment, nothing really can be done, but by continuing to follow rational policies instead of buying the snake oil remedies being offered across the corridor we can at least reduce the chances that the same number of people will be caught in the same sorts of circumstances next time the cyclical downturn hits.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing a matter of public importance:

SPEECH.PARA: The crippling effect of the Federal Government's policies on the rural industries of Australia.

There can be absolutely no doubt that the difficulties confronting farmers in Australia at present have given rise to a rural crisis of major significance. Farmers are battling against high interest rates, harsh market conditions and poor performance from both the current Government and the previous Liberal-National Party governments in relation to enactments affecting the well-being of the rural sector. The strength of the current protest from farmers is indicative of the enormity of the problem that they are facing. The Australian Democrats recognise that the strength and dynamism of our agricultural products have provided the foundation stone for Australia's economic base over a long time. Notwithstanding, we have seen people on the land assume more and more the brunt of the problem, under successive Liberal-National Party governments and the Labor Government.

The Democrats believe that the downturn in the rural economy can and must be reversed. It can be reversed by the adoption of clear-sighted and clear-headed policies. I will go through some of the policies that the Government has been involved in. It makes a rather interesting and telling list. For example, the Government has imposed a 10 per cent wine tax with the support of the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia and against the vote of the Australian Democrats. It has failed to honour fully its wool promotion pledges. It has effectively destroyed the tax averaging provisions and the income equalisation deposit scheme, again with the support of the Liberal and National parties. The Government has failed to do anything about the add-on cost, that is the freight cost, on sales tax. We had discussions with the Liberal-National Party Government. It too refused to do anything about that iniquitous freight add-on cost. The Government failed to maintain drought relief levels, or even to look at the introduction of its promised special drought scheme for country towns and rural people. We have seen neither hide nor hair of that since it was discussed in 1983.

The Government has failed often to consult rural people and various industry groups regarding legislation that comes into this place. It has substantially increased the burden on the meat export industry, again with the support of the Liberal and National parties. It has failed to maintain support for the citrus industry and to carry out the promise made in 1983 and again in the 1984 election regarding the fishing industry. As I have said before, it has failed to reform the various agricultural training and farm-based programs that were discussed during both those election campaigns. It has failed to act on a situation that the industries were moving towards-developing a national horticultural insurance scheme. It did not carry through its promise to set up an Australian fruits corporation. Of course, funds in the Budget last year to the rural adjustment scheme were cut by $10m for this year. As I have already outlined, the Government has been able to achieve most of these results with the support of the Liberal and National parties.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish! You mean that we did not reject its Budget Bills.

—They were not Budget Bills. It is interesting to see a change of tune since the last time those opposite knocked back a money Bill. I will look at some of the issues raised by us. They include: The Democrats' successful moves regarding a delay for the dairy industry; preventing the introduction of export inspection charges on honey, canned and frozen fruit and vegetables; the successful delay to the Live-stock Slaughter (Export Inspection Charge) Validation Bill; persuading the Government not to take away the grower majority on the Australian Wheat Board, despite the fact that the Liberal Party spokesperson in the House of Representatives had conceded that issue when discussing the Bill to adjust the Australian wheat industry. Each of those items gives a fairly clear indication that there is often a lot of rhetoric but, unfortunately, not much follow through on such items.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the major problems that we are facing is not so much the efficiency of our industry. Indeed, in the major commodity areas our industries are amongst the most efficient, if not the most efficient, in the world. That is not a problem. One of the major problems that for some reason many people in the rural sector have said that they do not want to hear about but that they really have to come to grips with is that, no matter how efficiently we manage to produce our rural exports, if we do not have markets there is absolutely no way in the world that we will be able to sustain the farming sector. Those markets are absolutely vital. Australia has not had a domestic market large enough to consume what it has produced since about the first 40 or 50 years of white colonisation. We need markets around the world to sustain the levels of agricultural activity that we have known in the past 20 or 30 years.

I suggest that it is absolutely pointless for people to write letters, as they do to me, saying: `Don't tell me about the problems with those markets'. I reiterate the point that I made last year when I spoke at the Council of Europe on this matter. Let us look at the European Community alone-that is, not at the problems currently facing us with regard to the United States farm Bill-and look at our major commodity areas. If the common agricultural policy's open-ended support did not exist, we would be able to and would be selling $200m worth more meat, $100m worth more in coarse grains, $220m worth more in beef and veal, $40m worth more in sheepmeat, $115m worth more in dairy produce and $80m worth more in sugar.

In all, the increased competition from subsidised European commodity exports on third markets, the reduction of world market prices and lost markets in Europe have cost the Australian economy, in 1984-85 terms, an estimated $1,000m a year. We have to face that. We have to face the fact that the European Economic Community has gone from a net importer in most of those major areas to a net exporter. For example, between 1972 and 1982 Australian beef and veal exports to the European Economic Community fell by 80 per cent. Butter exports fell by 97.3 per cent and apple and pear exports fell by 88 per cent. The list goes on. It is no good turning our back on that situation. The corruption of world agricultural markets by the European Community, and subsequently now by the United States, means that no matter how efficient Australian producers are we will not be able to sell our produce. Therefore it is vitally important that the Prime Minister's impending visit to the United States and to the European Economic Community provide him with another opportunity to lobby on behalf of Australian farmers threatened by those protectionist measures in Europe and the United States.

On almost every occasion that I have spoken to Australian farmers about these issues they have said to me: `We are quite happy to compete on equal terms. We are not asking for any handouts or any special deals. All we are asking for in terms of that world trade situation is to be able to compete on equal terms'. Of course, that is absolutely impossible at the moment with the enormous green support being provided in the European Community. The amount is half what we faced a couple of months ago but still billions of dollars are sitting in the Treasury coffers in the United States ready to be spent in our markets, undercutting our produce. Quite frankly, it is impossible to sell any of our produce if it has to be sold for the price that it is produced in competition with goods that are sold for less than the cost of production. The rural sector must realise that fact regardless of which government is in power. Whether under a Liberal-National Party Government-we saw it struggle with this issue year in and year out-or the current Labor Government, those international policies will be a major determinant of what happens in this country, whether we like it or not. Of course, we do not like it, but that will be the situation. It therefore follows that there is a responsibility on government to look at every area of cost imposed on the rural sector in Australia to see whether that cost imposition is justified. Fairly obviously, in many circumstances, that cost imposition is not justified.

I will mention a cost which was introduced by the previous Liberal-National Party Government, and increased by the current Government. I refer to the subject that we were discussing this morning, the export inspection charges, for which we seek 50 per cent recovery. In most comparable countries that is paid for from consolidated revenue. But here in Australia a National Party Minister introduced that and that, of course, gave a lead to the Labor Party to follow through with that charge. In most comparable countries that charge is picked up as a health cost that is required within the general community and in support of their export drive.

I find it very odd that on many occasions here in the Senate we have discussed Bills to provide incentives for the export of manufactured products. The only time we ever get to discuss rural exports is when a new charge is to be imposed. It seems to me to be an absurd situation. Over one-third of Australia's exports are in the agricultural area and yet I cannot remember one Bill that has come into this place that will provide support for rural exports. I remember plenty of them that add another cost or another charge.

It seems to me that we need to look at the rural sector. One hopes that the package that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) is presenting to the Government will quickly be considered by the Government and operationalised. When we are looking at the current situation, we must all realise that we are looking at a tragedy fast developing and at a crisis that will destroy not only the rural economy but also, effectively, Australia's economy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard a dissertation from Senator Macklin which was quite good but I do not believe that it did cover--
—How many marks would you give him?

—I would give him about six out of 10. But he certainly did not cover the matter of public importance that we are discussing in the Senate today. He mentioned some very serious problems and I acknowledge those problems. I refer to the corruption of the international markets and the effect that that corruption is having--
—Why did you vote for the export charges?

—I did not vote for the export charges. The corruption is having an effect on our overseas exports. But that is not what we are debating today. Of course, if we listen to the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, we would think that the farmers of Australia should be utterly grateful for the capital gains tax that has been inflicted upon them; that they welcome the fringe benefits tax and are overjoyed at the reduced water conservation expenditure tax write-offs that the Labor Party has graciously given them. Unfortunately, Senator Walsh did not sell his story very well during the last State election in Western Australia. The voters deserted the Australian Labor Party in droves. It is absolutely ridiculous for him to come in here with his sorts of arguments.
—The reason is that they understand him and they empathise with him.

—That is an academic argument and I am sure that the people of Doodlakine would never understand it. Since this Government came into office on 5 March 1983, only three years ago, we have seen a concerted attack on the great primary industries of this nation. We have seen deceit and deception practised by this Government, promises made and broken, interest rates going through the roof, rallies, demonstrations and phone-ins all over this country as the rural producers of this nation try to get a message across to this Government that they are in desperate need of help. I think it was only three weeks ago that there was a photo of a farmer kneeling outside Parliament House trying, in a symbolic gesture, to get this Government to understand the plight of the rural producers. I never again want to see a farmer on his knees. I never want to see that happen. I never want to see the great wealth producers of this nation, even in a symbolic gesture, on their knees outside Parliament House.

SPEECH.PARA: This country has ridden to prosperity on the rural producers over the years. The standard of living that we all now enjoy has been provided by the rural producers of this country. They earn 40 per cent of our export income and produce over $15 billion of wealth every year. It was our primary industries of wheat, beef and wool which were largely responsible for boosting our export income by 24 per cent last year and which allow us to meet much of our overseas commitments.

Yet what have we seen this Labor Government do? It has extracted $442m from the farming industry and $648m from the rural communities of Australia. That is the gratification that it has given the farmers for producing most of our export income: It is a concerted attack on the rural producers of Australia. One would think that a government would acknowledge, thank and try to work in with one of our only industries that help us to meet our overseas commitments. It is one of our only outlets that produce export income. I have four pages which list 41 ways in which there has been a direct attack on the rural producers and farming industries of Australia. In the May mini-Budget we saw a reduction in the general depreciation allowance, the removal of tax incentives from the income equalisation deposit scheme and a 2c a litre increase in the excise on aviation fuel. I could go on and on and spend my whole speech just reading the measures that have been removed by the Labor Government in the May mini-Budget and the August 1984 Budget. I have three or four pages containing a list of benefits which have been cut from the rural industries of Australia.

We have seen the imposition of an assets test that discriminates against farmers. A person could live in a home worth $500,000 or $1m on the shores of Sydney Harbour but a farmer could not live on a $50,000 or $100,000 farm and spend his twilight years on a farm which he has worked and lived on for all his life. He has been forced off it. That is what we have seen happen under this Government.

One of the worst deceptions we have seen-even for the Labor Party it reached the bottom of the barrel-is the Labor Government's promise to accept an Australian dairy industry proposal to restructure the dairy industry on the eve of the Victorian election. Three days after the election the Federal Labor Party Government reneged on that package which would have bankrupted 3,000 farmers. The Senate rejected the Labor Party's proposal. That is the sort of deception that we have seen practised against rural producers of Australia.

The Government brought in the May mini-Budget in which rural Australia wore 75 per cent of the cuts. People in farming and small business areas are prepared to carry their weight; they are prepared to shoulder their burden. However, 75 per cent of Budget cuts were directed at one sector of the community. Senator Walsh has the audacity to say that he is the farmers' friend. No one will fall for that; I do not think that Senator Walsh is even convincing himself.

Rural Australia has been targeted by policies of this Federal Government and in a desperate bid to get the Government to heed the call 50,000 farmers gathered on the grass outside this Parliament House. They came from all over Australia. I was fortunate to be able to accompany a busload of farmers from the Darling Downs and I listened to their concerns. We spent two days in the bus and they expressed to me their concerns, worries and fears about properties that have been in their families for two and three generations. They expressed to me the doubts that their sons would be able to take over the properties. They told me that there was no future in farming, that it was only a way of life and that the average farmer is around 50 years of age. When this generation is through very few people will be on our farms.

Let us see what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said to the farmers. The meeting was addressed by farmers, truckies, small business people and farmers' wives who all had a common thread. They needed help and were desperate. They were forced into this situation by high interest rates, high fuel prices and many other costs that this Government had inflicted upon them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nothing to do with the world oil price situation, of course.
—Of course the world price situation comes into it.
—What did the Government do about it?
—What will the Government do about it? Let us see what the Prime Minister said. At the meeting he stated:

SPEECH.PARA: What I say to you is this. I give you this undertaking that we will prepare a package which will significantly reduce the cost impact upon farmers.

That statement was made in June 1985. Let us look at this for a snake oil cure. This is what came up. Three months later the Government announced its tax changes. It introduced a capital gains tax; it introduced the quarantining of farm losses so that they could not be offset against income earned elsewhere; it introduced a fringe benefits tax; it reduced water conservation expenditure 100 per cent tax write-offs over one year. That is what the Prime Minister of Australia gave the 50,000 people who rallied outside this Parliament House. That proves once and for all, if we ever needed any further proof, that the Prime Minister could not care less about rural Australia. Three months after he promised rural Australia a package, what did the rural producers get? They got the greatest hiding-that is all it was-that rural producers of Australia ever got. This showed just how genuine Mr Hawke was. Three months after he spoke to the 50,000 farmers he inflicted these taxes upon them.

I want to tell the Senate that not only farmers and the rural producers are being hurt and are bleeding but small business people, restaurateurs, the garages and retail stores are all suffering from the insensitive Labor Government's policies that have been inflicted on them. Not one person in the country could say: `We have had our way of life and our standard of living lifted by this Labor Government'. In the last three years not one person in rural Australia could honestly say that his lifestyle has been improved. I defy anyone to say that in the three years of Labor Government he has had his lifestyle improved.

The capital gains tax, which everyone has feared, has run a streak of terror through everyone. That is what we saw introduced three months after the rally. I always like to make this point because I think it is a very effective one. Mr Hawke made this promise on a capital gains tax:
Let me make one point so that even our opponents can understand it and let me make it beyond all their powers of misrepresentation and distortion-There will be no new capital gains tax.

That is what the Prime Minister of Australia said. We have a capital gains tax; we have all other sundry taxes that have been inflicted upon us. Yet today the farmers of Australia are ringing in and recording their protest against high interest rates. All I would like to tell those people is this. `Save your 30c; save the money you would spend on making phone calls, because the only way you will ever get anywhere in Australia is to change the Government of Australia. You will then positively be able to get some sympathy on interest rates, some sympathy on fuel prices and some sympathy on water conservation'. The coalition will guarantee that everything that they have lost will be returned to them. We have put out a 14-point proposal enunciating the benefits that will be returned under a coalition government.

In the few minutes that I have left to me I want to deal with the sugar industry in my home State. For three years since this Government came to power we have been told that we will get a floor price plan and a price support scheme for the sugar industry. It has gone on and on for three years and the sugar cane farmers have felt that economic squeeze. They, of course, are hanging in and hoping that something will happen. Every time that the Queensland Government has put up a proposal the Federal Government has moved away. The Queensland Government has made its position clear. It has allocated $194m, which includes a $50m grant over three years, to assist the millers and the growers. The Australian Canegrowers Council passed a resolution this month clearly stating that price support is a Commonwealth responsibility. It has said that the State Government has met its commitments and it is now expecting the Commonwealth Government to meet its commitments and not continue to move away for another three years.

It is now clearly in the court of the Commonwealth Government to introduce a price support scheme. Never in the history of Australia has any State government had to pick up the burden of a price support scheme. We have seen time and again this Government give $180m to the car industry and the steel industry. Only a couple of days ago, we saw $24m going to the Ford Motor Co. of Australia Ltd despite the fact that Ford has made a profit of $150m. Yet when the sugar cane industry, which is on its knees, wants some price support scheme that was promised to it, it cannot even get it. This Government came into office with a promise-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am interested that Senator Boswell spent just three of his 15 minutes discussing issues relating to Queensland and, in particular, the crisis in the sugar industry. If he is genuinely concerned about the issue we are debating this afternoon-the crippling effect of the Federal Government's policies on the rural industries of Australia-I would have thought that he would have been prepared to give more than three minutes of his time to the crisis in Queensland's sugar industry. I find, as usual, that Senator Boswell is not particularly well informed. We have offered assistance to the sugar industry in Queensland since last September. Since last September we have been waiting for a response from the State Government. The Federal Government had a Cabinet meeting in Townsville last September and Mr Kerin and Mr Hawke made those announcements in September. We have waited all that time.

SPEECH.PARA: I would just like to quote from a report entitled `Sugar People Take a Caning', which is the most authoritative statement that is available on what people in the sugar industry of north Queensland are thinking about Senator Boswell and his State Government. I quote from the first page of the report, which is headed `Summary of Findings and Recommendations':
Joh should try to get along better with the federal government. Unless extra money comes from somewhere we won't survive.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was last September. What about today? What about the sugar cane growers passing a resolution saying it is your responsibility?

—I would be very happy to give Senator Boswell a copy of this report dated February 1986 which sets out the view of the people of the Babinda-Innisfail region. When the Queensland Premier was in that region he was run out of town. He was hissed and booed because the cane growers and the people of that region are fed up with his meddling. He will not allow Mr Turner and Mr Kerin to finalise the package. If Senator Boswell is prepared to listen for a short time he will find out what the people in the north Queensland sugar growing areas are saying. The report continues:

SPEECH.PARA: Some of the Babinda respondents are prepared to change the voting habits of a lifetime because of the politicians' response, or lack of response, to the sugar crisis. The respondents most likely to change their votes at the next election are those who divided their voting at the last election (supporting one party at the state level and another at the federal)
One respondent stated:
`My husband says we won't vote for National next time, especially in the state because Joh B. Petersen is not helping us; in fact he is doing some weird things'.

I think that is probably one of the most succinct comments I have heard about the policies of the Bjelke-Petersen Government in relation to the sugar industry in Queensland. It seems a pity that Senator Boswell is so uninterested in the sugar industry in north Queensland that he has left the chamber. I would like to finalise the point that I was making. Recommendations arising out of this report were made specifically to the Queensland Government. We always hear from the Premier about all that the Federal Government should do but I would like to put on record what the people in the area believe the Queensland Government should do. The report states that the Queensland Government should:

12. Use the powers of the Sugar Board and the Central Sugar Cane Prices Board, to control the production of sugar in accord with advice from the ``Sugar Industry Social and Economic Research and Information Service'', Co-ordinate reductions in sugar production with the Commonwealth scheme to subsidise canegrowers for land removed from their Assignments.
13. Subsidise interest payments on loans to canegrowers experiencing financial difficulties attributable to the recent decline in sugar industry profitability.
14. Subsidise interest payments on loans to sugar milling enterprises which are experiencing financial difficulties attributable to the recent decline in sugar industry profitability.
15. Subsidise interest payments on loans to small businesses which are experiencing financial difficulties attributable to the recent decline in sugar industry profitability.
16. Grant concessional railway freight rates on the transport of raw sugar.
17. Grant concessional railway freight rates for canegrowers on cargo related to sugar production.

18. Extend increased service to canegrowers through the Queensland Department of Primary Industries, to communicate up-to-date information and advice concerning the production and marketing prospects of farm products alternative to sugarcane.

It is quite clear further in the recommendations that it is the view of the respondents in this analysis that both the Federal and the Queensland governments, acting jointly, should finance a joint price support scheme.

As usual, this afternoon we have had a number of comments about what a Federal government could or may do in regard to the rural sector. Before I go on to detail precisely what the Federal Government has done and will be doing in the near future I would just like to quote from a poll that was undertaken by the National Farmer between March 1978 and November 1981 because I think sometimes the Opposition just needs to be brought down to earth as it is not as perfect as it would like to suggest it is in opposition. It seems to imagine that there was a wonderful utopia when it was in government. I would just like to put on record what the National Farmer saw in this poll. The article I have states:
Farmers' perceptions of the performance of the Coalition government's handling of agricultural policy in March 1978 and November 1981 was recorded thus:
The article continues:

The rural scandals involving Asia Dairy Industries, Meat Inspection . . . the Rae Committee's criticism of the Wheat Board's accounting problems and staff loans within the Wool Corporation no doubt contributed to concern about the coalition's performance.

Growing anger at the lack of fulfilment of political promises also features strongly within the pages of the National Farmer as a source of declining confidence of farmers in the Coalition. In January 1984 an article on that subject claimed that the Coalition had failed to fulfil `between 60 and 80' policy promises between 1974 and 1983, but warned that the Hawke Labor Government was building an `impressive' record.

TALK.START.PARA: —In breaking promises?

—Yes certainly, but I want to put on record that whenever these matters of public importance come before the Senate Opposition members behave as if the present Government is the only government ever to experience difficulties in dealing with a particular situation. I turn specifically to the issue we are debating this afternoon:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is actively considering rural Australia as an entity, and not just as an offshoot of primary industry and commodity production. There are a number of constructive measures relevant to rural Australians which this Government continues to actively support, whether directly or in co-operation with the State Governments. These measures range across health, education, transport, telecommunications, postal services roads and the many other requirements and facilities which need additional attention and offer funding if there is to be equity with urban Australia.
Those were the words of the Minister for Primary Industry, John Kerin. I do not remember a statement anything like that emanating during the coalition's time in office.

I go on to deal with a positive step that has been taken in considering the needs of rural and provincial Australia, and that is the establishment of the Rural and Provincial Affairs Unit. In October 1984 the Prime Minister foreshadowed the formation of a Rural and Provincial Affairs Unit, and in March 1985 the Minister for Primary Industry announced the establishment of the Unit. The broad aim of the Unit is to provide government with a specific perspective on rural Australia, where needs and problems often differ from those of metropolitan areas. The Unit is concerned with all rural Australians, including those living in provincial towns, and its objectives are in line with the Government's policy of providing services on an equitable basis for all Australians. The Unit will not do any special pleading for rural Australia but will assist government to understand how its policies affect non-metropolitan people and where policies may require change to achieve equity.

In summary, the objectives of the Unit are: To identify and assess policies and activities that have an important effect on rural Australia; with the co-operation of relevant government departments, to seek to improve where necessary the delivery of the policies and programs; to identify areas where there are gaps in or lack of co-ordination of policies and programs; to encourage action departments always to consider rural issues when developing or implementing policy; to disseminate information or government programs relevant to rural and provincial Australia.

I go on to deal with the issue that is constantly confronting us in the media and elsewhere. I refer to the phrase `crisis in the rural sector'. It is being taken to suggest that an irretrievable situation faces all Australian farmers, in all sectors and all over Australia. However, there is a significant group of people in some industries and in some areas who are facing very real difficulties. We are very concerned about those and the Minister is developing a major policy statement in this regard. But it is simply not accurate to talk as if all farmers in all sectors all over Australia are in crisis.

In broad macroeconomic terms the Government has achieved considerable success. Inflation is now running at about 8 per cent per annum-a significant fall from the double digit rates of recent years-and the growth in farm costs has also fallen considerably. The floating of the dollar and devaluation have helped maintain export returns for commodities. At the same time the Government has also provided specific assistance to the farm sector. For example, in the last Budget the Government replaced the tariff on grain harvesters with a bounty, which will save the industry some $11m per annum. As well, the Government introduced a full rebate of the wholesale excise on diesel used in primary production. This means the effective price of diesel for on-farm use will fall by about 10.6c per litre. That is more than 20 per cent, under the new petroleum products pricing arrangements. These arrangements announced on 24 February 1986, to take effect from the middle of March, will also provide a reduction in petrol prices of more than 5c per litre.

TALK.START.PARA: —They never had an excise on diesel.

—Senator Crichton-Browne does not appear to be interested in cuts in fuel prices. I ask him not to interrupt. The Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) has done his best to persuade the United States Administration to change some of its provisions in its latest farm Bill to soften the blow to Australia. The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, himself will be making representations to Washington next month. Mr Kerin is currently preparing a comprehensive economic and agricultural policy statement which will be presented to Federal Parliament on 15 April. I hope Opposition members will be around to make some constructive comments about that policy statement when it is brought down.

SPEECH.PARA: The farm sector cannot be considered in isolation from the rest of the economy. The economic performance of rural producers is affected by macroeconomic and industry policies generally, as well as by agriculture-specific measures. Consequently, that policy statement will follow a review of the implications of policies across the whole economy for the rural sector. In particular, the Government will be seeking to find lasting solutions to the serious difficulties faced by many farm enterprises and families. At the same time, the statement will take into account the effects of the downturn on families, services and businesses in country towns. Pork barrel approaches by the Opposition are not the solution. Senator Boswell referred to the coalition's policies, which I think he said were contained in a 14-point plan, yet I note that in the poll conducted by the National Farmer there was talk of up to 80 broken promises. It seems to suggest that 14 points are scarcely adequate to cover the many complex issues facing rural Australia and that the coalition's policy needs considerable expansion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —One wonders whether the Australian Labor Party is steeped in prejudice or ignorance as to the plight of the rural economy. However, whatever view one takes and whatever judgment one makes, the results and effects are identical. The farmers of Australia are being ignored, neglected and allowed to slide inexorably into bankruptcy and financial collapse as a result of the policies of the Labor Government, or indeed the lack of policy initiatives by that Government. For many farmers the struggle is for survival. It is not a claim for a nice 3 per cent productivity bonus or for improved living standards. It is, as I have said, a struggle for survival. It is a question of farmers losing their farms or maintaining them. It is a question of protecting their own future and that of further generations.

SPEECH.PARA: Many areas of the rural economy, many of the rural community, are in a state of crisis. Many are verging on bankruptcy. In my own State alone foreclosures and forced sales are becoming a daily way of rural life. Abject poverty in parts of Western Australia is becoming endemic. When we talk of the rural community, we are talking not only of farmers but also of people involved in the infrastructure-the service industries and those who live in country towns. We are dealing not just with a social problem but with a major economic problem for all Australians. The Australian agricultural sector is one of the most vital economic sectors of our entire nation. Currently it is going through one of its greatest periods of crisis this century. The blame for the current problems which our farmers are facing can be laid very firmly and fairly on the shoulders of the present Hawke Labor Government. Whatever excuses and reasons the Government may offer, the current rural malaise is in fact the Government's fault and should be sheeted home accordingly. It is an inevitable consequence of Labor's domestic policies.

Let me examine the kinds of problems which Australian farmers are facing and then the reasons why the Labor Government should be taking the responsibility. At the outset, the very crux of the rural problem is falling farm incomes. This year farm incomes will fall by 24 to 25 per cent. The Government is expecting farmers to live on incomes in the wheat and crop sector of minus $7,500, in mixed livestock $4,500, sheep $12,200, beef $16,000, and horticulture $6,200. The average farmer in Australia is expected to live on 18 per cent of the average weekly earnings of the average Australian. No farmer can be expected to live on that sort of income. Nevertheless, that is the current state of the economy. I seek leave, Madam Acting Deputy President, to have incorporated in Hansard details of the costs, outlays and receipts for the average farmer in Western Australia who has a base yield of 1.7 tonnes per hectare of wheat per year, based on the 1986-87 year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Those figures will show that the average wheat farmer in Western Australia is expected to lose $48 per hectare in wheat. It is little wonder that in Western Australia alone this year it is expected that there will be a reduction in plantings of wheat of 25 per cent, on the best scenario, and, at worst, of 45 per cent. That is primarily due to the fact that many of those farmers will make a loss if they plant, and the balance of the farmers cannot get an advance from their banks. So, already there is a crisis. For Senator Walsh to talk about macroeconomic circumstances of the future is absolutely absurd. There are countless farmers this very year who will become bankrupt as a result of this Government's policies.

SPEECH.PARA: Then we have the problem of inflation. In Australia we have inflation rates that are more than double those of our trading partners in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. Almost 80 per cent of our wheat is exported and 50 per cent of our beef is exported-and our farmers must sell on an open market. With a rate of inflation of about 8.2 per cent, of course they cannot compete. In my own State of Western Australia the effect of inflation on costs has been quite dramatic. In the 12 months from September 1984 to September 1985, the price of fertilisers has increased by 15 per cent, the price of chemicals by 8.5 per cent, fuel by 13.5 per cent, and interest rate payments by 22.8 per cent. Labour costs have risen by 5 per cent, and they are expected to rise by 7 per cent this year. Also, of course, inevitably, when our farmers' costs are rising at such rates and while their overseas competitors enjoy inflation rates of half ours and interest rates of a quarter of ours, there is no prospect of our being able properly to compete.

Of course, two other problems are helping to destroy the rural industries of this nation. One is the effect of the rising levels of debt at a time of rising interest rates. Between June 1984 and June 1985, the total debt of farmers increased by 21 per cent to a staggering $7,220m. That, surely, is the highest increase in the level of debt of any part of the Australian economy. In June last year, according to figures provided by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, average debt figures for various sectors of rural industry were as follows: Wheat, $123,570; mixed livestock, $76,160; sheep, $55,000; sheep and beef, $52,810-just to cite a few. Of course, this is happening at a time when we have declining rural values which, of course, mean that a farmer's equity in his farm is declining, and so his asset is declining dramatically. In my own State of Western Australia perhaps the debt problem is best shown by the statistics that I have before me. I seek leave, Madam Acting Deputy President, to have these statistics incorporated in Hansard. They show that 45.1 per cent of wheat farmers have a level of debt in excess of $100,000. These increasing debts are due to increases in interest rates and to the rescheduling of debts and, of course, it is just impossible for these farmers to go on.
