TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Of course, the burden of carrying these levels of debt is worsening, when interest rates are rising. In September 1985 the Primary Industry Bank was charging 16.25 per cent for loans under $100,000 and 19 per cent for overdraft levels of over $100,000. Current figures for overdraft debts at commercial rates are 18.25 per cent for loans under $100,000 and about 19.95 per cent for amounts over $100,000, and in many cases they are in the range of 23 per cent. It is hardly any wonder that the BAE, in its recent quarterly review, suggests that up to 50 per cent of the increase in farm costs is caused by a rise in interest rates. The figures which I shall cite show the effect of rising debts and rising interest rates, and this is best seen by examining the levels for those farms which the BAE considers to be `at risk'. It is interesting to note that in the last 12 months the number of farms considered to be at risk in Western Australia has increased by 400 per cent. In Australia generally the figure is 80 per cent. In the dairy industry it is 500 per cent. In horticulture, the figure has gone from 8 per cent to 13 per cent. So there has been a dramatic increase in the last 12 months of those farms which fall into the category, by definition, of being at risk-`at risk' being those farms that have 70 per cent or less equity, less the living expenses, less capital repayments, and that is not including interest rates, of course.

SPEECH.PARA: Our farmers are being expected to sell their products on a world market and required to buy inputs at artificially high levels from protected industries. There has been much debate about the level of protection and the effect that it is having on the rural sector, but it is fair to say that the average, intelligent judgment is that it costs the average farm about $9,000 in protection. If one takes off about $2,000, in round figures, for the subsidies that farmers receive, one sees that it is costing the average farmer about $7,000 in protection.

In light of all these problems, let us ask ourselves what the Labor Government has done for the rural sector in the last period. It has supported the Australian Council of Trade Unions' productivity claim. It has raised interest rates. It makes almost no inroads into protection. It has failed fully and honestly to pass on the fuel price falls to the whole community. It has destroyed the effectiveness of income equalisation deposits. It has put a sales tax on wine. It has refused a request to pass the money received from the indexing of excise into the bicentennial road development program. It has cancelled the previous Government's supplementary water resources program. It has tried to introduce a fertiliser bounty. It intends to introduce a capital gains tax and a fringe benefits tax. It has quarantined farm losses. It has removed the special deductibility provisions for water conservation. They are the benefits that have been passed on by this compassionate, understanding, pragmatic, realistic Government to that part of the economy which provides 40 per cent of our export earnings.

Let us look at these matters in detail. The Government has backed the ACTU in its 3 per cent productivity claim. What does the average farmer do when he is lumbered with a 3 per cent increase, when his income itself has fallen by 143 per cent in the past year and he is now receiving a bill for another 3 per cent? What consideration is there for his capacity, his competence, his ability to absorb that extra cost? What consideration is there for the productivity and capacity to pay? The answer is: None. The Government has made no attempt to examine those matters. It has simply unilaterally decided that the trade union movement will receive that benefit. Where was the Government last year when the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission was asked by the ACTU to pass on a 2.6 per cent wage decision? It was deafening in its silence.

The Government's attitude, simply, is: `Well, if it keeps the ACTU happy, if it keeps the trade union movement happy, if it keeps our base support happy, let the farmers go broke. They are not an attractive part of our constituency. We can win without their seats anyway, so to hell with them. Let us distort and debase the economy, but let us keep our supporters on side'. Of course, the Government has pursued a policy of increasing interest rates purposely, deliberately and wilfully, partly due to incompetence and partly due to pragmatic decisions. It has lifted interest rates in the last 12 months from around 14 per cent to 19 per cent. There are all sorts of other things that the Government could have done in regard to propping up the dollar. The problem is that the Government is perceived by the world economy to be incompetent and it has had to prop up the dollar by driving up interest rates to extortionate levels. And then the Government is still struggling.

Of course, the Government could have done it quite differently. It could have had a complete discounting of wages, and it could have had no ridiculous productivity rise, and then Australian goods would have been much more competitive and the dollar would have been supported by an improvement in our trading position. Instead, the Government has taken the weak option. It has raised interest rates to protect the weak dollar as a result of its incompetence, and, of course, the effect has been passed on to the rural sector. We have sitting opposite Senator Gareth Evans, who tells us what a wonderful thing he has done for the rural economy in allowing it to be excluded from the excise on off-road farm diesel.

TALK.START.PARA: —Eleven cents a litre.

—When was the rural economy paying it? The Minister has done nothing for it. He has maintained the status quo, and he knows it. Senator Evans, of all people, should feel guilty about the con he is trying to put over the rural community. The Government achieved nothing.
—No gratitude; 11c a litre for off-road use.

—How can Senator Evans expect gratitude for doing nothing? He stands still and he wants people to love him. For goodness sake! It is the greatest con trick since the Bill of Rights. The Government decreased by 5.3c a litre, as I recall--
—A decrease of 5.77c and 11c for farmers.

—It decreased the price of petrol by 5.77c. It did not even have the courage to give a proper discounting. If it had given a proper discounting, it would have reduced the consumer price index by 2 per cent. The original assessment was 0.5 per cent, ultimately one per cent. The Government could have reduced the CPI by 2 per cent. Inflation would come down by 2 per cent and the Government would make our rural producers more competitive than they are. But the Government has done none of those things. It has not had the courage, the conviction or the commitment. That is the attitude the Government has towards the rural sector. It has done away with income equalisation deposits, which allowed farmers in the past to smooth out their incomes. It has introduced an impost on the sale of wine and a whole range of policies which, regrettably, time does not allow me to go on with.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government sought to introduce a duty on fertilisers, but because Brian Burke was having an election it lost its nerve. It was not concerned about the farmers. It was concerned about Brian Burke losing his damned election! He would have lost it, too. Pragmatically, Mr Hawke, lying in the sun and tanning himself at Kirribilli said: `We will do away with the fertiliser proposal, to help Brian Burke'. The Government could not have cared less about the farmers. It introduced a capital gains tax, the quarantining of off-farm income and a fringe benefits tax. It deserves no credit from anybody, least of all the farmers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Black Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) I apologise for the Government having provided assistance to Western Australian farmers recently! I am sorry that it displeased Senator Crichton-Browne to learn that we won the Western Australian election. I am sure he realises that we will win the next election as well. I am pleased to be given the opportunity today to argue the merits of the Federal Labor Government's economic policies as they affect the rural sector. I state from the outset that I do not take the view held by some cynical political observers that the Federal Government can afford to ignore the current complaints of the rural sector simply because the Government holds few rural seats with any substantial concentrations of rural voters. We believe that all Australians, irrespective of where they live and how they vote, deserve to be treated equally. In the current situation of depressed world commodity prices confronting rural producers, they deserve a measure of favourable consideration from this Government, and that is exactly what they are getting.

SPEECH.PARA: I also state, for the benefit of those rural producers who are listening to the broadcast of this debate and who are intending to ring the honourable member for McMillan, Mr Cunningham, to complain about high interest rates, that his telephone number is 72 7541. I am pleased to put that on the record. It seems that a well know Queensland rural newspaper placed my office telephone number under his name and I have received more than my fair share of telephone calls on this issue. I am also pleased to advise rural producers on the southern Darling Downs that I will be visiting their region next week with the Prime Minister's rural task force, to examine the situation in the area at first hand as the guest of the honourable member for Rankin, Mr David Beddall. During the visit we will enter into discussions with a wide range of rural producers, the local Chamber of Commerce and representatives of local government. We are seeking to learn at first hand the nature of the rural problem rather than to score cheap political points, which unfortunately has been the trend in the debate this afternoon.

It is crucial, when discussing the current difficulties facing Australian producers, to place them in their current international context and to compare the sort of responses made by this Government with the solutions put forward by the former conservative Federal Government. The obvious starting point is the current weakness in our international commodity markets. This weakness can be attributed to major structural changes which have occurred in these markets in recent years and which are entirely unrelated to elections in Australia. The rapid expansion of European Economic Community production in imports, the extensive use of export subsidies by the United States of America, a drop in the rate of increase in import demand by developing countries and a reduction in imports by China have all led to the accumulation of high levels of stocks and resulting price falls. Unless there are adverse weather conditions in major producing countries, these accumulated stocks will not be diminished, unfortunately, over the coming years. This sort of situation is likely to be aggravated further by increased competition in our traditional markets from further subsidised exports from the EEC, and from the United States following the introduction of its farm Bill.

Domestically, the most important thing the Government can do to improve the rural sector's competitive position is to continue to manage the economy well. In broad macro-economic terms, this Government has achieved considerable successes in this area. Inflation is now running at about 8 per cent per annum. That is a significant fall from the double digit rates of recent years. The growth in farm costs has also fallen considerably. The floating of the dollar and the devaluation have helped to maintain export returns for commodities. At the same time the Government has also provided specific assistance to the farm sector. For example, in the last Budget-this point was noted earlier by Senator Reynolds-the Government replaced the tariffs on grain harvesters with a bounty which will save the industry well in excess of $10m per annum. Also, as has already been raised in this debate, the Government has introduced a full rebate of the wholesale excise on diesel used in primary production. This means that the effective price of diesel for on-farm use will fall by about 10.6 cents a litre, that is, more than 20 per cent, under the new petroleum products pricing arrangements. These arrangements, announced in February, will also provide for a reduction in petrol prices of more than 5c a litre-5.77 cents, as I am indebted to Senator Gareth Evans for pointing out to us.

It is useful to compare our actions with those taken by the current Opposition Leader when he became Treasurer in 1977. At that time crude oil receipts were 1.4 per cent of all Commonwealth receipts-some $346m. When he left the Treasurer's office, oil receipts totalled 9 per cent of total receipts, that is, an increase of some 700 per cent. The total collected then was a massive $3,400m. That is not a record, I submit, which the Opposition can afford to boast about.

The Government is also very much aware of the current problems associated with the present level of interest rates. Again, they have to be seen in their correct context. The Bureau of Agricultural Economics estimates that some 7 per cent of farmers will be at risk in financial terms in 1985-86 and that the risk is greatest for those farmers who have less than 70 per cent equity in their property and who are also faced with negative farm income. This figure is up from 5 per cent about a year earlier. Whilst this represents a large number of individuals-some 12,000 farms-it by no means indicates a massive crisis across the entire sector. The reason for that is that conditions across this sector and within industries are diverse. Farm cash operating surpluses in beef are forecast to increase to 10 per cent in 1985-86, in contrast to the overall fall. There is also a wide distribution of debt. Twenty-eight per cent of farmers have no debt. A further 18 per cent have less than $20,000 debt. These people are net lenders to the rest of the community. If they have their funds free, they will benefit, for example, from higher interest rates. On the other hand, 12 per cent of farmers have debt levels which exceed $150,000. There is a crisis in that respect for those farmers. We concede that it is a crisis, but it is a crisis for only a number of people and not for the sector as a whole.

Government policies in relation to farm debts have also produced results which compare favourably with those obtained by the Opposition. Far from discriminating against farmers, the Government has adopted positive policies. It reduced the inflation rate of farm costs from 11 per cent in 1982-83 to a forecast 7 per cent this year. If the previous Government's 11 per cent inflation rate had continued for the past three years, farm income this year would be $1.1 billion, or about 33 per cent, lower than is currently forecast. We also floated the currency, resulting in a depreciation of the trade-weighted exchange rate by some 25 per cent when compared with the previous year. If the previous Government's overvalued exchange rate-the previous Government, as we all know, deliberately followed a policy of overvaluation of the exchange rate-had been continued, farmers would be some $2 billion, or well over 50 per cent, worse off than they are now.

We heard some discussions earlier about the Queensland sugar industry. I would simply like to point out for the record that in August last year the Savage committee, more formally known as the Sugar Industry Working Party, recommended measures to help the Australian sugar industry, which was then and is now suffering the effects of a collapse of world sugar prices, and in the case of the Queensland industry, massive overregulation and overexpansion under the mantle of the current Queensland Government. The two cornerstones of the Commonwealth's recommendations were price support and deregulation. The Federal Government was quick to respond with a $150m package of direct price support which was made conditional on the State Government matching Federal funding on a $1 for $2 basis.

In a series of talks between Mr Kerin and the Queensland Primary Industries Minister which followed, the Queensland Government repeatedly refused to recognise its financial responsibilities to the sugar industry. While the New South Wales Government agreed to price support for its industry in September and while industry leaders negotiated on deregulation, the Queensland Government has consistently kept trying to back out of the deal. The best the Queensland Government could offer was a package of loans and guarantees on loans to an industry which was already heavily in debt. The National Party in Queensland has decided not to provide the $70m of direct assistance to meet the Federal Government's offer, although negotiations are now continuing.

It should be pointed out that some eight months after the Savage committee's report, through the meanness and the unwillingness to co-operate shown by the Queensland Government, the State's sugar industry has still not received the financial assistance it so badly needs. As a former union official employed to represent the interests of workers in the sugar industry, I am well aware of the extent to which the economy in major provincial cities on the Queensland coast is dependent on the sugar industry and the extent to which employees directly have links with the political and the economic fortunes of their employers. I think it is fair to say that the Government has endeavoured to do the best for both groups.

I would also like to point out that during my research for this speech this afternoon I looked through a number of documents produced by the National Farmers Federation and the Livestock and Grain Producers Association to try to understand the extent and nature of the criticism they have been making about the Federal Government. While doing that I came across a document which listed some major LGPA-NFF achievements. I think it is fair to point out that, of these 40 or so achievements, a large number are directly related to actions taken by the Federal Government which may or may not have been the subject of lobbying by the NFF.

For the benefit of the record, I will list a few of those achievements that the NFF is claiming responsibility for. It says that it achieved the float of the Australian dollar, resulting in over 25 per cent devaluation since March 1983. It is also claiming to have achieved reductions in tariffs on large grain harvesters from 15 to 2 per cent. It is boasting that it achieved indexation of rebate on diesel fuel. It also, apparently, achieved changes to the assets test for farm pensioners. I am pleased to be made aware of its extensive role in that regard. It claims that it achieved a comprehensive $270m drought relief package which preserved the national sheep and cattle population during the 1980s drought; rejection of proposals to impose tariff duties on imported tractors, resulting in savings of $35m per annum; rejection of a proposed $40m per annum tariff imposition on imported four-wheel drive vehicles; achieved rejection of higher protection for the steel industry, saving farmers around $53m per annum; 100 per cent taxation deductibility for water storage and reticulation improvements; tax averaging provisions ensuring equity to primary producers with fluctuating incomes; and increased allowances for isolated children.

Apparently, it also achieved single-handedly Federal biological control legislation and State government commitments for complementary legislation; farm gate pricing systems for the live sheep trade; $25m per annum government contribution for wool promotion; assistance to increase the wool base reserve price for 1985-86; and further redevelopment of market support funds. It also encouraged the Australian Wheat Board to greater flexibility in direct grower to user sales.

The NFF has been caught betwixt and between with the document listing these achievements in that, whilst it is extremely critical of the Federal Government in a number of areas, it cannot resist the temptation to boast about the achievements of the Federal Government whilst at the same time claiming credit for them. Nevertheless, those achievements should be put on record as achievements directly made by this Government for rural producers.

In summary, I believe the Commonwealth Government is putting into place the right sort of macroeconomic climate for an efficient rural sector. In particular, we have been using what influence we can to enhance our international trade situation. We are also developing and extending services and assistance at the level of the individual. At the same time, we are taking a constructive look at rural society beyond the farm gate. In conclusion, if there is such a thing as a rural crisis in Australia at the moment, the blows have been softened considerably by the actions of this Federal Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia is teetering on the brink of economic disaster. Our current account deficit for this year to date is an all time record-up 25 per cent on the corresponding period last year. Devaluation of the dollar was expected to achieve a strong rate of growth of exports and a fall in imports. However, it has failed to do so. There is also a world glut of primary commodities. Our closest allies-the United States of America and the European Economic Community-are flagrantly breaching the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade on trade practices and protectionism, subsidising more and more of their commodity exports and dumping them in Australia's traditional markets for primary produce. Japan and the United States are engaged in an economic war which crushes Australian manufacturing in the middle and the tariffs supplied by the Government to protect our own manufacturing remnants place a heavy cost burden on our rural industries.

SPEECH.PARA: Interest rates are crippling private consumption and private investment and reducing our level of economic growth so that we face another spate of job losses and higher unemployment, with rural sector borrowings at an all time high, in excess of $7 billion, and with a current massive downturn in farm incomes forecast by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics. This is the worst crisis for the rural industry we have yet faced. It is comparable to the 1930s. Now is not the time to place unreasonable burdens on the rural sector's productive capacity. Our balance of payments problem can be solved only by a massive growth of exports and a massive reduction of our foreign borrowings. We have borrowed heavily in recent years, primarily for the private sector, to cover the increasing debt of our productive industries, including farm borrowings. What our rural producers and our manufacturers need is to increase exports. The way to increase exports is to lower costs, improve productivity, put innovative products and technology on to the market and to be insulated from the volatile world market crises which are spreading this whole burden over the whole community. We need a stable, local business environment and the Government is not offering this.

What our rural producers do not need are fringe benefit taxes on essential services not publicly provided in rural areas such as transport and housing. We do not need quarantining of farm incomes so that rural producers are all unable to diversify their operations, as happens in other industries, to cover production of commodities currently facing depressed world prices. Everybody else can move out of his sector, but the farmers are tied there by the Government's quarantining arrangements. This is a quite unacceptable situation. When we compare Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and the effect of its offsetting its steel operations on its other operations, when we compare what happens between companies, the Government is just simply picking on the rural sector and stopping farmers from moving out of an area which is depressed because of factors outside of the farmers control. It is really disgusting that this should happen.

One should compare also the retrospective nature of this quarantining tax with the provisions for negative geared investments in rental housing. Many rural enterprises have been operating in this fashion for years, and that is accepted. A productive industry like farming has not been given that opportunity. Because of the shortness of time, I seek leave to incorporate three letters which point out the problems of the forestry and fruit growing industries in this area. These industries are also quarantined. I have permission from both sides of the House to do so.
Leave granted.

Senator D. Vigor,

Dear Senator,
In my position as Chairman of the Almond Co-operative Ltd., which handles over 80% of the Australian production, I offer the following submission concerning the Almond Industry.
Figures show that between 1970 and 1985, the total local production increased from approximately 800 tonnes of kernel per annum to the latest figure of over 2,000 tonnes per annum.
Imports, almost exclusively from the U.S.A., have increased from around 700 tonnes to 3,000 tonnes in the corresponding period-this is equal to $12m loss in foreign exchange.
In other words, although local production has more than doubled over recent years, the percentage share of the Australian market has in fact declined.

At current production levels, the imported product would translate at around 5,000 acres of almonds. Combined with this, there is decreasing production in the traditional areas of Willunga and the Adelaide Plains, due to a number of factors, including the urban spread, severely limited quality and quantity of underground water supplies, high land values, combined with generally older trees and smaller and less viable holdings, many of these by `hobby farmers'.
There is little doubt that expansion must continue to keep pace with demand. Latest management and technological expertise must be used to match U.S. production figures and costs.
This expansion will be largely in the Murray River area, where the climate, soil, and water availability are most suitable for this to occur.

The Almond Industry is seen by such recognised bodies as State Departments of Agriculture, Commonwealth D.P.I., A.D.F.A. etc., as a very viable alternative to wines and other depressed horticultural industries, and a likely replacement for some of the `vine pull' areas.
With the large cost and relatively long lead time of around 5 years, there has been, and will continue to be, a very great need for investor dollars.

In the case of most developments in the area where we are involved there has been a remarkedly successful marriage of investors and practical farm managers who have a significant financial interest in these developments.

This has led to the maximising of productivity and the large syndication of plant and equipment, out of reach of any single operator. The community huller-cracker, worth $500,000, is an example of such syndication.
Other growers within a radius of 200 km have been able to have their product processed at reasonable charge through an infra-structure which would have been completely beyond their reach.

As production moved from the traditional areas to the Riverland and Sunraysia, the Almond Co-operative Ltd., recognised the situation, sold their property in Adelaide, and secured, in an arrangement with Berrivale Orchards (formerly B.F.J.), a part of the R.F.P. cannery site, and moved their plant into this area.

A joint venture on the packaging and marketing of almond products was entered into with Berrivale Orchards. New products were released, and employment for around 15 people was found in a district with serious unemployment problems.
This surely is an example of an Industry which is very much self motivated and progressive.

I am convinced that for the Industry to expand there needs to be support for the investor dollar, and an encouragement for investors into this field. However, if the Government is to discourage this, then surely whatever projects were started prior to the Treasurer's announcement should be able to bring their undertaking to fruition.
Yours sincerely,
ADRIAN H. LACEY
COMMERCIAL MOTOR VEHICLES LIMITED AND ASSOCIATED COMPANIES
241 Flinders Street, Adelaide, South Australia
Address Mail to Box 2238, G.P.O., Adelaide 5001
7th February, 1986
Senator D. Vigor,
10 Pitt Street,
Adelaide, S.A. 5000
Dear Senator Vigor,

I appreciated the opportunity to meet with you recently and to indicate our concern, shared, of course, by a great number of other people, at the changes proposed by the Federal Treasury as it affects taxation write-offs for rural development.

Whilst I appreciate the Government's desire to stamp out tax evasion, it is our view that there has been a gross Government over-reaction to the so called `Pitt Street' or `Collins Street' farmers, ripping off the system.

Quite obviously no tax system is perfect as has been demonstrated repeatedly over the last few years, and there well may be some persons taking advantage of current taxation laws as it relates to agriculture.

However, the Government's contemplated action will, in our opinion, be counterproductive in that legitimate rural development of the type not requiring Government support or subsidy and which contributes positively to the economy, but which in the development stage result in losses being written-off, should be considered in the light of the long term advantage to the community.

Some five years ago our Company decided, in conjunction with Mr Adrian Lacey, to participate in the development of a 500 acre almond orchard at Lindsay Point, adjacent to previously planted almond orchards totalling some 750 acres, and about 20 kms east of Renmark.

We entered into this $2 million project which involves very considerable funds for development, and significant initial losses until such time as the trees become productive, in the expectation that we could afford to stand the development costs and losses by absorbing such losses against profits made elsewhere in our Company.
It is now proposed by the Treasurer that commencing in the financial year 1986-1987 these losses can no longer be claimed if above $20,000 per annum.

The change in the rules announced by the Treasurer simply means that in our case, we have not even reached the productive stage generating any surplus cash flow, and therefore we will have to delay the balance of our planned development for 3 or 4 years or until such time as sufficient income is available from existing trees to enable us to continue our planting programme. This is a costly and unnecessary delay.

We believe that in agricultural projects such as this where development costs are high, where there is a significant lead time before the trees become productive, it is quite unfair to change the tax rules halfway through such a major commitment.

Our Company is solely involved also in the development of a 300 acre pistachio plantation at Robinvale in north west Victoria. This is the largest single pistachio-growing project so far undertaken in Australia.

Pistachios do not come into production until the 6th year and based on the limited number of pistachios currently growing in Australia, there is no guarantee that American production experiences will necessarily be those which we will enjoy here.
Some 18 months ago we planted our first 40 acres of pistachios and had planned to plant approximately a further 50 acres a year over the next five years.
Based on the current tax proposals by the Treasurer, we will be in a position to plant 52 acres this year, but we will then have to delay further plantings for some years ahead.

It is our view that the Democrats should strive to obtain agreement from the Government that negative gearing should be allowed long term development projects, such as which we are involved in, which were commenced prior to the date of the Treasurer's announcement.
In the case of both almonds and pistachios, Australia is by no means self-sufficient.
Although the Australian production of almonds has increased from 700 to 2,000 tonnes over the last decade, we are still only producing 40% of the current market requirement.
A further 5000 acres of almonds could be planted in Australia before the total current local demand was satisfied.

The ability therefore to continue with these projects, to improve rural farm income, to help even in some small way to redress the current balance of payments problem, would seem to us in themselves sufficient reasons to allow the writing-off of development costs to continue.
In the case of pistachios, there is virtually no local production and at the present time, imports are running at approximately $1.5 million a year.
Furthermore, the technology is not presently available in Australia for pistachios, as is the case with almonds, which have been grown here for over 100 years.

At considerable expense to our Company, our Manager has visited on two occasions the Californian Industry, as well as this Company hiring an Advisor to visit from the U.S.A. and report on our operations. The Industry in Australia has gained a great deal from these visits.

We have been responsible for the importation of the very latest rootstock resistant to the killer root disease Verticillium wilt (present also in Australia) which had devastated large areas in California before the release of this rootstock, and make these available at minimal cost to other local producers.

In the U.S.A. the pistachio nut has been the `glamour' nut during this decade in particular. Through advertising and promotion the domestic market has seen huge expansion, which we confidently expect could happen in Australia. This would result in considerably more areas planted here to meet local demand, and, in addition, a lucrative export potential which is so far untapped could be developed.

It seems incongruous under Mr. Keating's Tax Proposals that businesses can write-off research and development costs provided they are not associated with agriculture. At the same time, profitable agricultural enterprises could write-off development costs in either another agricultural enterprise or an industry, but when it comes to an industry trying to develop a self supporting agricultural development, then it is not provided the same benefits.

It seems to us at the very least the Government should be prepared to honour policies which were in existence before the Federal Treasurer's announcement on the tax reform package, if justice is to be done in this country.
This is the aspect on which we would certainly seek the support of your Party and you in the debate when the matter comes before the Senate.
Yours faithfully,
COMMERCIAL MOTOR VEHICLES LIMITED
J. A. CRAWFORD, A. O.
MANAGING DIRECTOR
PRIVATE FORESTRY COUNCIL
Tasmania

Senator David Vigor,
Parliament House,
Canberra. A.C.T. 2600
Dear Senator,
During this coming session of Parliament you will be called upon to consider the Treasurer's Tax Reform Package.
The Private Forestry Council of Tasmania supports the principle of Mr. Keating's motives but cannot agree with its implementation in the present proposed legislation.

The Private Forestry Council with the Australian Forest Development Institute has been working for the past seven years endeavouring to influence Governments to seriously look at the taxing of forestry activities. Numerous inquiries have also urged Government to review the matter. Even your own Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce reporting on ``All aspects of Australian's Forestry and Forests Products Industries'' called for action within six months of tabling its report; that was in December, 1981.

Recently the AFDI prepared and widely distributed in Parliamentary circles, a most capable expose on the Treasurer's proposed amendments in quarantining primary industry losses as it effects forestry. The submission points out the inequities and discrimination against private forestry investors. It does not clearly say that hitherto there were upfront tax benefits for the investor. The removal of the present benefits to the likes of the Pitt Street farmer will be detrimental to private forestry development in Australia and set back any hope of achieving early import replacement. (Wood products are the second major imported commodity after oil.)

It is the contention of this Council that the forestry issues involved require detailed analysis before being generalised into an ill-conceived category. The appended graph illustrates how an investor under the present law, even at 60% tax rate, can earn 4.6% Internal Rate of Return on his investment in 25 years (Curve D) compared with the quarantining proposal (Curve C) where the best he can achieve is 3% over 40 years. The investor will be 35% worse off in approximately double the time if the amendment is passed.

It is the objective of this Council to see trees planted for the benefit of Australia. The motives for the action whether it be commercial, farm shade and shelter, visual landscape, erosion control or control of rural tree decline is unimportant to the establishment of the trees. The present Government's policy implemented through several Departmental programmes, Greening Australia, National Soil Conservation and various CEP projects, confirms the importance of massive tree planting schemes.

To achieve the generally excepted principle of a Greener Australia the investment money that that sound, controlled, taxation investment and development allowances would attract could be immense and thereby save public funds in the creation of a National asset. The concept of investment allowances is not new within tax legislation. Since the 1960's such measures have been used to achieve National aims, land clearing, petroleum and mineral exploration, manufacturing equipment and just recently, research.

The argument is in favour of the investor because the bona fide farmer is provided for in both current and proposed legislation. If investment money is rejected what is the alternative to create the needed asset.

My Council commends to you the AFDI submission to the Hon. John Kerin and seeks your support to examine the issues involved and if you agree with the merits of the case to refer the matter into Committee.
I thank you for bearing with me on this protracted matter of the taxing of forestry activities.
Your sincerely,
J. G. ALLWRIGHT,
Chairman,
Private Forestry Council

TALK.START.PARA: —The letters show distinctly that these areas have terrible problems and the Government has not properly thought out its policy. The Government is applying a capital gains tax to depress further rural land prices and depress further investment in rural industries. There is no way that rural people can get out of trouble that way. There are high transport costs in rural areas with purchases even bearing sales taxes on the prices which are already inflated by the transport costs. Outdated procedures for controlling dumping of rural produce from overseas on our local markets are contributing to this sorry picture. Outdated tariff protection for our local manufacturers is forcing our rural producers to pay well above world prices for their machinery, while being forced to export without support on those same world markets.

SPEECH.PARA: Unilateral compulsory acquisition of land which has been developed to high levels of productivity over generations is also having a bad effect. The Government has supported union sabotage of our export abattoirs-the Government failed to uphold the right of producers to sell their stock. The inflated export inspection charges on rural exports, against which the Democrats have stood, is another problem area. Meat inspections cost more than three times what is does when done by a State department. It is clear that the J curve effect that we were expecting to be associated with the devaluation will not appear. Waiting for the J curve is like waiting for Godot. The Government is just waiting while the whole economy is going to pieces, particularly the rural economy. I deplore this fact.

We need to explore alternative trading mechanisms such as barter and the development of local regional economic communities to give strength to our exporters and producers. We need to have imaginative ways of handling the export problem and we need to help our farmers.

TALK.START.PARA: —The time for consideration of the matter of public importance having expired, I now call on consideration of Government papers tabled earlier this day, pursuant to sessional order.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This Government of disposable promises has disposed yet again of another promise. In five minutes we are expected to deal with a matter which in the other place was a ministerial statement. It is utterly and totally deplorable, but presumably that is all the time that we will have. In looking at this Government's statement I looked at a number of items. For example, on page 8 the Government says:
. . . Aboriginal people in all mainland States will have secure title to their reserves.
Later on that page, the Government says:
. . . Aboriginal needs are complex and far-reaching, and secure tenure to land, important though it undoubtedly is, meets only one facet of these needs.
It is fascinating to go back to the 8 December 1983 statement, in which the Government said:

We in this Government came to office with a concern that our predecessors had allowed conservative State Governments to slow the momentum of that earlier progress and to that extent the Constitutional prerogatives of this parliament were eroded.
Now this Government proposes to abandon this issue entirely to those conservative State governments. The Government also said in the 1983 statement:

We will have consultation with the Aboriginal people. We have enlarged the resources available to the National Aboriginal Conference and have given it means to speak to the Government as the national voice of Aboriginal interests.
This Government has destroyed, completely shut down, the only national voice of Aboriginal people. The Government also said in 1983:
To restore to Aboriginal people a proper form of land rights throughout Australia is not only possible but a necessity. In fact, it is the solemn duty of this Parliament.

Today we have the statement that I have just read. It says: `Yes, it is an important issue but there are other, also important, issues'. That is the normal cop out that we have seen from this Government and from so many people in the community.

As for talking about secure land rights, I mention one group of people. It may be only a small group but what has happened there is symptomatic of what this Government is doing. Yallambee is a small reserve outside Mount Isa in a creekbed. It has about 60 permanent residents and 40 itinerants living in 11 absolutely deplorable broken-down homes. What has the Government done here in terms of its solemn promise? It has done absolutely nothing. Where the community wrote to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) and said `What will you do about this housing?' the Minister wrote back and said: `We are concerned about it. We will do something about it but first you must have title to that land'. As we know, the Queensland Government will not give title to fringe groups. I read from a report tabled in the Queensland Parliament:
Queensland has established a successful Aboriginal welfare housing programme which has almost eliminated `fringe dwellers'.

This group of fringe-dwellers do not want to be eliminated. They want to live at Yallambee. What is this Government doing? It will not provide a miserly $3,000 to purchase the land on which those people are now living. So much for the promises of this Government. It has no intention of fulfilling any of the high rhetoric promises that the Minister gave in his ministerial statement in 1983. The statement before us today ought to be debated at length because it is a major statement. The Government is only intent on walking away from promises. Mr Holding's rhetoric, left unabashed by this Government and this Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), has shattered the hopes of Aboriginal people. It has heightened the animosity of miners and contributed to community ignorance and racial disharmony. The cruelty is that it would have been better for all parties if those now disposed of promises had never been made. There are still dispossessed and alienated Aboriginals who have reason to believe that the white people and their Government are, as one Aboriginal put it, `very clever people, very hard people, plenty humbug'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the time available to me I wish to speak briefly on the paper before the Senate-the text of a statement by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding). Firstly, I wish to make clear my dissatisfaction with the fact that this statement has been tabled as a paper, which results in the Senate having only a limited time to discuss it. I believe that a matter of such importance and complexity should have been tabled in this place as a ministerial statement. That would have given more scope for senators to speak more comprehensively on the paper. The paper amounts to an attempt at an explanation of the Government's toing and froing over the land rights debate.

SPEECH.PARA: After three years of preferred models, promises and prevarication the Federal Government last week unveiled a land rights scheme which satisfied virtually no one, except Mr Brian Burke, the Western Australian Premier. I venture to suggest that the Government's decisions on land rights had very little to do with the consultations Mr Holding had with Aboriginals and everything to do with the electoral backlash which it expected from the rest of the Australian community if any attempt was made to impose national land rights legislation, not to mention the unpalatable prospect of one of the Australian Labor Party's own, Mr Burke, taking the Government to the High Court of Australia if the Federal Labor Government attempted to impose land rights legislation.

This paper tabled by the Minister gives an account of how each State has dealt with land rights or is dealing with land rights. Not surprisingly, the Labor States-Western Australia, New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia-all come out with very good score cards and there is no threat of the Federal Government getting heavy and imposing legislation on them. Queensland does not come out too badly, but perhaps that is because the Federal Government does not feel up to becoming embroiled in a land rights debate with such a strong opponent as the Premier of Queensland, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen. The other two non-Labor States or Territories are Tasmania and the Northern Territory. Tasmania gets a rap over the knuckles for being stubborn and refusing to enact land rights legislation and the Federal Government undertakes to negotiate with Tasmania. What will be done if the Tasmanian Liberal Government remains stubborn is left to the imagination. The Northern Territory, as honourable senators know by now, is to remain fettered by the difficulties imposed by the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. That legislation has been in place since 1976 and it has become increasingly apparent over the years of its operation and the extension of its original intentions by the High Court that the legislation requires some amendment.

The Federal Labor Government has been promising reform since it came to power in 1983 and now, three years down the track, what has it to offer? The absolute right of veto over mining on Aboriginal land is to stay. That is one of the principal problems with the legislation yet the Federal Government is choosing to ignore it. What of a time limit on land claims, so that we can restore a bit of certainty to the Territory-so that pastoralists will know, if their stock routes and reserves are traditional Aboriginal land, not to mention the ordinary citizen with public land. Well, the Federal Government does make a suggestion about a time limit. It suggests 10 years from now-another 10 years during which confusion can reign supreme in the Territory, during which traditional land claims will crop up at the most opportune times, that is, whenever a piece of unalienated Crown land is discovered to be of some value to someone-miners, pastoralists or community organisations.

To give credit where it is due the Federal Government has said that it will introduce amendments to facilitate access across Aboriginal land for the provision of services such as electricity, water and sewerage. This is reasonable. On that point, I feel that I should mention that the Minister for Education, Senator Ryan, recently suggested in this place that in my private member's Bill, which was debated to some extent last Thursday, the elements of my Bill which go to make the same provisions were lifted from the proposed legislation of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Holding. Of course, they were not. My Bill has been on the drawing board, for over three years, and these provisions relating to access for the provision of essential services were largely based on those proposed by the Honourable Ian Wilson when he was Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in the Fraser Government. So if I lifted them from anyone it was from Ian Wilson who was working on them years ago-long before they ever occurred to Mr Holding.

On the matter of Aboriginal land rights the Federal Government often seeks to back up its actions with the authority of various experts in the field. For example, Senator Ryan recently referred to the need for Aboriginal control over their land which the Senator said was regarded as vital by Justice Edward Woodward. For the benefit of Senator Ryan I would like to bring her right up to date on what Mr Justice Woodward is saying about Aboriginal land rights. At the twenty-third Australian Legal Convention Mr Justice Woodward said:
I can only reiterate this warning--
he was referring to the warning to Aboriginal people to lay claims only to areas which are genuinely of value to them-

and suggest that Aboriginal councils and their advisers give careful thought to the extent of future claims-and even consider the advisability of forgoing or surrendering some land already claimed or granted.
Even Justice Woodward, who is quoted with such authority by Senator Ryan in this place, has acknowledged that there are problems with land rights.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —On page 2 of the statement the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) states:

SPEECH.PARA: Aborigines are citizens of the States like everybody else. They are entitled to look to the States to provide them with those basic services that State governments normally provide to their citizens.
It also states:
While their motives may have varied considerably, the underlying premise is clear; Tasmania aside, the States accept that they have a responsibility.

I am afraid that Tasmania's situation is deplorable. In Tasmania we have an Aboriginal community whose fight is not only for land rights but also to gain recognition that it exists. The myth persists that all the Aborigines in Tasmania were killed. That is not true, but the myth does persist. It is used against the Aborigines. These people are fighting for recognition. They have petitioned the Gray Government for a small parcel of land at Oyster Cove. The Gray Government has not responded in any way to this, except to say no.

The Aboriginal community in Tasmania looks with great envy at the mainland, at some of the more enlightened States where Aborigines are at least being given some land rights. In Tasmania the Aboriginal population is not only discriminated against; it is ignored. We saw in Tasmania the deplorable situation of a drive being held across the State with the goal of killing off all the Tasmanian Aboriginals. Fortunately, many escaped. Later they were rounded up under the guise of religion and herded into camps where many of them died. Some did survive. They merely want recognition. They would also like the use of the title to their mutton-birding islands in Bass Strait. Very little is said about this. Perhaps very few people on the mainland know about this. It is very important to the Aboriginal community that does exist. It is one of the few ways that Aborigines can still maintain themselves on their land and maintain their dignity. The Bass Strait islands are important to this. Of course, once again, the Gray Government refuses to negotiate.

I feel that the situation in Tasmania should be rectified. As a Tasmanian, I feel that I have a responsibility towards these people, many of whom are my friends, to try to bring their case to the nation. I hope that the rest of the nation recognises the fact that the Tasmanian Aboriginal people deserve better than they are getting from the State Government, and I hope that the Aboriginal people around the country get better than they will apparently get from the Federal Government.

After all, these people used that land. They used it wisely for 42,000 years or so and they left it in much the condition that they found it; it was still usable. They had a philosophy which allowed them and us to survive. If we now look to their culture and take some guidance from it we can all live together in harmony on this continent. If not, Aboriginal and white people alike will no longer be able to survive in Australia with any great degree of plentitude because we are running down the environment very rapidly. With these remarks I will terminate my contribution. I hope that the people of the mainland of Australia recognise the problems of the Tasmanian Aboriginals.
Debate (on motion by Senator Archer) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The 1984-85 annual report of the Canberra Theatre Trust highlights some of the basic problems in the Government's administration of the Australian Capital Territory. At one level there is the exquisite slowness with which the Department of Territories operates. At another, there is the Government's policy of running down equipment and buildings as much as possible before handing over a giant headache to the local community and to the proposed self-governing council.

The statement of the Chairman of the Canberra Theatre Trust, Mr Kerry Stokes, at the front of the report summarises very well some of the difficulties. All performing arts centres in Australia are going through a difficult period because of high interest rates. These are eating into the disposable income of families and entertainment is one of the first things to go; people just do not go to the theatre. Canberra is further disadvantaged because of the very high transport and travel costs associated with bringing productions into the Australian Capital Territory. The population is quite small and unable fully to defray the extra costs that arise because of this. The Australian Opera, the Australian Ballet, the Sydney Dance Co. and a number of productions of the Elizabethan Theatre Trust were unable to visit Canberra last year simply for this reason. At the moment we have only a tentative booking for the Australian Ballet this year; we are not certain that it will actually come to fruition.

However, the same problems arise for commercial managements of theatre. They find it much more lucrative to bring productions to the main State capital cities than to Canberra. Fortunately, money is made available through the Canberra development fund. This does attract some commercial productions. This is one of the few things in which the House of Assembly has had a say to date and I think it is very laudable. The money that goes into the entrepreneurial activity fund can be used to offset the rentals charged for the use of the theatre and thereby makes Canberra a much better place to visit for a commercial promoter. It is also available so that the rentals charged when amateur societies use the theatre can be kept at a very reasonable level.

In the report the Canberra Theatre Trust draws attention to its request of 23 March 1984 that it be allowed to participate in activities outside the centre. This would enable the Trust to use another venue if the Theatre Centre were booked out. It would also enable successful productions to tour in rural areas of New South Wales and thus extend the services which are offered. While the Trust is now allowed to sell tickets for outside venues its other pleas have fallen on deaf ears. Perhaps the Department is working on the matter but its track record does not leave much hope for an early and sensible solution.

There is also mention of the rather run-down nature of the building. The floor and seating need quite a deal of work. The foyer needs complete refurbishing and the furnishings and appointments have been battered by 20 years of constant use. Apparently there is an asbestos problem which will have to be attended to. I understand that money from the Department of Territories and the Department of Housing and Construction will enable this work to be done. However, it is disturbing that the Government has knocked back two proposals for imaginative reconsideration of the facilities and the development of this area into a more useful community resource. If attitudes do not change, the people of Canberra will be handed a crumbling problem of major magnitude. It seems that the Government's intention is to do this in every area associated with self-government. I hope that this fact will be noted and that we can introduce various changes into the self-government program to help such organisations as the Canberra Theatre Trust. I commend its annual report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make just one or two quick remarks particularly in relation to the comments made by Senator Vigor who, I think, told half the story in relation to the Canberra Theatre Trust. If one reads a little more detail into the letter, written by Kerry Stokes, the Chairman of the Canberra Theatre Trust and addressed to the Honourable Gordon Scholes, one has a clearer understanding of what is happening in relation to the Theatre and its maintenance. Kerry Stokes, the Chairman of the Centre, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Minister,
On behalf of the Canberra Theatre Trust I present the Twentieth Annual Report of the operations of the Canberra Theatre Centre for the year ending 30 June, 1985.
I think it is worth mentioning at this stage that the Theatre Trust and the Theatre Centre have been operating for 20 years and have done a remarkably good job. Mr Kerry Stokes continued:
The report details the Trust's achievements during the past year and also those factors inhibiting the satisfactory realisation of the objectives specified by the Ordinance.

A comparison with other Centres shows that our operation is efficient, especially in terms of subsidy per unit of attendance. Careful management and stringent economics in a time of rising costs and reduced touring activity have resulted in costs being contained. But the decline in usage and attendance, which have been evident for some time, are still causes for concern. These problems are common to performing arts centres throughout Australia but are accentuated in our case by the relatively small population and the age of the Centre.

If Senator Vigor had pointed out those matters it would have been fairly clear that the Centre has done a very good job and that the Government has not completely neglected it. From the time the Centre has been operating, the work done and productions put on by it have resulted in wear and tear. I think that point has been recognised by the centre and the Government. Mr Kerry Stokes continues:

The Trust has accorded high priority to the development of local arts activities. The encouragement of professional and semi-professional local companies, through joint ventures, and the class programs, are obvious examples.

We especially indicate our concern for the physical state of the Centre. Twenty years of energetic use have taken their toll and decisions concerning the future of the Centre cannot be postponed without serious detriment to the cultural life of the Canberra community.
I think everyone agrees with that. The letter has been written to the Minister for Territories. If we were to ask him I think he too would agree. Mr Stokes continues:
The Trust has submitted proposals and we are disappointed that they have not been accepted. Nonetheless--
this is the point that was not raised-
further proposals are in preparation and will be submitted after consultation with officers of your department.

I repeat that this letter was addressed to the Minister and signed by Kerry Stokes, Chairman of the Canberra Theatre Trust. The other point raised by Senator Vigor was that there is no opera in Canberra. The letter continues:
The obvious omission was opera. As mentioned earlier, the Australian Opera does not visit and Canberra Opera disbanded.
I do not think that point was made by Senator Vigor. The letter continues:
Dance was well represented with programs from Australian Dance Theatre, Qld Ballet, Canberra Dance Ensemble and others including folk ensembles from Spain and Bulgaria.
Musicals included Graeme Bond's Captain Bloody, touring productions of Beach Blanket Tempest, Footrot Flats, Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs . . .

So the Theatre has performed very well and has had a large number of productions in the 20 years in which it has been operating. I think the point has been made to the Minister that some repairs and work need to be done to bring the centre to the level it was when it was first opened. I think that Kerry Stokes, the Chairman, and the Minister realise that further work needs to be carried out. Some work needs to be carried out to save the Centre so that we can have productions of this sort of art and musical productions at it. I hope that in future Senator Vigor, in his endeavours and enthusiasm, will tell the full story, not half the story, in relation to the Centre.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I wish to speak on behalf of the productive sector of the economy even if it is on only a very small report for what is one of the smaller primary industries. The Fishing Development Trust Account has been going for some years. It handles only a fairly small amount. In the year under review it was $350,000. It has a very wide effect on the fishing industry and fits in very well with other research moneys from other sources. It does not have the same constraints that some other funding has but it gets right to the point and it does things when necessary. The Fishing Industry Act annual report shows that only five new projects were added to the list this year but it continued with some of the existing projects.

I think that we have now all come to realise that Australian waters are not very plentiful with fish and that we need to guard very carefully what we have. We need to handle in the best possible manner what fish we have; we have to try to look for the species of high value; we have to conserve them adequately and we have to increase as much as possible the value of the work we do to the catch. This body does nearly all of those things.

A major project has been in operation for the last three of four years which makes an adequate survey and assessment of deep water fish from southern New South Wales to south-eastern and south-western Tasmania. The results have been very patchy. I believe that we have now reached the stage when we have to accept that this area will never be a major fishery. We will find that there will be patches of fish. It will be expensive fishing but I believe that the amount of research that has been done will probably prevent some disasters in the area of over-fishing when the resource is really quite limited.

Over the last few years I have had a lot of interest in the endeavours to establish an octopus fishery in Bass Strait. While the trust account has done quite a lot of work and provided funds for this project over a period, the research has been held up for a remarkably small item. So far it has not been possible to produce a clip that will stand the corrosion on the bottom of Bass Strait to hold the octopus pots to the line. After some years of research we still do not have a material that can withstand this and it is holding up research. I am very sorry about it because a young fisherman called Michael Hardy, whom I have mentioned in this place before, has done a lot of work on this. At times he has given up other forms of fishing to concentrate on this matter and it is a pity that all the technicalities of the situation have not enabled him to maximise his effort. I appreciate the part played by the Fisheries Development Trust Account over the years and the way in which it operates in conjunction with the other financing bodies.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —I warn the honourable senator that he has only a little over a minute to speak.

—Thank you very much, Mr Deputy President. I will go directly to page 4 of the statement of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden). The Minister states that the Philippines will need all the help and encouragement it can get from its friends. I wanted to speak particularly to that point. For my sins 30 years ago I happened to be in the Philippines as a journalist just after the death of Ramon Magsaysay, who, as honourable senators will remember, was pledged to land reform in the Philippines and the other things that the Minister talked about in the statement which he has made today. Not much changed in the Philippines after that. I want to remind the Government of the intractable nature of the problems in the Philippines and the fact that the accession of the Aquino Government has not necessarily solved those problems but that they must be solved. I implore the Minister to go further than he has in this statement and to try to use whatever influence he has with the Aquino Government to see that there is a genuine program of land reform in the Philippines. Such a program is urgently needed and will be resisted by those regional power groups, especially of the army, which, I assure the Senate, will still be in place.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister said that the expectation of reform is acute and widespread. He has really said something there. The barrios in the Philippines have suffered for decades. It is not good enough for us now to sit down and consider that all has been solved and that because of the people power in the Philippines this matter need not concern us any more. With those words I can only reiterate the need for us to take as positive an attitude as we can towards the Philippines without committing that final sin of intruding unduly in the internal affairs of that country.
Debate (on motion by Senator Kilgariff) adjourned.
Motion (by Senator Kilgariff)-by leave-agreed to:
That the resumption of the debate be made an order of the day for General Business, Thursday.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Dolphins and Whales in Captivity

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 March, on motion by Senator Georges:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I started my presentation on the report of the Select Committee on Animal Welfare on 12 March and I wish now to continue. At that time I was pointing out that Senator Brownhill, who is also a member of the Committee, made a dissenting report. Senator Brownhill, speaking on his decision to issue a dissenting report, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Having taken that decision, I believe I have been proven right by the only people qualified to comment-those scientists, marine park operators, zoologists, marine biologists who work in the field of cetacea.

These are not the people who really should be listened to. Listening to these kinds of people would be akin to listening to the woodchippers on an evaluation of whether or not to make an area into a national park because all these people have a vested interest. Senator Brownhill said that he had been proven right by the only people qualified to comment-the marine park operators. They want to make money out of dolphins. That is what they are interested in. It is a commercial operation. So their comments would have commercial merit but in terms of animal welfare they have no right at all to comment.

What about the scientists, the marine biologists and the zoologists? I was an academic for 18 years and I know how it works. These people are trying to save their academic rice bowls. They are on a good wicket. They have got something to study. They have made their whole academic career out of studying dolphins in captivity or dolphins in general. It is quite good for them to have these dolphins kicking around so that they do not have to go out and get seasick on a boat. They can study them in place. Certainly they are trying to protect their vested academic interests. These people are not dispassionate observers of the scene; they have a vested interest-and so it goes. I think the people we want to listen to are those who have the welfare of dolphins at heart-the people who are truly interested in the welfare of the dolphins, not people with some commercial or academic interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —People who don't mind them dying in the wild while the other ones are in captivity.

—The honourable senator says that these people do not mind the dolphins dying in the wild while others are in captivity. What an obnoxious thing for him to say. I hope that he will retract that statement because it is a slur on the very people who were so concerned about these animals that they got the Committee on Animal Welfare going in the first place and then testified before it. Senator Brownhill is using that old chestnut that constantly comes up. He is saying that since something terrible is happening some place else we all ought to rush off and do something about it and leave his pet project alone. That is not so. We ought to work on them all. Certainly we are concerned about the gill netting of dolphins. This is something at which this Senate and this Government should have a look because dolphins are dying in gill nets. Probably while we are speaking dolphins are dying in gill nets in Australian waters and this should be handled.

SPEECH.PARA: But what about the oceanariums? Do they have any impact on this? Not likely. In fact, during the Senate hearings, Mr Gordon Anderson from the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service stated that the presence of Atlantis-a dolphinarium-was not critical to the research program, which could have proceeded without captive dolphins if none had been available. This research program refers to the gill netting of dolphins. Here we have a testimony that the dolphinaria are not essential to the stopping of gill netting. Senator Brownhill, in referring to the effects of captivity on cetacean sonar, stated:
In Australia, work has been conducted at Atlantis, Western Australia, over five years on this subject, with no recorded loss being established.

Project Jonah and all the animal welfare people contend that there is good reason to believe that a concrete tank acts as a reverberation chamber. It is only common sense. Dolphins are used to living in an open sea environment. If they got reflections off anything it would be off the bottom of the sea. If we put them in a tank they will get reflections off the side of the tank. It is impossible to prevent this even with a catenary curve in a tank as some of the dolphinariums are proposing. Doctor Peter Fullagar, a highly qualified geophysicist, who deals with seismology, noted in his submission to the Senate Committee the way in which waves are refracted around the earth's surface. He has said:
. . . there are reasons to conclude that acoustic conditions inside a tank would be both unpleasant and disorienting for cetacea.
I think common sense could also add that of course they would be. The dolphin is a free swimming animal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to add a few remarks on the report of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare as it relates to dolphins and whales in captivity, particularly as it relates to dolphins or cetacea, as they are referred to in the report. I wonder whether many people in Australia would know what cetacea are, but everybody knows about dolphins of course. They have been in captivity in oceanaria in various parts of the world for many years and have given pleasure and enjoyment to very many people, both young and old, as they have watched displays.
—Yes, but what about the dolphins?

—Well, I have not been able to talk to the dolphins, so I am not too sure about that, but children particularly enjoy these displays, and I would say that adults in the main are only grown children. Figures available tell us that five million people each year go to oceanaria in various parts of Australia, including Seaworld on the Gold Coast. I can speak about the high standards of care at Seaworld because I have had the opportunity of going there and seeing it for myself, just as I have seen the vast numbers of people who enjoy going there and taking the opportunity to take their children. I have taken my grandchildren there and I know just how much they enjoy it. Throughout the world 110 million people each year go to see dolphins in oceanaria. I believe that these dolphins should be given adequate room to live, and paragraph 8.15 of the report recommends strict guidelines for the future care of cetacea. If there are strict guidelines and they are adhered to, it would seem to me not to be quite so wrong to keep them in captivity. Paragraph 2.25 says:

SPEECH.PARA: Recently there has been increased interest in observing . . . cetacea in their natural environment. Numbers of visitors to Monkey Mia, in WA, to see the dolphins, have grown considerably. Dolphins are common along the east Victorian coastline and are regularly observed in Port Phillip Bay.

I was up in Torres Strait towards the end of last year and saw quite a number of them around there, but in most cases it is very difficult to see the dolphins. They are lovely animals to watch. I suppose it is nice for them to be free in their natural state, but it does not give people as a whole the opportunity of seeing them. I understand recently one of the dolphins at Monkey Mia was speared by a tourist, so it does not seem to me that dolphins in their natural environment are any safer than they are in captivity.

The Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin, made a statement about dolphins being caught in nets of foreign fishing boats operating in north Australian waters. He expressed concern about the catching of dolphins-he did not call them cetacea by the way; he called them dolphins-in the gill nets of foreign fishing boats operating in northern Australian waters under agreement with the Commonwealth. I understand, too, that hundreds of dolphins die in shark nets off the Australian coast. Does that mean that if all the oceanaria are to be closed, as is suggested in New South Wales, all the shark nets around Australia should be removed, if one takes the argument to the ultimate. I am sure that many people who swim in our oceans would be very upset if that were to happen.

It is important that animals be well cared for and those of us who live in the country appreciate this. At home we, as do other people who live in the country, have horses for riding and dogs for cattle work, all of which are well cared for. At our place even the possums are well cared for because every night when we are home they get fed. The birds at Bethany do not have to go looking for food as seed is given to them every day. I believe we want to look after animals and birds. I think it is important to remind Australians of the need to care for their animals, but I do not think we want to get carried away by information from the animal liberation people who tell us that dolphins in captivity are not being looked after, because I believe that they are. I believe that the owners of oceanaria would want to look after dolphins in their care to the best of their ability, so that they will live in captivity and will be able to multiply. This is happening in all the oceanaria throughout Australia. If they were not being well looked after, I am quite sure that this would not be happening. In addition, it gives pleasure to millions of visitors to oceanaria in Australia and also helps to maintain successful business enterprises, so that oceanaria will continue to give pleasure to people throughout Australia, adults and children as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that the Select Committee on Animal Welfare was unanimous in all but three recommendations, and it was certainly agreed on the general thrust of the recommendations, acknowledging the welfare aspects of the inquiry and the deficiencies in the present treatment and conditions of captivity of cetaceans. I make no apology for using the word `cetaceans'. I think that it is increasingly a word known to the Australian public and covers a number of species. Senator Brownhill, who dissented from those three recommendations, seems to have had second thoughts about the rest of the report, but I shall return to some of his comments later.

SPEECH.PARA: In discussing the report I draw particular attention to the evidence of a high rate of disease, of mortality, and particularly of infant mortality. In other words, they may breed, as Senator Bjelke-Petersen said, but that does not mean that the offspring survive. There was also evidence relating to stress, particularly due to the acoustic properties of concrete tanks and changes in behaviour and social relationships brought about by the conditions of captivity. I think Senator Sanders has adequately answered Senator Brownhill's complaints about the acoustic evidence.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was not very good evidence that he gave.

—I could go into the matter in more detail, but I do not think there is any point in going over it again. It is expert evidence by Dr Fullagar, who is an expert in this area. Senator Brownhill referred last week to the letters he has received disagreeing with the recommendations of the Committee. I emphasise that there is a large body of scientific data which shows the opposite. We have referred to sound stress and I cite one further authority, Geraci, who identified the following problems of captive cetaceans:
