SPEECH.PARA: (a) Hierarchal aggressive behaviour by dominant animals on subordinates, from which no escape is possible in captive conditions, leading to injuries and death. Restricted space in dolphinaria appears to increase this aggressive behaviour.
(b) Nutritional disorders associated with a restrictive captive diet.

(c) Susceptibility to disease of recently caught cetaceans leading to high mortality rates, notably during the first few days and weeks of captivity. Exotic diseases that have not previously been described in wild specimens are not uncommon in captive cetaceans.

The argument has been advanced that dolphinaria and similar establishments are educationally valuable. This argument may have had some merit in the past, but it has little in these days of widely available video, television and film material which can show these mammals in their natural state behaving normally rather than as circus performers.

In many parts of Australia it is possible for children to observe cetaceans in the wild. I think, for example, of the southern reaches of Port Phillip Bay in my own State. But certainly care is needed-this was referred to in the report-both in observation at sea and in filming because of the possibility of interfering with the lifestyle of the animal. Senator Brownhill referred to gill netting which, if honourable senators will excuse the metaphor, is a red herring. I might agree that gill netting is harmful, but it is not part of the terms of reference of the inquiry, which deals with cetaceans in captivity. Of course, those who object to the capture and keeping of cetaceans also object to gill nets-not just for cetaceans but also for other sea life-but that is not relevant here. Nor do I agree with Senator Brownhill's inference that it is a good thing to exhibit these creatures because people flock to see them. That was some of Senator Bjelke-Petersen's argument as well. People used to go to stare at mental hospital patients, and they still stare at cock fights and other blood sports; but that does not justify them.

Those who are complaining about the Committee's recommendations are, I believe, motivated far less by the desire to advance education and research than they are by commercial considerations. Most dolphinaria, or oceanaria, or whatever one likes to call them, do little research or genuine educational work. Nor have they been, with a few individual exceptions, prominent in the rescue efforts which have been mounted to save stranded whales, quite successfully in recent years, by various groups around Australia.

Incidentally, the man who proposed showing captive cetacea in Melbourne, who complained widely and not always with complete honesty about the findings of the Senate Committee, failed to respond to my answer to his letter, in which I answered a number of the points that he made. I can only assume that he found that he could not satisfactorily answer those points. I am very pleased that the Cain Labor Government in my State of Victoria has taken a decision to prohibit the keeping of cetacea and their capture in Victorian waters. The New South Wales Government has this week taken similar action, and I congratulate it.

I am not a person who is prone to anthropomorphic tendencies-that is, imputing human characteristics to animals. But there is a strong case, based on a large body of research, to show that cetacea are high in the order of species, on the grounds of intelligence and of demonstrated complex social behaviour. I think that there were flaws in Senator Brownhill's argument last week, when he said that there was no correlation between those two so, therefore, neither was valid. As a psychologist, I have read a lot of that research and seen a lot of visual material on the subject. I should like also to quote the words of Jacques Cousteau, whose name is familiar to everyone here, as it is to most people in Australia. He has said:

Marine mammals, and toothed whales in particular, stand above and apart from all other creatures except man. They deserve protection and respect. I am sincerely against using them as circus animals and therefore I am against the creation of commercial exhibits of live marine mammals.
I commend the Committee for its report and recommendations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, would like to speak about the report of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare in regard to dolphins and whales in captivity. I commence by commending the Committee on the work that it has put into the consideration of this important matter. I am very pleased that the report recommends the establishment of high standards for dolphinariums in Australia. However, I should like to address my comments on the report to two particular recommendations about which I have some concern. The first is that no further facilities for keeping captive cetacea be permitted to be established in Australia. The second recommendation is that existing oceanaria be allowed to continue keeping cetacea for the time being but that the keeping of cetacea be eventually phased out unless further research justifies its continuance. The Committee has based its recommendations on the following conclusion:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . benefits of oceanaria in Australia for humans and cetacea are not longer sufficient to justify the adverse effects of capture for captivity.
That conclusion must be questionable in light of available scientific and highly regarded evidence. On page 73 of the report the Committee states:
Analyses of mortality rates and longevity can be used for the objective measure of the welfare of animals in captivity.

But independent scientific research, both in Australia and overseas, has shown that there is no conclusive evidence to support this view. Indeed, as Michael Bryden, Reader in Anatomy at the University of Queensland, has indicated, the Atlantis Marine Park in Western Australia has not had a single mortality. Improved husbandry methods have improved the welfare of captive animals significantly, and further application of stringent husbandry methods, as recommended in the report-with which methods I fully agree-will result in greater welfare for dolphins in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has done so for pigs and fowls, too, in intensive husbandry.
—Yes. Another view accepted by the Committee was:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . evidence points to the probability that cetacea have complex social behaviours and are highly intelligent.

That appears on page 3 of the report, and that view is also based on questionable reasoning and, it would appear, a lack of objective, scientific support. This identification of complex social behaviours and intelligence implies that ants and bees--

TALK.START.PARA: —We did not say that at all.

—Just hang on; let me finish, Senator; you will have your turn next. This identification of complex social behaviours and intelligence implies that ants and bees, which also have complex patterns of behaviour in a highly complex social structure-I am sure that Senator Georges would not deny that-are therefore--
—We did not say what you are suggesting in the first place.

—I am not saying that you did, Senator; I am just simply making the point that because ants and bees have those structures, it could follow logically that they, therefore, also are highly intelligent. Acceptance of this argument--
—But we did not say that.
—I am not saying that you did, Senator.
—Yes, you are; you are inferring that we did.

—I understand that the honourable senator may be able to respond in a few moments. Acceptance of this argument warrants the cessation of keeping ants and bees in captivity, which, of course, would be an absurd result. Moreover, there is no evidence to support the view accepted in the report that dolphins have a particularly high intelligence compared with non-human animals, such as dogs and sheep. Indeed, the only evidence that supports the view that dolphins have a particularly high intelligence relative to other non-human mammals, is that dolphins have a large brain.

SPEECH.PARA: Sir Francis Crick, who is a Nobel Laureate, believes that the large brain of dolphins is related to their sleep patterns and metabolism and may have nothing to do with intelligence. The evidence cited in the report for the `intelligent' dolphin is--

TALK.START.PARA: —Did he say `may'?
—Yes, I think so-`may'.
—He did not say `has'.

—No, that is right; and I shall come to that shortly. The evidence cited in the report, though, for the `intelligent' dolphin is dismissed by other independent scientists because of its lack of objectivity, as they see it. The view that `dolphins are intelligent' does not stand up to objective and rigorous testing and cannot be employed to support the case against the captivity of cetacea. The report also fails to pay due heed to the benefits in terms of scientific research for all Australians and the international community.

SPEECH.PARA: Much of our understanding of the needs and behaviour of captive aquatic animals, including cetacea, has proved invaluable in the protection and management of their wild counterparts. Without oceanaria, we will be unable to learn how to treat dolphins in the wild with the care and attention that is necessary in the interests of animal welfare. Unless some of these animals were kept in captivity, it would be very difficult and expensive to conduct the necessary research. After all, in the wild, cetacea are extremely mobile. The report also fails to acknowledge the negative economic impact of the possible shut-down of those parks already in existence and of forbidding any new marine parks. I understand that in New South Wales, for example, two parks have already been threatened with closure. I have no objection to the Government having a say in terms of the operation of parks and the standards to be set, but I would think that there would be advantage in giving existing parks an opportunity to upgrade their standards rather than to threaten them with closure prematurely. Uncertainty and risk for future developments in the industry will occur as a result of the recommendations. Existing owners will be reluctant to upgrade their facilities, because they may keep cetacea, according to the report, only for `the time being'.

Our tourist industry could well be affected. First hand contact with cetacea plays a vital role in raising public awareness of this important group of animals. Thousands of people visit marine parks each year. Closure of marine parks would force tourists to turn to other countries where they could view dolphins. We would completely lose control of the environment and practices of marine parks if they were banned. I repeat what I said at the outset: The Opposition welcomes the recommendations of the report concerning the upgrading of facilities and improved husbandry methods. But, if the recommendations regarding the possible closure and prohibition of establishing new parks are adopted, it will be a very severe blow to our international standing in the scientific community.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not speaking on behalf of the Opposition, are you?

—No, I am speaking privately. I would not do otherwise. The adoption of those recommendations would curtail our efforts in the protection and management of captive animals and their wild counterparts. It would have an unwarranted negative impact on the economy and, to a degree, on the social fabric of Australia. I believe that emotions, rather than dispassionate discourse and objective evidence, will be the modus vivendi guiding policy decisions in this area unless we are very careful. That is not a good basis for making sound and responsible policy decisions. I hope that the Government will give these issues full consideration before taking final decisions. I hope that State governments also will be influenced in that way.
—I think you ought to read the report again.

—I have done so. In conclusion, the point I am making is that the evidence on this issue is very balanced on both sides. I believe that the report and its recommendations need much more careful consideration before firm decisions are taken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare on its report entitled `Dolphins and whales in captivity'. I believe that it is a further step in what one might call the civilisation of mankind. One should thank organisations such as Project Jonah which, in the last 10 or 15 years, have brought new thinking into the area of the treatment of animals. I believe that, just as Australia stood foremost in the world in regard to the stopping of the trade in whales, it is important that in this area a recommendation of the Senate Committee makes it clear that we do not want to see an extension of the holding of cetacea in captivity. The report is the result of careful consideration and analysis by the members of the Committee. I believe that the first three recommendations are outstanding and important. The first recommendation, in paragraph 8.9, states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Committee recommends that no further facilities for keeping captive cetacea be permitted to be established in Australia and that no further permits be issued for the capture of cetacea in Australian Commonwealth or State waters. It further recommends that importation of cetacea from overseas be banned.

One might say that the actions which the Victorian Government and, apparently, the New South Wales Government are taking indicate that this recommendation will be accepted. The second recommendation, in paragraph 8.10, states:

The Committee also recommends that existing oceanaria be allowed to continue keeping cetacea for the time being but that the keeping of cetacea should eventually be phased out unless further research justifies their continuance.
The third recommendation, in paragraph 8.12, states:

The Committee recommends that existing oceanaria be required to submit to more stringent assessments of educational and research functions by supplying detailed information similar to that required for applicants for scientific and educational permits in current Commonwealth guidelines and to be able to show that education and research constitute a significant component of the oceanarium's activities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I am glad to hear Senator Brownhill's interjection. The report is not unanimous; but it seems that Senator Brownhill has rather firmed up his attitudes since the time he put in his dissenting report. However, before I come to that matter, I say that some conclusions which the Committee makes in the report are very important, such as that contained in paragraph 6.26, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: There is general acknowledgment, even among those who support oceanaria, that cetacean behaviour is changed by captivity and that adverse effects may result.
There is sufficient evidence in the report to suggest that this is so. Paragraph 6.35 states:
Available information does confirm that all cetacea suffer some stress during capture and transportation.

It is clear that most environments in which cetacea are kept are not similar to their native environments and, undoubtedly, cause a great deal of distress to fairly sensitive animals such as cetacea. The keeping of cetacea in concrete cages without a semblance of natural life is not approved of by the Australian people generally. I think the Australian people generally will approve of this report. As I have said, New South Wales, and particularly Victoria where there is a current application for the establishment of an oceanarium, have made it clear that such practices will not be tolerated.

It has been said that the Committee was not unanimous in its recommendations. Senator Brownhill has put in a short dissenting report. I point out how very limited are the matters from which he dissents. He recommends in his dissenting report that paragraph 8.8, which states that the benefits of oceanaria are no longer sufficient to justify the adverse effects of capture on cetacea, be deleted. He states:
I do not believe the evidence is sufficient for that conclusion to be reached.

In other words, he is not persuaded by the whole of the evidence. Paragraph 8.9 of the report recommends that no further facilities for the keeping of captive cetacea be permitted and that no further permits be granted. Senator Brownhill's recommendation is very limited. His recommendation is as follows:

The Committee recommends that no further permits be issued for the capture of cetacea in Commonwealth or State waters, unless there are adequate scientific or educational reasons for so doing. It further recommends that importation of cetacea from overseas be banned.

I do not think he is suggesting in that recommendation that the evidence does not exist. It is clear from my reading of the report that the evidence is very substantial to show that no further permits should be granted. The third paragraph from which he dissents is paragraph 8.10, which recommends that the existing oceanaria be allowed to continue but that they be phased out unless there is scientific justification for their continuance. Senator Brownhill's recommendation is as follows:
The Committee recommends that existing oceanaria be allowed to continue keeping cetacea, provided they meet the strict guidelines and national standards proposed in this Report.
I do not think Senator Brownhill is suggesting that the keeping of cetacea should now be phased out.

Certain arguments which have been raised in the debate, particularly by Senator Brownhill, have been replied to in a letter, which I think we all received, from Dr Stephen Whiteside, the Co-Director of Project Jonah, dated 14 March 1986. For the sake of convenience, I seek leave for the letter to be incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Dear Senator,

Project Jonah believes that a number of statements and assertions made in the House by Senator D. Brownhill on 12th March, 1986 are either incorrect or misleading, and thus, must not be allowed to pass unchallenged. These statements (in parentheses) together with our response, are as follows.
(i) Referring to his decision to issue a Dissenting Report, Senator Brownhill states:

``Having taken that decision, I believe I have been proven right by the only people qualified to comment-those scientists, marine park operators, zoologists, marine biologists who work in the field of cetacea.''

Scientists and marine park operators are most certainly NOT the only people qualified to comment. The issue is in large part a moral one and should therefore be judged by as broad a cross-section as possible of the general community. Community-based groups such as Project Jonah therefore are extremely well qualified to comment on moral issues such as this, as was well recognised by the Senate Committee. Indeed, if the discussion were left to scientists and marine park operators alone we would have no Report to discuss, as it was the work of groups such as Project Jonah, Greenpeace and the Australian Conservation Foundation that originally provided the stimulus for the Report to be commissioned.
(ii) Referring to the question of the effects of captivity on cetacean sonar, Senator Brownhill states:
``In Australia, work has been conducted at Atlantis, Western Australia over five years on this subject, with no recorded loss being established.''
Project Jonah contends that there is good reason to believe that a concrete tank acts as a reverberation chamber, which is likely to be highly unpleasant to captive cetacea.
In his submission to the Senate Committee, Dr Peter Fullagar, a highly qualified geophysicist, states:
``. . . there are reasons to conclude that acoustic conditions inside a tank would be both unpleasant and disorienting for cetacea.''

The fact of the matter however is that no formal study of this nature has ever been undertaken. We seriously doubt whether the Atlantis study included comprehensive recording of wild dolphins for comparison with captive specimens.

Indeed, even Dr M. Bryden, from the University of Queensland, a staunch supporter of the captivity of dolphins, knows of no such study having been performed. In a letter of his to Senator Brownhill (29th January, 1986) he states, in reference to the effect of concrete tanks on dolphins' sonar:
``. . . it could easily be tested, and should be tested.''

While we do not share Dr Bryden's optimistic assessment that it would be easy to test, we certainly agree that it should be tested. Certainly, Dr Bryden's implication is quite clear that, to date, it has not been tested.
(iii) Senator Brownhill states:
``. . . successful breeding in captivity is increasing, with calves born at Marineland, South Australia, the Porpoise Pool at Coffs Harbour and at Warragamba, New South Wales.''
The fact of the matter is that there is a gulf between ``successful breeding'' and the sporadic births referred to by Senator Brownhill. Moreover, these births relate to dolphins only.

False killer whales (pseudorca crassidens) are also held captive in Australia. There are no reported births of false killer whales in captivity anywhere in the world. Sea World (Queensland) has put forward a proposal to exhibit killer whales (orcinus orca) in captivity. Only one of the small handful of killer whales to be born in captivity has survived for more than a few months. It was born at Sea World (Orlando, Florida) in September, 1985 and hence is now only six months old.
(iv) Senator Brownhill states:

``Recently the Committee Chairman, Senator Georges, was quoted on television as saying very little work had been done on the accidental trapping of dolphins in gill nets. The truth is that substantial work has been done on this subject and is continuing. This work would have been impossible without the availability of captive dolphins.''

During the Senate hearings, Mr Gordon Anderson, from the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, stated that the presence of Atlantis was not critical to the research programme, which could have proceeded without captive dolphins if none had been available. (Senate hearings 24th April 1985, Hansard pp. 3, 773-4).

The problems of gill nets is far greater than just the numbers of small cetacea they entangle. Many other forms of marine life are also trapped and drowned. Indeed, gill nets are an unsound method of fishing, as they are totally non-selective, and generally deplete all fish from a given area in an uncontrolled fashion over a period of years. Groups such as Project Jonah are calling for a total cessation of gill netting operations in northern Australian waters.
Senator Brownhill continues:

`Over 3,000 dolphins are trapped each year in gill nets. Only fifty dolphins are kept in oceanaria, and yet it is these captive dolphins that have attracted the attention of the animal liberationists while thousands of others die accidentally each year through fishing operations. The argument is not in perspective.'

The fact of the matter is that Project Jonah first submitted evidence to the Senate Committee on Animal Welfare in relation to both the Taiwanese gill net industry and cetaceans in captivity on 14th March 1984 (two years ago today). Since that time, we have continued to lobby Federal politicians and public servants in an attempt to achieve our aim of the total cessation of all northern Australian gill net fishing operations.
The Minister for Primary Industry, the Hon. John Kerin, issued a public telex on 17th February 1986 in which he stated:

`A review of policy on pelagic gill netting is underway to develop a alternative approaches which could be adopted should research fail to demonstrate a satisfactory method of reducing the dolphin catch.'

Project Jonah commends the Committee for its Report, and urges that the Government accept its Recommendations. Unfortunately, however, it seems to us that Senator Brownhill is motivated more by a desire to defend the short-sighted interests of dolphinarium owners than a desire to properly address the complex issues involved.
Yours sincerely,
Dr Stephen Whiteside,
Co-Director,
Project Jonah (Victoria).

TALK.START.PARA: —Dr Stephen Whiteside expresses in the letter certain views as to the questions that have been raised in the debate so far. The answers to the questions raised are, to my mind anyway, pretty conclusive. I believe that this report stands as a landmark in a story in which Australia has taken the lead, so far as animals are concerned. I believe that the Committee is to be warmly commended for the work it has done. Its job is arduous and it still has things to do. Already the State governments have indicated their support for the Committee's recommendations. That in itself is evidence of the success of the Committee. I commend the report warmly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the report by the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare entitled `Dolphins and whales in captivity' I commend my colleague Senator David Brownhill for his work on the Committee and not only for his dissenting report, which I agree with--
—He was not part of the inquiry.

—I am getting to that. Senator Brownhill was thrown in at the deep end to a Committee which had a lot of work to do. He has been able to read up on a lot of the evidence that was given and has come to the decisions he has. All of us, when we are first elected to this place, know how hard it is, when we get put on these standing or select committees, to get the feel of the committee, how it operates and all the rest of it. Senator Button and I were on the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts. We both hit this place at the same time and both went through the learning curve but in this instance Senator Brownhill, as Senator Georges rightly says, was not there and had to read a lot of the evidence afterwards and still come to his conclusions.

SPEECH.PARA: I must confess, with my limited experience on Senate committees and their reports, that I am disappointed with the standard of this report. The Senate standing committee and select committee system is second to none in this nation and the reports are held up by everybody around Australia as reports of stature and their recommendations are looked at by all those who are involved and, indeed, are acted upon by many tiers of government. Yet this report really is not up to the reputation and standard which I have come to expect of our Senate standing committee system. It is one of the first reports I have seen which is based more on emotion than on the evidence as presented. I think it is a deplorable state of affairs when our Senate select or standing committees get to that stage. The high reputation of the Senate and its standing committees is at stake. It is rather unfortunate that this has happened. There is not much time and I will just touch on two factors.

TALK.START.PARA: —No. You have nothing to say. You have not got much time. You denigrate the Committee.
—Just relax, Senator Georges.
—How can I relax in the face of that?
—Senator Georges will get his turn. In chapter 7 under the heading `Ethics', paragraph 7.2 states:

SPEECH.PARA: Many people concerned with animal welfare now question whether humans are entitled to exploit animals and to act in a manner which will cause animals to suffer.

I have no quarrel with the concern about causing animals to suffer. Nobody would agree with animals being made to suffer, whether in captivity, in the wild or wherever. The report states in paragraph 7.3:

Critics argue that oceanaria exploit cetacea primarily for profit and that this is morally indefensible because it causes suffering to cetacea, who, as intelligent and complex beings, are entitled to greater consideration by humans.

Who are the critics? They are not the great mass of people out there, of course, but a few select people whose evidence this Committee has seen fit to pick up-the Project Jonahs and all the rest of them. What is wrong with exploiting animals? The economy of this nation depends on the exploitation of animals-by dairy farmers, beef farmers and sheep farmers. We would not be in the situation we are in today and indeed this nation would not have been founded if it had not been for the exploitation of animals. Yet here we have this emotional statement-critics saying that it is morally indefensible to exploit animals. That is one of the things I mean when I talk about the Committee's emotional reaction to this.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are being as emotive as any of us.

—I am not being emotive; I am being quite practical. I am a dairy farmer. Other people here are sheep farmers and beef producers, and we all exploit animals for this nation. Indeed, those who have worked with animals know quite well that they have to look after them because, if they do not, they will not get the best out of milking cows in the bails, mustering beef cattle for market or shearing sheep in the sheds. Of course we exploit animals. This nation runs on the exploitation of animals, but in a good, proper and well ordered manner. But the critics argue that oceanaria exploit cetacea primarily for profit. Well, I never! This is seen as one of the major planks of the Committee's report. Senator Sanders said that this was such a terrible thing. Of course, if we have listened to the union movement over many years we will have heard that employers have exploited employees, but we will not go down that track at this time of the afternoon.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Georges had a debate with Senator Short on whether dolphins are intelligent and complex beings. What does that mean? Senator Zakharov talked about them being of a higher order. There is no scientific evidence to categorically assert the level of intelligence. Neither complex behaviour patterns nor size of the brain are indicative of intelligence, and indeed Senator Short picked up that point. Many of our animals and insects have very complex behaviour patterns but it is certainly no indication of intelligence. Page 32, chapter 4, in relation to Project Jonah, states:
. . . the tacit assumption implicit in dolphinarium displays that the capture and exploitation of a weaker animal (e.g. dolphins) by a stronger animal (e.g. man) is perfectly legitimate.

It is rather emotive language, to say the least. Anybody would think that dolphins or any animals which lived in the wild were living in the Garden of Eden. It is a jungle out there. They fight for their very existence. When they come into captivity it is usually found that they have plenty of parasites, worms and all the rest of it in their digestive tract, and it is generally accepted that they do not have very long life spans. It is a jungle out there, not a Garden of Eden.

I have no argument with Senator Georges on how they are treated in captivity. On that we are one. I fall out with Senator Georges on the idea that somehow or other having animals in captivity can be deleterious to them. As a matter of fact, I think the dolphins are far cleverer than we give them credit for. Most of the dolphins that I see are doing what they like doing in the environment they like doing it in and they have men trained to stand on the beach and throw them food. I have to give them credit for that. Let us forget this idea that somehow or other we have taken them out of a Garden of Eden and put them into a hostile environment. I have never heard anything so silly in all my life.

It appears that the Committee's report unfortunately dwelt on the fact that there was an application for an oceanarium and evidence was given about that. In reality that was not the Committee's brief. Its brief was to look in totality at the merits and the way that dolphins can be kept--

TALK.START.PARA: —What happened was that we were forced into that situation. We admit that in the report.

—Okay; that is admitted. It is unfortunate that it happened that way, but I still stand by what I said originally. Senator Georges will get no argument from me on the fact that their welfare is all important. It is up to governments to set standards by which they are kept. I welcome those recommendations that set those standards and I look forward to their upgrading, but I cannot accept the allegation that I laid down. I stand by what I said. It is unfortunate that members of the Committee got off on an emotional tack and let their good judgment on the evidence presented be swayed by the emotion of the arguments put up by the minority groups who make a very comfortable living out of the exploitation of all these issues that arise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the report of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare entitled `Dolphins and Whales in Captivity'. I commend the Committee for having brought to the attention of the Senate and to the attention of the Parliament a series of issues which need to be addressed. The report, in essence, has three primary recommendations. The first recommendation is that there should not be the establishment of new facilities for dolphinaria or for the public display of cetacea in captivity. Secondly, there need to be clearly defined standards for those facilities which will continue to exist. Where necessary, those facilities should be up-graded to appropriate standards. Thirdly, there should be no capture of animals from the wild for further display in dolphinaria. I agree with the first proposition, that there should be no new facilities established. I agree with the establishment of standards and the recommendation for the upgrading of existing facilities to appropriate standards. The only criticism and caveat that I express about the taking of cetacea from the wild is that from time to time there will be dolphins, in particular, which have been stranded, injured, or may be sick and which should be taken into facilities to save their lives. To that extent I depart, perhaps only marginally, from the recommendation.

SPEECH.PARA: Scientific evidence I suppose is like political opinions; it is possible to line up any number of scientists on both sides of just about any argument. In the long run, a lot of these decisions will have to be made by the political system, by people like us who are not scientific experts but who will have to make up their minds on the basis of the weight they accord, from their experience and intelligence, to differing scientific opinions. That is fair and proper. After all, it is very much what we are elected to do. There are differing scientific opinions on at least three critical factors in the cetacea issue. There are differing opinions on the intelligence of cetacea. For a start, we are never altogether sure what we are measuring. To all intents and purposes, intelligence can be defined only as that which happens to be measured by intelligence tests. To that extent, it is therefore open to a considerable amount of discussion and debate as to whether dolphins and cetacea in general are more or less intelligent than, or as intelligent as, any other animal for which we have some sort of measurement.

Secondly, there is dispute about the actual facilities and the effect of keeping animals in these facilities. There are questions about acoustics and the dolphins continued capacity to communicate with each other, and considerable questions about the health of animals in captivity. The third matter touches on mortality rates. The difficulty is that it is extremely difficult to measure what are natural mortality rates in dolphin populations. Evidence is simply not available to establish the average life span of a dolphin. We certainly do not know very much about the natural mortality patterns. What we do know is very much confined to a small part of the dolphin population-the bottle-nosed dolphin. We know nothing about the Irrawaddy River dolphins, white dolphins or Hecton's dolphin-mainly in Tasman waters. To that extent, scientific evidence is not necessarily as clear as one would like.

I will say something briefly about three other issues. The first is that in response to the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare I made it my responsibility in the last two months to visit the three dolphinaria in New South Wales. I spent some time specifically at Warragamba, Port Macquarie and Coffs Harbour to look at the facilities. In at least two of those facilities there is a very substantial need for significant upgrading, even of the existing facilities-let alone speculating about the future.

The Coffs Harbour facility and the way that Mr Hec Goodall runs it, are excellent. The Senate Committee conceded in its report that it is excellent and that it make a contribution to research and, in fact, to improving animal welfare in general and the welfare of cetacea in particular. I am a little concerned about some of the responses by the State Government in New South Wales. Mr Carr, the Minister for Environment, put out a Press release on 14 March. He announced that there would be a New South Wales Marine Mammals Protection Act, which I welcome. It is long overdue. He said basically that two of the three New South Wales facilities would be closed down. His Press statement said:
In addition, all dolphinariums in New South Wales except one are to be phased out and all remaining captive marine mammals are to be made the property of the Crown.

I am distressed that once again the New South Wales Government has taken the opportunity to move into the seizure of property. Whether it should be in the hands of the people who currently own it is a matter for debate. I do not believe that the New South Wales Government should unilaterally intervene to make into the property of the Crown that which is currently the property of somebody else. That is a different debate. I do not want to get into that other than to express my concern. I will mention two other matters. The first is that I was delighted to see the Press release from the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) on 17 February indicating that there would be a review of pelagic gill netting and the very serious matter of the incidental catch of dolphins as part of the commercial fishing operation. That is very serious for wildlife policy and needs to be addressed. I am glad that the Government is doing something about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the shark nets to protect the swimmers on the east coast?

—Senator Brownhill is absolutely correct. There is a whole series of arrangements-whether for shark netting, the fishing industry or long-line operations-which clearly have to be addressed if we are to have a sensible approach to the whole problem, rather than focusing on one aspect.

SPEECH.PARA: The final point-perhaps it is here that I part company somewhat with my friend Senator Collard and some of my other friends on this side of the chamber-is that I think it is correct to say that there is a moral dimension to the whole way in which human beings treat animals. It is not just a matter of whether we believe that they should be exploited or not, but it does touch very fundamentally on the sorts of standards of behaviour we, as a society, believe are acceptable in dealing with other living creatures which, to that extent, are totally within our power-over which we in fact have power of life and death. For a large number of them the inevitable fate is that they will die to serve the needs of the human species, whether for food, clothing, transport-whatever it happens to be.

Nevertheless, the way in which we treat those animals is a matter of concern not just for animal liberationists and welfare people but for people who believe that human beings are tested in terms of their standards of behaviour by the way in which they personally, and as a community, react in situations in which they have total power, and other living creatures are powerless. That is an important moral question. It is an emotional question. It is not possible to take the emotional and moral dimensions out of the debate about animal welfare issues. It is important to address them sensibly, rationally and on the basis of information. To the extent that the Senate Committee report raises those issues and compels us to confront them, I welcome it. I congratulate those involved in its preparation, in the final report and the dissenting report, and in its presentation and exposure so far in the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Puplick's statement that the issue of keeping animals in captivity is a moral one. It is also a welfare issue and, for many, an economic issue. The keeping of dolphins and whales in captivity is simpler than the overall general problem because there are relatively few people who will be economically affected by the decision to ban the practice. Those most affected are scientists, marine park operators and zoos. Even so, for the few affected, this is an important issue. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a letter outlining the problems of one such venture so that I can answer some of the problems.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
MARINE WORLD VICTORIA LTD.
Area Office:
79 Nepean Highway, Aspendale,
Victoria 3195
17 February 1986
Senator D. Vigor
Parliament House,
Canberra,
Dear Senator,
Thank you for your concern and interest in the issue of the problems facing dolphins and whales.
As has been shown by the continuing controversy, the termination of our project, `Sequana Marine Garden', was to be the `cutting edge' of the worldwide campaign to close all Marine Parks.

Contrary to the beliefs of animal rights activists, dolphins and whales are not essential to `Sequana'; our concept embraces the whole marine zoological world. However, the recommendations within the Senate Report and the subsequent decision by the Victorian Government to act upon those recommendations, will have devastating and far-reaching effects on the long-term conservation of dolphins generally, and small inshore dolphins particularly.
Who will now continue our work on the environmental effects on dolphins and whales? This may be an unpopular issue, but I assure you, is essential to the wellbeing of animals in the wild.

It has been accepted that `Sequana Marine Garden' has strong educational and scientific purposes, and that the facilities will be available to Universities and serious researchers. The only marine species that we now cannot offer our services for, are dolphins and whales.

The only work on the problem of gillnet fishing, is being carried out on captive dolphins. Remove dolphins from Marine Parks, and the very core of this important research is automatically eliminated. Measure if you will, the eleven dolphins and two false killer whales we proposed to keep, against the thousands killed each year.

You will also know that if the opportunity is taken away for the public to be aware of these wonderful animals, you also have a continuing decline in public empathy for them which, in this technological age, will be to their long-term detriment.
In short, the Report does three things:
Denies dolphins the benefit of research into the effects on them caused by human encroachment into their environment;
Denies them the benefit of research into netting problems, which would prevent thousands being killed each year;
Risks loss of public empathy for them, to their long-term detriment.

`Sequana' is going ahead without dolphins. However, if there is genuine concern within the Senate for cetacean welfare, then there is no alternative but to reject the recommendations of the Senate Report which affects the continuance of oceanaria, and recommend to the Victorian Government to review their decision.
The future of the species may well depend on this decision.
Yours respectfully,
RODNEY ABEL
Managing Director

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The letter mentions a number of issues and I wish to point out that there is some doubt as to the educational value of seeing dolphins in confined spaces. I shall come back to this later. I also seek to incorporate in Hansard a letter from Mr Fensham which handles this point effectively.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
MONASH UNIVERSITY
Clayton Victoria Australia 3168
Telephone: 03 541 0811
Telegrams: Monashuni Melbourne
Telex: Monash AA32691
2 April 1985
Mr Paul Barsdell,
Secretary,
Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare,
Parliament House,
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
Dear Mr Barsdell,

My attention had been drawn to the fact that there is an application in Victoria from some commercial interest to establish a ``dolphin-arium''. Furthermore, I understand that this application is supported by a claim about the education value of such a venture. It is about that claim that I am writing to your committee since I do have some expertise in relation to environmental education within which broad umbrella other ecological education fills. Your committee, I assume, will be influential in how decisions about such applications are made.

Whatever other educational purposes the managers of such a dolphin-arium set out to achieve, it is hard to escape the fact that the concrete reality will be that the viewing public will learn that it is legal, proper and appropriate to keep dolphins in such a confined unnatural space and to use them for public entertainment.

A paramount goal of environmental education is to establish in its target audiences of learners an appreciation of the ecological subtleties and balances of whatever biophysical system is being taught. There is no way that the dolphin-aria that I have seen elsewhere could be argued to be a reasonable approximation of the natural eco-system of dolphins. We may have to compromise and approximate the natural system in order to make it assessable and this is done with other animal species in zoo education and in in-school studies. However, at least recently, the approximations of the natural eco-systems in zoos have been improved considerably and strenuous efforts are made to separate educational programmes in such places from the exploitation of the animals for entertainment.

Fortunately, modern technology is enabling us in education to ``bring'' much more spectacular accounts of animals in their natural eco-systems into the classrooms of formal education and into the lives of the general public. The steadily increasing availability of high quality TV programmes including ones about dolphins offers educators very good alternatives.
Accordingly, I would argue that you should not take too seriously the educational aspects of this proposal.
I would be happy to enlarge on these points and support them with more detailed educational evidence, if your committee so wishes.
Yours sincerely,
PETER J. FENSHAM
Professor and Dean,
Faculty of Education

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I would like to see alternative ways explored for continuing the acquaintance which man has been developing with dolphins and I am very excited by the initiatives taken by dolphins themselves. At Monkey Mia, a fishing resort in Western Australia, dolphins come in every day to swim in the shallows and play with the local swimmers.
—One got killed the other day there too.
—It is a dangerous business for the dolphins. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a report of the activities at Monkey Mia. It is a single page report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The report read as follows-
GREENPEACE AND THE MONKEY MIA PROJECT

It is noon in the arid coastal fishing resort of Monkey Mia, Western Australia. Desert-red sand dunes shimmer under the merciless midday sun, the silence broken only by the gentle lapping of water on the bay shores. Campers lie in the shade of their tents and caravans, or sit chatting in the shallows, seeking relief from the oppressive heat. And yet, in a matter of minutes, the scene of languid tranquillity is transformed. Cries of `Here they come' echo around the campsite, and children and adults alike hasten towards the beachfront.

What is occurring is a daily ritual which has taken place for the past sixteen or so years, for at this remote part of Western Australia, wild dolphins come into the shallows daily to make contact with people. Nowhere else in the world has this kind of interaction occurred on a regular and long-standing basis. Adults, children, the aged and the disabled are all given the opportunity to observe, touch, feed and make friends with free dolphins. It is unique because it is on the dolphins' own terms; they are not constrained in any way, nor `trained' to amuse us like their unfortunate captive counterparts. one dolphin, identified as `Holey-Fin' has been known to virtually beach herself by wriggling up onto the sand in order to reach a young baby who could not yet walk, allowing the baby the opportunity to play with her. The dolphins will politely take fish from tourists, and they have occasionally brought in fish from their hunting expeditions to give to people in a delightful exchange of social pleasantries.

Monkey Mia has become famous internationally, and is one of Western Australia's major tourist resorts. Greenpeace, along with many other groups and individuals, has been involved in trying to ensure Government protection for the area, and the preservation of this human/dolphin experience. Increasing numbers of tourists have placed the dolphins under enormous pressure. During the peak tourist season, there can be anything up to 300 people lining the beachfront all vying for the attention of a few dolphins. Developers have applied for permits to build a luxury motel complex on the beachfront where the dolphins can swim inshore in order to accommodate yet more people, and attempts made to be granted permission to carry out sand mining operations in the nearby Shark Bay area. Fortunately, intense lobbying and a sensible government attitude ensured that these proposals were refused, since any sudden changes to the dolphins' habitat or social experiences could potentially frighten them away from continuing their daily visits.

Greenpeace has also joined with others in requesting that the Western Australian Government provide funds for employing a warden whose job it would be to control the crowds and inform the public about dolphins behaviour. Last year, the government announced that funds would be made available, and that it also intended to partially finance the construction of an information building on the beachfront at Monkey Mia. Greenpeace will be contributing financially to this particular project. The centre is now being built, and will contain educational material, books, videos, leaflets and photographs so that the public can gain maximum educational benefit from their experience with the dolphins.

Hence, Monkey Mia is for the moment, and hopefully in the long-term safe from exploitation. Its protection is a tribute to the prevailing common sense and sensitivity of individuals, groups and governments alike, and the patient perseverence of those dolphins who continue to allow us the opportunity to get to know them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I note that the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare has decided not to seek closure of existing marine parks and zoo enclosures but to impose minimum standards for care and environment for cetacea. I endorse these findings of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to canvass another area where cetacea are affected by man's economic activities; I refer to the fishing industry. Problems arise for cetacea both from direct fishing for whales and dolphins and from incidental damage caused to the species while trawling or netting fish. This has been covered by Senator Puplick to some extent. Whaling has now been banned in almost all countries, which is indeed not before time. In fact some species of whale are still threatened with extinction. There is already some evidence of recovery for some species but the blue, fin, sei, humpback, right and sperm whales are still in very low numbers.

Another mammal which is still economically exploited is the seal and I believe that we need to expand our look at these areas. The recent ban on imports of seal skins by the European Economic Community has been welcomed by all who are concerned with this animal's welfare. The last economic exploitation of a cetacean seems to be the killing of dolphins, or porpoises as they are also known, both directly for food and because they are actually competing with man in fishing villages. This is happening in Taiwan. In Australian waters gill-netting, which is carried out for salmon in Japan and shark, mackerel and tuna in Australian waters, is actually drowning dolphins which are mammals like us and have to breathe air. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a letter from Mr Ashley Wilmott from Greenpeace Australia Inc. on this matter.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
GREENPEACE AUSTRALIA, INC.
First Floor,
155 Pirie Street,
Adelaide, S.A. 5000
Dear Friend,

We humans have had a special relationship with dolphins throughout history. The Ancient Greeks revered them for their wisdom, and the penalty for killing a dolphin was the same as that for killing a person.
There are many accounts of dolphins rescuing drowning sailors, and co-operating with fishermen by herding fish into their nets.

For all the harm we have done to them, dolphins maintain their trusting, friendly attitude to people, and indeed appear to seek out human friendship. A notable example is the situation at Monkey Mia, a remote stretch of the Western Australian coastline where dolphins regularly interact with humans for no reward other than friendship itself.
Dolphins deserve our reciprocal respect and we should do no less than ensure their complete protection.

``Dolphins are completely protected in Australian waters'', I hear you say; and most would probably believe this statement to be true. Yet the real truth is that thousands of dolphins die at the hands of fishermen around our coastline every year. Lovable, sensitive and highly intelligent dolphins that many of us admire for their free spirit and gentle nature drown slowly after becoming entangled in fishing nets. The nets that are responsible for the vast majority of dolphin drownings are called gillnets, designed to trap fish by their gills, and are very efficient but highly indiscriminate in what they catch. Gillnets are invisible to dolphins, turtles, dugongs and seabirds as well as the fish they are supposed to catch, and form veritable `curtains of death' for any marine animal unlucky enough to swim into them.

By far the largest number of dolphins are taken by the Taiwanese gillnetters operating under licence in the Australian Fishing Zone (off our northern coast) in the Timor and Arafura Seas. About three thousand dolphins drown in nets set by this fishery each year. The Taiwanese are actually fishing for shark, mackerel and tuna, currently using 270 kms of nets (with an average length of 9 kms and a depth of 15 metres each) out of 30 vessels. They set the nets at dusk and allow them to drift in the currents until they are retrieved the next day.

Five species of small marine mammals are caught in these fishing operations, with the Bottlenose Dolphins constituting 80% of the total numbers. The other species caught are the Spinner Dolphin, Spotted Dolphin, Indo-pacific Dolphin and the False Killer Whale. Three species of turtles and dugongs are also caught. Dugong populations are especially under threat, being already listed as an endangered species.

Gillnets are equally devastating to fish populations. Their very effectiveness leads to over-fishing and ultimately a decline of fish stocks. The percentage of non-target fish caught (known as trash species) is particularly high resulting in even further ecological disasters, akin to clearfelling of forests!

These facts are well known by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service and the Department of Fisheries. Australian Fisheries observers spotcheck Taiwanese ships to monitor the catch and determine the numbers of marine mammals caught. What has now come to light is that the Taiwanese grossly under-report the numbers of mammals caught.

Meanwhile the Australian Government not only allows the renewal of the licences for the Taiwanese to continue, but is encouraging Thailand to operate in a joint venture with Australia by waiving licence fees! This will dramatically increase the number of dolphins caught each year. It appears that the dolphins must suffer in the interests of promoting a fishing industry in our northern waters, whereby Australia receives only marginal benefits in the form of licence fees.
Gillnetting in Australian waters is just a part of the increasing use of this method of fishing worldwide. It is an issue that is being taken up by Greenpeace internationally.

The Japanese high seas driftnet fishery has been a focus of attention in the North Pacific. Each year about 5,000 Dalls Porpoises and between 250,000 and 750,000 seabirds become entangled in their nets. Thousands of these gillnets are lost and continue to ``ghost fish'' and entangle marine birds and mammals while they drift without hope of being recovered.

In October 1983 Greenpeace Australia was present at the first meeting between government and non-government organisations to discuss the problem of entangled marine mammals in Australian waters. As a result of this, the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service (ANPWS) has been conducting a research program into net modifications to reduce dolphin mortality. However, the trials to date have shown inconclusive evidence that the use of acoustic reflectors, such as the metallic bead chain will warn dolphins of the presence of nets. Greenpeace sent a researcher to Darwin for six months to verify the extent of the problem and to work with the ANPWS research program to help determine a solution. It became evident that the research will take years, and many thousands of dolphin deaths, to come up with net modifications that will at best only reduce the dolphin mortality. Greenpeace will only be satisfied when no dolphins or other sea mammals are harmed. It is quite clear the gillnetting must stop.

Viable alternatives to gillnetting exist. One of these is longlining . . . A fishing method that has been used successfully all over the world for many years, which does not pose a hazard to marine mammals. Greenpeace is campaigning for a complete changeover from gillnetting to longlining within three years.

Greenpeace has been fighting for the rights of marine mammals for 14 years and has highlighted the atrocities man has inflicted on them, including the commercial seal hunt in Newfoundland, whaling the world over, and the dolphin slaughter at Iki Island in Japan.
Now we are faced with having to save dolphins in our very own waters, where such animals are supposed to be fully protected.

The capture of dolphins in gillnets can't be called incidental as it happens on a very large scale all the time. Therefore we ask you to help us fund our campaign to save the dolphins from drowning in gillnets. Please send us a generous donation TODAY, or purchase some of the merchandise we are offering in the enclosed brochure.

We rely on your contributions for our effectiveness to work not only on the issues we are already confronting, but to take on issues that are equally as important. Let's show the dolphins our mutual respect, as well as maintaining the ecology of the sea, by eliminating the gillnet problem.
Yours very truly,
ASHLEY WILMOTT
Australian Dolphin
Campaign Coordinator

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for the consideration of reports from committees has expired.

—On behalf of the President, and in accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the report of the Auditor-General upon audits, examinations and inspections carried out under the provisions of the Audit Act and other Acts, dated March 1986.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE FOR THE SCRUTINY OF BILLS

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of my colleague Senator Tate, I lay on the table Scrutiny of Bills, Alert Digest No. 4, dated 19 March 1986.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Public Works Committee, I present the forty-ninth general report of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The report which I have just tabled covers the activities of the twenty-eighth Public Works Committee during the period 28 February 1985, when it was formed, to 31 December 1985. During that period the Committee presented 16 reports encompassing a wide variety of public works ranging from a submarine escape training facility at Garden Island, Western Australia, for the Royal Australian Navy, to a new Commonwealth Law Courts building at Parramatta. The total estimated cost of work examined by the Committee during the report period was more than $255m. The report mentions at length the circumstances which required a relatively large number of proposed works being exempted from Committee scrutiny on the grounds of urgency.

SPEECH.PARA: There were four exemption motions during the year. The estimated cost of work exempted was more than $214m. The Committee, and I am sure the Senate, would not wish to see a repeat of this in future. One very significant and disturbing development which has emerged in recent years is the preponderance of proposals referred to the Committee late in the Budget sittings. I suggest that, with proper planning, referrals could be spread more evenly throughout the year, thereby avoiding the possibility of the Committee being unable to report on proposals referred late in the Budget sittings.

The Committee is conscious of the need to report as expeditiously as possible on all references. It must be emphasised, nevertheless, that the Committee has a responsibility to Parliament to carry out its functions in a thorough and expeditious manner.

I believe the record shows that the Committee has played a significant role in being the `watchdog' of Parliament since its establishment in 1913. It represents the interests and aspirations of all Australians, on whose behalf, and for whom, Commonwealth public works are conceived and constructed. The Committee intends to maintain that role during the present Parliament and, indeed, in the longer term. I thank the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT PARLIAMENTARY COMMITTEE OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts I present the report of the Committee on the Munitions Production Trust Account.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This brief inquiry by the Committee into the Munitions Production Trust Account was initiated following unfavourable comments made by the Auditor-General in his September 1984 report. The Committee examined the operation of the Munitions Production Trust Account and found that the Munitions Production Trust Account exists in addition to each of the trust accounts used to operate the Government owned munitions factories. This Trust Account was established on 17 February 1956 under section 62a of the Audit Act 1901 to replace the Manufacture of Munitions Trust Account which had operated since 1940. The purpose of the Munitions Production Trust Account as defined at the time of its creation was to finance firstly, the manufacture of munitions in Government factories, annexes and industry for departments of the Commonwealth and other governments and authorities; and, secondly, any other approved service of a munitions factory or annex.

SPEECH.PARA: The Munitions Production Trust Account can be described as a holding account, financing the production of munitions. It enables factories to obtain reimbursement for production, undertaken in advance of payment, from the Department of Defence or overseas customers. Over recent years responsibility for the Trust Account has been variously with the Department of Industry and Commerce, the Department of Productivity, the Department of Defence Support and most recently, from December 1984, the Department of Defence. The Auditor-General suggested that a separate trust account could be established if necessary to handle overseas transactions where munitions are sold to overseas countries. The Committee discovered that an existing trust account could quite adequately handle overseas munitions transactions, namely, the more general trust account called the Defence-Projects for Other Governments and International Bodies Trust Account. The Committee questions why this Trust Account and the Munitions Production Trust Account, with their overlapping functions, have not been rationalised.

The Committee concluded that the Munitions Production Trust Account has not been managed well over recent years, with financial records being lost, important procedures not followed and a lack of appropriate control documents. The Committee believes that many of these problems may have arisen because of the form and nature of this Trust Account, and that such an arrangement may leave itself open to inefficient accounting and management, together with a lack of direct responsibility or an interest in the efficient operation of the Trust Account.

Also, the Committee is concerned that the Department of Finance has not taken more interest in the operation of the Munitions Production Trust Account and has not become more involved in resolving important problems with the Trust Account. The Committee noted that the Munitions Production Trust Account causes the factories to carry out double accounting with increased administrative costs. It concluded that the munitions factories, financial statements would be more accurate, informative and be consistent with accepted accounting standards without this device. The Committee concluded that there were no cogent reasons for continuing to maintain the Munitions Production Trust Account. I commend the report to honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The 244th report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts on the Munitions Production Trust Account, I believe, is a severe indictment of the Department of Finance for not taking greater interest in the trust account and for its lack of involvement in resolving issues relating to that account. It is also a criticism of a further four departments-the Department of Industry and Commerce, the Department of Productivity, the Department of Defence Support and the Department of Defence-for various shortcomings which include such things as a loss of records, failure to produce debit notes, poor accounting controls and wrongful retention of funds for amounts of between $2m and $3m for periods between three and four years. There has also been a lack of adequate accounting instructions and accounting manuals. There is severe criticism of the failure of the Department of Defence to honour undertakings given to the Committee. There is an appalling lack of accountability when witnesses can claim that because they were not involved with the trust account at the time, they could not provide a suitable explanation to the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The trust fund account is one of three accounts used by the Commonwealth; the others are the Commonwealth Revenue Fund and the Loan Fund. Section 60 of the Audit Act provides that a separate account, to be called the trust account, shall be kept for all moneys which shall be placed to the credit of that fund under such separate heads as maybe directed by the Minister for Finance. In accordance with section 61 of the Act, moneys standing to the credit of the trust account may be expended only for the purposes of such fund or under such authority of an Act. The trust account which is in the subject of this report relates to the manufacture of munitions in government factories, annexes and industry for departments of the Commonwealth and other governments and authorities and also other approved services of a munitions factory or annex.

I wish to remind the Senate of the responsibilities of a trustee because the account is called a trust account and therefore certain obligations are placed on trustees. A trustee's duties generally are to take possession of and to preserve the trust property, to be diligent and prudent in administering it, to act personally and be impartial between beneficiaries, to keep accounts and to give information to the beneficiaries as required and to invest the trust funds in the manner permitted by statute. Some may say that the trust account is a misnomer because it is really a suspense account, but that does not absolve the trustees of their custodial responsibilities at all. Others say that is effectively a holding account financing the production of munitions. However, it is still called a trust account and therefore the trustees have all the responsibilities of the fiduciary relationships of a trustee. Furthermore, I believe that it does not excuse the appalling lack of controls and the degree of indifference between departments when functions change from one department to another. I believe that there is a requirement, when handing over records and when functions change, to make sure that the records are accurate and up-to-date so that the department taking over those responsibilities has up-to-date and correct records. Unfortunately, all too often there is the attitude: Let somebody else sort it out; it is not my responsibility.

I believe that the Parliament and the people of Australia are becoming quite indifferent to a long procession of criticisms, poor record keeping, lack of accountability, loss of revenue and spiralling Budget costs. A whole litany of items is frequently presented by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. I remind the Senate that it is not the Public Accounts Committee's responsibility to bring people to justice, its responsibility is merely to point out particular problems; it is the duty of the Director of Public Prosecutions, the Public Service Board, the Department of Finance and various departmental heads.

Of greater concern is the present disregard by the Australian Labor Party of the concept of ministerial responsibility when we have a whole litany of things going wrong and costs to the Government. While the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) daily harangues people from his coward's castle he overlooks his parliamentary responsibilities, in particular, his responsibilities to the Department of Finance, which has a lot of shortcomings. The public should be sick and tired of waste from reports surrounding the Defence Department's activities, such as the cancellation of a program to develop an Australian built basic trainer for the Royal Australian Air Force. After five years work which cost nearly $65m of taxpayers' money, this has been rejected in favour of an overseas aircraft.

Another related PAC report, on project management, identified three levels of accountability-probity, efficiency and effectiveness. It found that alternative defence options were not always identified or adequately assessed and proposals were not supported by reliable data, especially cost estimates. That report pointed out particular problems in relation to the acquisition of major defence equipment. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
