DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Palm Sunday: Peace Rallies-Tasmanian Peace Trust-Mr John Quick: Forestry Commission Tasmania

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7 p.m., under sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of the imminence of Palm Sunday, I am using the adjournment debate to speak about the organisers of the peace march and how they have contrived to involve the churches and well meaning Christians in the so-called peace march. I understand that the organisation under whose umbrella the march is being organised is the People for Nuclear Disarmament. The Palm Sunday peace rallies will take place in capital cities around Australia next Sunday. I believe that the majority of people in Australia are very suspicious of the aims of some of the people who have played an active part in organising this event. I recognise that many of the people who will attend this march, as distinct from many of the organisers, are sincere in wanting the world rid of nuclear arms and, for this reason, they adopt the attitude that this should be done on a multilateral basis. However, I want to point out to some of the leading lights of the peace movement who have helped to organise this march and try to uncover their objectives by quoting them on various issues so that the people who do march will not do so ignorant of the aims and objectives of the organisers.

SPEECH.PARA: The umbrella group organising the march is, I believe, the People for Nuclear Disarmament-sometimes known as the PND. The PND's first organisers, Andrew Hewett and Phillip Hind, were closely associated with the Communist Party of Australia. Others, such as Sam Goldbloom, are key figures in the pro-Soviet Socialist Party of Australia. The stated objectives of the PND are the mobilisation of public opinion in support of disarmament and peace, mobilisation for independent foreign policy for Australia, opposition to foreign military bases in Australia, opposition to the mining and export of uranium, and support for self-determination movements in other countries. A key personality in the PND is Dr Joseph Camilleri, who is also concerned with Pax Cristi and the Movement against Uranium Mining. In his book Civilisation in Crisis he asserted:
The central question . . . to which revolutionary Praxis must address itself . . . is how to hasten the demise of the capitalist order . . .

David Wurth, a committee member of PND, told a recent Marxist summer school organised by the Communist Party of Australia that the only reason Palm Sunday was chosen for the march was to rope in the churches. As a matter of fact, I believe that it really wanted to hold the march on May Day, which would have been more appropriate to its cause.

Beverley Symons, writing in the Communist Party of Australia journal Praxis in 1982, said that the strategy of holding the march on Palm Sunday had worked beyond expectations and she expressed surprise at the way in which Christians had flocked to the 1982 rally. It is probably not so surprising when we recall that Lenin had this to say about religion:

We (Communists) shall find our most fertile field of infiltration of Marxism within the field of religion, because religious people are the most gullible and will accept anything if it is couched in religious language.

We do not have to look very far to find church organisations which have policies and objectives to which the Soviet Union would not object. For example, the World Council of Churches, in a resolution passed at its sixth assembly, called for an end to the supply of arms to the opposition groups in Afghanistan. The World Council of Churches encouraged and subsidised the setting up of the Pacific Conference of Churches, which incorporates Protestants and Catholics. This organisation depends upon large grants from the Australian Council of Churches and the Uniting Church in Australia. The peace aims of the Pacific Conference of Churches include, firstly, opposition to multinational corporations; secondly, support for independence movements; thirdly, opposition to the nuclear industry; and, fourthly, a declaration of the Pacific as a zone of peace which would include opposition to the deployment of nuclear powered and armed aircraft, opposition to the Rimpac military exercises, opposition to mutual defence treaties or alliances and opposition to United States of America bases.

The proceedings of a conference hosted by PND in September 1985-in Melbourne, I understand-are also very enlightening. In order to achieve its goals, the conference stated that it must implement education campaigns with the goal of exposing the myths on which the ANZUS alliance and our national security are based. The myths it listed were that ANZUS increases our security and that Australia is under threat and needs a strong and powerful friend. The conference stated that we do not need a strong and powerful friend. Other myths listed were that we can rely on the United States to come to our defence; that world stability and peace rely on the maintenance of the Western alliance; that United States nuclear strategies are stabilising; and that the Soviet Union is expansionist. The conference also stressed that no country willingly moves into the Soviet camp-so far, so good-and that this is a product of unfair structures imposed by the West. When we are dealing with Soviet expansionism we have to ask: What about Afghanistan? What about Angola? What about Ethiopia, where the Russians are supporting Cuban mercenary troops? I am informed that a lot of the wheat that we provide to Ethiopia does not always find its way into the stomachs of the people who are starving in that country, but quite often finds its way into the stomachs of Cuban and other troops dedicated to keeping the Marxist regime in power. I could go on and talk about Mozambique, Hungary, Poland and other countries. Yet these people say that the Soviet Union is not expansionist. As usual, the west and, in particular, the United States are portrayed as being responsible for world instability, aggression against the peace loving Soviet Union and world poverty.

In conclusion, I would just like to mention some interesting figures concerning aid to starving African countries. According to the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organisation, the Soviet Union has delivered a total of 7,500 tonnes of cereal to the 21 starving nations. This is only one-third of the contribution of Zimbabwe. The United States has delivered three million tonnes and the European community 1.71 million tonnes.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much more is that than the Soviet Union?

—It has produced 7,500 tonnes, the Americans three million tonnes, and Europe 1.71 million tonnes. Surely a progressive super-power with a superior economic and social order could at least manage to give those countries more than Zimbabwe, rather than one-third of the contribution of that small African state. Perhaps this is because the proletariat still has to endure food queues in the Soviet Union although members of the privileged class of the Party can still get the luxuries they want. In 1980 alone, Western aid exceeded all the economic assistance granted by the Soviets in the quarter century from 1955 to 1979. Such aid as Moscow gave-parsimonious as it was-went only to countries of which the Kremlin thought it could make political use. Needless to say, the results for Soviet arms sales to Third World countries are far more impressive.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope that the people who intend to march on Palm Sunday are aware of the humanitarian acts the Soviet Union is famous for and will at least consider calling for multilateral disarmament rather than adopting the unilateral attitude which they almost inevitably take in relation to the Western democracies. I honestly believe that we should start giving the word `freedom' a little more priority than the ambiguous word `peace', although peace and freedom go well together. Peace and freedom, I feel certain, can come only through security. On Palm Sunday there will be church leaders and other well meaning Christians, including Archbishop Faulkner, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Adelaide, the Moderator of the Uniting Church, Mr Biggs, and the Church of England Bishop Rayner.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you join them and make it respectable?

—I believe that these people will march under the slogan `Disarm and feed the world'. Apparently they have been able to wipe aside the more obnoxious left wing slogans such as `Ban the bomb' and all the other stuff they usually carry around. What does `disarm' mean? It means, to my mind, getting rid of the Navy, the Army, the Air Force, and all the bases we have here and getting rid of the ANZUS treaty.
—I am leaving.

—I should think that Senator Georges would leave when he has to listen to these things. If we were really serious about peace and about demonstrating a massive procession in favour of peace, it would have been appropriate for the churches, with the aid of a responsible community committee, to organise a candlelight procession during the season of peace and goodwill leading up to Christmas. I believe if that had been done it would have been a very fitting climax to the International year of Peace. One would not need slogans to march under. All that would be needed would be a wooden cross. At the end of that candlelight procession, there could be an ecumenical service which I believe would be supported by thousands, indeed hundreds of thousands, of people. We might even get Senator Button out there marching alongside me, holding our candles and demonstrating that we are fair dinkum about peace and good will among men.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard a remarkable tirade from Senator Jessop condemning many Australians who, next Sunday, will take to the streets in order to demonstrate their concern for peace-and not necessarily in the naive way Senator Jessop suggests. Of course, those who march will be aware that many of those also on the streets, in the parks, at the rallies, or at the church-sponsored services are there because of the different values that motivate them. As long as there is a kaleidoscope and mosaic of banners and indications as to the motive force behind the various groups within the rallies and marchers, I would say that no particular person or group need feel inundated or submerged in some overall alien philosophy.

SPEECH.PARA: We need a more constructive and creative involvement of ordinary Australians in the peace movement. I want to mention a particular initiative taken in Tasmania recently which I think indicates such a move. Before I leave Senator Jessop's speech may I say that, as I recall it, late last year in the Catholic Cathedral in Melbourne there was indeed an ecumenical service, the theme of which was the seamless garment; in other words, that people needed to have their concern for life expressed over a whole range of social issues, ranging from reverence for life within the womb right through to reverence for life within cities when it is threatened by destruction through nuclear or even a conventional holocaust of weapons. It is that consistent ethic of reverence for human life which I think Senator Jessop would want to see in place and which I certainly want to see in place, rather than some of the distorted political ideological posturing that segments one form of attack on human life and says that is the one we need be concerned about. There are many of them over a whole range of social issues and perpetrated by a whole range of different political systems and non-government agencies, corporations and other organisations. We have to tackle all attacks on life wherever they occur.

The point I wish to raise is the creation within Tasmania, at a function which I had the privilege of attending at Hadleys Hotel in mid- November late last year, of the Tasmanian Peace Trust, which is entitled on the pamphlet which accompanied the opening and which has been distributed widely in Tasmania, `An invitation to invest in peace'. I bring it to the attention of the Senate because I believe that the Peace Trust can provide a model for other Australian groups in the mainland States to help fund the activity of peace groups by making them independent of government largesse and the fluctuations in funding that come and go with international years of peace and such like events. The fact is that the Tasmanian Peace Trust has been established under a very distinguished board of men and women who have already made claims for distinction in public life in Tasmania. I seek leave for the list of trustees, some 15 of them, to be incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The list read as follows:
1. Michael Aird, MHA Franklin.
2. Lesley Alcorso, State President WILPF (Womens International League for Peace and Freedom).
3. Simon Allston, Solicitor.
4. Len Barry, Trade Unionist.
5. Neil Batt, Businessman, former President ALP.
6. Peter Brain, Treasurer, PND. (People for Nuclear Disarmament).
7. Dr Bob Brown, MHA Denison.
8. Jean Hearn, Former Senator.
9. Elspeth Hope-Johnstone, Artist.
10. Doug Lowe, MHA Franklin.
11. The Reverend Father Desmond McDonnell, Anglican Chaplain, to the University of Tasmania.
12. Dr Dougald McLean, Convenor MAPW (Medical Association for Prevention of War).
13. Dr Bill Oats, former Principal Friends School, Author, Historian.
14. Doug Parkinson, Solicitor, Secretary, Lawyers for Peace.
15. Dr Robert Tonge, NW Regional Paediatrician, member MAPW.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The idea is that the Trust has as its goal the vital human goal of peace and is designed in a way which enables funds to be deposited with this legally constituted Trust under the control of the trustees of eminence whom I have mentioned. The funds are then invested in safe securities and the income is to be used for the propagation of peace within Tasmania. In other words, the moneys which are deposited are absolutely safe, the capital will never be touched, and it is only the interest that will be able to be disposed of by the trustees to various groups, organisations or persons who call for some financial assistance-it will involve only small amounts, hundreds of dollars or so-to assist them in their method of promoting the cause of peace.

SPEECH.PARA: If I mention two names, one would be Mr Claudio Alcorso, who together with his wife Lesley Alcorso, who is the State President of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom, are most prominent Tasmanians concerned in a very practical, concrete yet compassionate way with the promotion of peace within our world. The initial inaugural chairperson of the Trust is our own former Senate colleague, Mrs Jean Hearn, who has taken the chair with the full support of a wide range of Tasmanians who form the board of trustees. The formation of that board, and the initial support already obtained, makes it clear that it will transcend all political divisions and overcome many of the barriers that sometimes get in the way of concerted group activity in relation to the promotion of this cause. I express the hope that that initiative taken by a group of Tasmanians will indeed be of value, not only within the Tasmanian community but also as a model which might be adopted and adapted as needs be by people on the mainland.

One does not need to go into the Palm Sunday rallies or other activities in the service of peace other than with a prudent approach, an awareness of the desire of many to manipulate for their own political ends. But to leave the field to those whom one despises for their political views would be to betray many, particularly young Australians, who are looking for leadership and inspiration in relation to the promotion of peace. Such must not be left to the political manipulators, who so easily muscle in on the aspirations and the yearning for peace that so many Australians will want to express on Palm Sunday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was most interesting to hear Senator Tate's remarks. There is no doubt about his views, from what he has said tonight. I believe that he is a very sincere person, and one would certainly agree with the thoughts that he has put forward. They were most interesting. I do not think that there would be very many who would disagree with him. We will watch with interest the organisation that has now been formed in Tasmania. If this organisation goes along on the principles and guidelines that the honourable senator has just indicated, I believe that there is considerable scope for it.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight I wish to support the comments of my colleague Senator Jessop concerning the Palm Sunday march this weekend. In doing so, once again I refer to the closing remarks of Senator Tate, which were spot on. There is no doubt that we all want peace and must take constructive and positive steps to ensure that world peace can be achieved. I think that it is true to say that there has been a feeling in certain parts of the community that the major political parties in Australia have not been doing enough in relation to peace issues. The Liberal Party of Australia has, for some time now, been taking positive steps to rectify this situation. It has developed a policy which takes as its theme peace through security. This is the thought that Senator Jessop presented very ably this evening. This policy recognises the need to maintain the Western alliance and Australia's role in that alliance. It acknowledges the valuable role played by the joint United States-Australian facilities at Pine Gap and Nurrungar in maintaining a balance of deterrence. The Liberal policy supports continuing involvement with and commitment to ANZUS. It supports multilateral disarmament, so long as it is verifiable. These are responsible attitudes to a complex and critical issue for the people of Australia and the world.

There are, of course, other views on how peace might be achieved, and the Palm Sunday peace marches of past years-I emphasise that I am talking of past years-have been dominated by left wing groups advocating unilateral disarmament by the West, while ignoring the immense military build-up of the Eastern bloc and, principally, the Soviet Union. Most of these groups are anti-ANZUS, anti-American, and anti-capitalism. Unfortunately, they have managed to monopolise the peace debate and to a large degree exclude or put off the vast majority of Australians who support peace but who support the peace through security approach.

These so-called peace groups have, of course, been quite clever in organising the peace march for Palm Sunday. By doing this they bring in members of churches who, in addition to swelling the numbers, add an air of respectability to the marches. Of course, these people from the churches are people who have very genuine feelings, and once again I refer to the comments of Senator Tate and Senator Jessop. According to a media report this month, a committee member of the People for Nuclear Disarmament, a Mr David Wurth, said at a recent Marxist summer school organised by the Communist Party of Australia that the only reason Palm Sunday was chosen for the PND peace march was to rope in church contingents in order to give the movement respectability. We have to be very wary of this type of organisation. The churches have been taken for a ride to quite a degree. They are lending their support to extreme left wing groups with which many of their parishioners would wish to have no association. They are marching under banners such as `United States Bases Out' and `Reagan is a war-monger'-all anti-American slogans. There is no mention of the Soviets in Cam Ranh Bay in Vietnam, or of the increase in the Soviet naval presence in the Pacific. The banners are a dead give-away-the peace groups are in favour of the unilateralist approach to disarmament.

If people who do not agree with these sentiments wish to march this Sunday, I believe that they should ensure that they do not add legitimacy to the unilateralist view. To do this, they will need to differentiate their views and make it clear that they are marching for multilateral disarmament, not unilateral disarmament. They must make it clear that they support the maintenance of deterrence as a proper regulating principle for arms control, for surely the only real disarmament is mutual disarmament. People marching need to make it known that they support the Western alliance, in which Australia's own security is intimately bound up. They need to make it clear that they support the United States-Australian joint facilities which are essential to maintaining deterrence and which make nuclear war less likely.

Our policies are aimed at contributing to the avoidance of nuclear war. The breaking of alliances, unilateral gestures and nuclear pacifism make war more likely, not less. These policies must be stressed in all forums-peace marches included, if that is necessary. I can fully understand how many Australians feel frustrated and unable to do anything about the threat of nuclear war. As we have heard this evening, the young people are feeling frustrated, and it is to them that we must give some assistance and guidance. I understand that they see the Palm Sunday peace march as an opportunity to express their views on this crucial issue. But people must be sure that they are not being used to swell the ranks of radical left wing groups which advocate unilateralist policies, the abandonment of ANZUS and the closure of the joint facilities. If people are marching this weekend, they should make it quite clear where they stand on these issues, and that the Left does not have a monopoly on the answers to the problems of avoiding nuclear conflict.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to use the opportunity afforded by this adjournment debate to draw to the attention of the Senate the contribution of a great public servant who has recently retired. I refer to Mr John Quick, the former Chief Commissioner of the Forestry Commission in Tasmania. John Quick has made a tremendous contribution to the forestry industry, and I believe that it is mainly through his efforts that Tasmanian forest industries lead the rest of Australia in terms of good forest management patterns and practices. He has worked for at least 30 years for the Forestry Commission. Before becoming Chief Commissioner over five years ago, he served as Chief Forester in a number of regions in Tasmania, prior to becoming head of the Private Forest Division.

SPEECH.PARA: As head of this Private Forest Division, John Quick was responsible for a significant reafforestation program in Tasmania. Forty per cent of the forests of our State are privately owned, and it was through the efforts of John Quick that farmers clearing their land were encouraged to replant. He was responsible for giving sound management advice, for arranging for grants and loans for the establishment of plantations and for assistance with reafforestation programs.

John Quick's forestry training taught him to be a long term planner, and this has led to policies which will ensure the continuance of forest industries in Tasmania for generations. He always thought through the consequences of any proposed course of action, and he was a man who consulted as many people as possible on every new issue. He always made time to listen to the conservationists, and decisions were always made in the best interests of Tasmanians and Tasmania. He was an outstanding member of the Public Service. He was highly regarded by his staff and friends in the Forestry Commission and by his colleagues on the Standing Committee.

John Quick has two outstanding achievements in the forestry industry which I would like to mention. Firstly, he was the father of the Forest Practices Act-the first of its kind in Australia. The Act established a code and, from 1986 on, all wood must be harvested according to the code. This ensures that proper forestry management practices are complied with and that the environment is protected at all times. Secondly, he was responsible for what is known as the visual management system. All State forests in Tasmania have been colour-coded into three categories: sensitive; not so sensitive; and, basically, all systems go. In the sensitive areas clear felling is disallowed and logging can be carried out only on a selective basis. Forestry operations can be carried out only in such a way that there is very little evidence of any activity at all. Roads, for example, must be concealed so as not to spoil the aesthetic appeal of the area. In the not so sensitive areas the rules do not apply quite so rigidly. With the publicity given to the conservation movement in Tasmania, it is important to recognise the huge steps forward that have been taken by the Forestry Commission in recent years and to give credit to the sound management practices and techniques that have been instilled into our forest industries and to their concern for the environment.

I believe that John Quick's influence has spread much further than Tasmania because of the significant role he has played in the Australian Forestry Council over the last few years. He was chairman of the sub-group which was responsible for drafting forestry policy. I commend John Quick for his work and wish him well in his retirement.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 7.31 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 20 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the defence communications satellite terminal at the Advanced Engineering Laboratory Satellite Communications Experimental Facility (Hansard, 20 October 1981, p. 2255 and 18 November 1981, p. 3153) still operational.
(2) What are the formal designations and dates of launch of all United States satellites tracked or communicated with by the terminal referred to in (1) above since it was first used in 1974.
(3) What is the international designation of the DSCS satellite 93-26 (Hansard, 20 October 1982, p. 2255) and its date of launch.
(4) Is it expected that experiments with the terminal referred to in (1) above could lead to operational use of the US, DSCS system by the Australian Defence Force.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Advanced Engineering Laboratory Satellite Communications Experimental Facility is not a defence communications satellite terminal as such because it is not, and never has been, involved in transmitting or receiving military operational communications. It is a facility used for experiments to develop technical expertise with various techniques of satellite communications so that any potential operational usage by the Australian Defence Force may be assessed competently. This is the only purpose for which this facility has been and continues to be used.

(2) The formal designations (international designations in brackets) and dates of launch of all United States satellites which have been used for communications experiments with this facility since 1974 are:
DSCS I 93-23 (1967-0003C)-launched 18 Jan. 1967
DSCS I 93-26 (1967-0003F)-launched 18 Jan. 1967
DSCS II 94-37 (1977-0034A)-launched 12 May 1977
Gapfiller Pacific Ocean satellite SDS F3 (1976-101A)-launched 14 October 1976
FLTSATCOM 4 West Pacific Ocean satellite (1980-087A)-launched 28 October 1980
FLTSATCOM 2 Indian Ocean satellite (1979-038A)-launched 4 May 1979.

In all cases, access to these satellites was arranged for periods when they were not required for operational usage. Of all these communications satellites only the DSCS I satellites were in sub-synchronous orbits and required to be tracked in order to use them; all other communications satellites have been in geo-stationary orbits and, therefore, have not required tracking.
(3) See the answer to part (2) above.

(4) The Australian Defence Force already makes operational use of DSCS via its own ground station at Watsonia Barracks and via jointly operated ground stations at North West Cape and Nurrungar. The Advanced Engineering Laboratory Satellite Communications Experimental Facility was not used to conduct experiments as a specific precursor to these operational uses. See also the answer to part (1) above.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 12 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Can the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs advise the current number of Guatemalans in Australia and whether the Humanitarian Program could be applied to this country to allow more immigrants in view of the impoverished situation in which most of the people in Guatemala in Central America are forced to survive.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Ethic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: There is a small Guatemalan community in Australia but their numbers are too few for them to have been separately identified as an individual grouping in any Australian census to date.
Since 1 July 1975 Australia has resettled some 80 Guatemalans-the majority accepted from outside Guatemala under the Central American refugee program introduced by the Hawke Labor Government in 1983.

The Special Humanitarian Program (SHP) is aimed at assisting people who do not qualify for refugee entry but who are nevertheless fleeing substantial discrimination or gross violations of human rights. The SHP is not intended to assist those whose claims rest purely on their impoverished situation.

One example of SHP operations is where Australia considers individuals still within their country of nationality who are experiencing human rights difficulties. It is not, however, possible for Australia to do this everywhere. Issues which need to be taken into account before mounting such an operation include whether the target group is readily identifiable and available to undergo migration processing. Other factors include the question of whether local authorities countenance such activities by Australian migration officials and whether the safety of our officers can be guaranteed.

The poor human rights situation in Guatemala is well-documented and remains a matter of concern. Many of the Guatemalans reportedly displaced by the indiscriminate sweeps of guerrilla areas are innocent peasants or ``campesinos'' who would not be interested in resettlement outside the region and, more importantly, whose best interests would not necessarily be served by such a response. The nature of most abuses is such that it is difficult to identify in advance those individuals who may be in danger.

At this time, it is not considered appropriate to undertake humanitarian processing for Guatemalans still within Guatemala. Australia will continue to consider for humanitarian entry individual Guatemalans located elsewhere and deserving cases deemed by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, or comparable authority, to be of concern and in need of permanent resettlement.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 18 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What forms of household assistance are available for primary producers in financial difficulties.
(2) Are tin miners regarded as primary producers; if so, what forms of assistance are available to them.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Self-employed primary producers who elect to continue to run their businesses are not eligible for unemployment benefits or special benefits under the Social Security Act.

Their spouses may qualify for benefits provided the spouse's main commitment is to finding off-farm employment and they meet other eligibility criteria. The primary producer may also qualify for unemployment benefits on this basis.

Primary producers on low incomes may also qualify for the Family Income supplement which provides up to $16 per week for each dependent child. This benefit is separate from the child allowance payment.

The Rural Adjustment Scheme (RAS) is available to assist persons engaged in rural industries. Household Support is part of the RAS. This provides assistance up to the level of unemployment benefit to applicants who have low incomes and are assessed as having no long term prospects of viability. This assistance may be available for a total period of three years. During the first 12 months the applicant must be considering whether to leave farming. In order to continue to receive assistance during the remaining two years the applicant must actually be trying to sell the farm at market value. Applicants for Household Support cannot receive unemployment benefits.

If the sale of the property leaves the farmer with further financial difficulties the RAS provides for Rehabilitation assistance in the form of a loan which may be converted to a grant of $8,000 indexed to movements in the CPI from 1 July 1985.

(2) Tin miners are not covered by the RAS. However on 3 March the Ministers for Trade and Resources and Energy announced a program of assistance, modelled on the RAS, to small tin mining operators who are experiencing difficulty in rationalising their mining operations in the wake of the collapse in world tin prices.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the question put to me by Senator Vigor on 14 November 1985 (Hansard, page 2150) about aspects of operations of the Australian Bureau of Statistics, the Treasurer has provided the following information:

ANSWER.PARA: The ABS requires its field interviewers to be licensed to drive, and to own or to have access to a motor vehicle because the completion of field interviewing assignments within the specified survey period requires speedy transport in all weather conditions between addresses which are often widely dispersed. Interviews must also carry stocks of survey forms and it is not feasible for this material to be transported other than by motor vehicle.

The ABS's reliance on obsolete computing equipment is now limited to a single machine acquired in 1970 which handles a very small number of statistical applications. Since 1980 when it acquired its first FACOM computer the ABS has phased out 11 obsolete machines according to a preplanned schedule and the remaining machines will also be phased out according to these plans by the end of 1986. There have been no long delays as against planning intentions in getting the ABS central computing installation operational. The present major ABS computing installation is based on a FACOM M3 82 installed in April 1984 and is one of the most modern installations in the public service.
ABS planning for more extensive application of small-scale technology is proceeding as rapidly as possible within existing financial constraints.

The release of the results of statistical collections is dependent on various factors including the size of the collection, its complexity, and whether it is a new project or one of a regular series of periodic collections.

Important economic indicators such as balance of payments estimates, unemployment estimates, and the Consumer Price Index are published very promptly. Results of the larger or more complex collections take longer but computer processing is not a major contributing factor, and in most cases preliminary results are made available ahead of completion of processing of all data.

Not all ABS statistics are suitable for on-line access. However, the ABS is investigating the possibility of developing an on-line service through the CSIRO network to provide access to a large time series data base. Selected data will also be available shortly on the national VIDEOTEX service. Various commercial networks have offered on-line access to selected ABS statistics for some time.

The Government is very conscious of the need to make the best use of available resources in all public undertakings. Well developed processes have been set up in the ABS to scrutinise priorities and procedures to ensure that the organisation is efficiently managed. It is expected that this process of scrutiny will continue.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 February 1986 (Hansard, page 418) Senator Vigor asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Can the Minister indicate when we can expect the uniform inquiry regulations for the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal?
(2) Could further delays provide the opportunity for litigation in relation to the Tribunal's inquiries?
(3) Does the delay since 1 January mean that applicants for new commercial radio licences in Newcastle and Mandurah can only be sent out interim application forms?
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

(1) Finalisation of the regulations dealing with the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT) inquiry procedures has taken longer than anticipated due to the need to conduct extensive consultations with the ABT, industry bodies and public interest groups. Subject to the availability of drafting resources it is hoped that the regulations will be in place within a month;

(2) This is a matter of concern. However, I should point out to the honourable senator that a major consideration in finalising the regulations has been the importance of an extensive consultative process in minimising the likelihood of legal challenges to inquiries conducted under the new procedures.

(3) I am advised that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal has prepared interim application forms which it is providing to prospective applicants for the Newcastle and Mundurah commercial radio licences. It is the intention of the Tribunal to accept applications lodged in such a form in order to commence a licensing inquiry and it is not expected that such applications would need to be relodged after the regulations are in place, although additional information may be required from applicants.
This course of action accords with procedures to be adopted in the regulations which will provide the Tribunal with a discretion to accept applications that are not in the approved form.
